TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:

PARA.TAB: Australia's old growth forest and wilderness areas are being diminished as a result of continued logging. The Federal Government has granted new woodchip export licences despite its agreement for a moratorium on logging in high conservation areas.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate should:
apply conditions retrospectively to woodchip licences in order to meet Commonwealth obligations, and
exclude from licences, woodchip derived from old growth forests and wilderness.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law

PARA.TAB: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled—

PETITION.PARA: The petition of the undersigned show that:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submit that as the current debate proceeds on the Family Law Reform Bill, that the role of the grandparents be included in discussion, with particular emphasis on the needs of the children affected by divorce (including defacto partnerships).

We submit that the grandparents, in the majority of cases, can be the one "constant" element for the children, to help maintain their stability and peace of mind, with someone who is part of the extended family and whose main concern is their wellbeing.
Your petitioners therefore request that:

PETITION.PARA: The Federal Government amends the Family Law Reform Bill to ensure that the role of grandparents be included in any considerations of the needs of the children affected by divorce (including defacto relationships).

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Guide
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.We are opposed to the sex guide endorsed by Ms Lawrence, Minister for Health in the Keating Government, and published in the December issue of Cleo.
2.We believe that the sex guide encourages dangerous sexual practices which could have serious medical and moral effects.

PARA.TAB: We call on Ms Lawrence to withdraw her endorsement of this sex guide and for the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, to indicate his disapproval.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sydney Olympics 2000
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia:

PARA.TAB: Urges the Federal Government to bring down legislation that all merchandise bearing the Sydney Olympics 2000 insignia shall be made in Australia from material made in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Desertification
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We, the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the proposed signing of the UN Convention on Desertification has the potential to adversely affect the rights of farmers to manage their farms, and of local authorities to govern their shires as well as infringing the constitutional responsibility of the states on land management issues.
We therefore request that the treaty not be signed without first receiving the scrutiny and approval of the Senate and subject to such reservations as the Senate might recommend.
As your petitioners in duty bound shall ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia asks that the Childcare Rebate Act 1993 and the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Act 1993 be amended with the application of common principles. To ensure that all parents with dependent children are treated equally, allowing maximum freedom of choice in child rearing.
These Acts need to be amended to take account of:

PETITION.PARA: 1.the fact that 60% of married women in the workforce who have children, would prefer to stay at home and mind their children, but for economic reasons can't afford to (Institute of Family Studies Survey).
2.the failure to provide for equitable choice for women and families in allowing parents the maximum right to choose the most appropriate form of care for their children.
3.that there be recognition of a parent at home as a formal occupation reflecting its economic value and worth to society.
4.the need for equal payment of any subsidies and allowances for the care of children, paid directly to the parent.
5.the recognition that a family with more than one child incurs extra expenses.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners request that the Senate amend the Childcare Rebate Act 1993 and the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Act 1993.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Guide
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned citizens condemn the Minister for Health, the Hon. Carmen Lawrence MP and the federal Labor Government for spending a quarter of a million dollars on the Cleo magazine supplement featuring a section entitled the Agony and the Ecstacy, that promotes anal sex as a normal and safe activity, under the guise of sex education.

We call on the Federal Government to address the real needs of young Australians by providing resources for health education programs that do not glorify potentially dangerous sexual practices, but promote sound medical advice and support in areas of HIV AIDS and sexually transmitted diseases and youth suicide.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances I give notice that, 15 sitting days after today, I shall move that the following delegated legislation be disallowed:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Customs Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1994 No 435 and made under the Customs Act 1901
2.Income Tax Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1994 No 461 and made under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936
3.AUSTUDY Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1994 No 409 and made under the Student Assistance Act 1973
4.Remuneration Tribunal Determinations Nos 30 and 33 of 1994, made under the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973
5.Civil Aviation Orders, Part 105 AD/F27/103 Amdt 6, made under the Civil Aviation Act 1988
6.Civil Aviation Orders, Section 40.1.0, made under the Civil Aviation Act 1988
7.Rules of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1994 No 464 and made under the Industrial Relations Act 1988
8.Statistics Determination (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1994 No 465 and made under the Census and Statistics Act 1905
I seek leave to make a short statement about the committee's concerns with this legislation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee's concerns with these instruments include discretions with no indication whether subject to review, prejudicial retrospectivity, uncertain provisions, possible invalidity and possible breach of personal rights. As usual, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short summary of the matters raised by the Committee.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Customs Regulations (Amendment) Statutory Rules 1994 No 435
The Regulations amend the Principal Regulations as a result of amendments to Australia's anti-dumping and countervailing regimes.

Some of the amendments confer wide discretions on the Minister. Subregulations 180(6) and (7) and 181(4) and (6) provide that, if the Minister is satisfied that there is insufficient information to enable certain costs or profits to be calculated, then the Minister may determine an amount having regard to all relevant information, and may disregard any information that he or she considers to be unreliable. The Committee has written to the Minister seeking confirmation that the exercise of these significant discretions, as well as the others in the Regulations, is subject to independent review.
Income Tax Regulations (Amendment) Statutory Rules 1994 No 461
The Regulations provide rules for the calculation of transitional Reasonable Benefit Levels.

These amendments confer significant discretions on the Commissioner. Proposed regulation 51 provides that the Commissioner may determine Reasonable Benefit Limits at a rate higher than the Regulations provide in special circumstances. Also, the Commissioner may permit registration of a transitional RBL at a date later than the specified cut-off-date. Each of these decisions might have significant financial consequences. The Committee has written to the Minister seeking confirmation that the exercise of these discretions is subject to independent review.
AUSTUDY Regulations (Amendment) Statutory Rules 1994 No 409

Among other things, the Regulations make changes to income calculations and rent assistance, abolish the Student Assistance Review Tribunal and transfer its functions to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and make changes to fit in with the Sex Discrimination Act 1984.

Amending regulation 36.2 adds subregulations (4)-(6) to regulation 108. These amendments confer important discretions on the Secretary to suspend and recommence the payment of benefits. The subregulations also omit the Note to regulation 108, which advised of a right of appeal to the Student Assistance Review Tribunal. Elsewhere, the Regulations confer the review functions of the Student Assistance Review Tribunal on the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. The Committee has written to the Minister seeking confirmation that regulation 108 decisions by the Secretary will be reviewable by the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. The Committee has also asked for advice on some minor drafting errors.
Remuneration Tribunal Determinations Nos 30 and 33 of 1994, made under the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973
These Determinations make variations to the recreation leave entitlements of certain office holders.

Determination No 30, which varies Determination No 20 of 1991, appears to have taken effect retrospectively from 10 December 1991. Determination No 33 then repeals Determination No 20 of 1991 with effect from 19 December 1994. The Committee has written to the Minister seeking confirmation that the retrospective operation of Determination No 30 can prejudicially affect no-one other than the Commonwealth.
Civil Aviation Orders Part 105 AD/F27/103 Amdt 6, made under the Civil Aviation Act 1988

This instrument amends the Schedule of Airworthiness Directives for Fokker F27 Series Aeroplanes by incorporating modifications specified in the Fokker Structural Integrity Program and Subsequent Temporary Revisions.

Given the Committee's previously expressed view of the operation of s.49A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, that a regulation may incorporate matter contained in a non-statutory instrument only as that instrument is in force at the time the regulation takes effect, this would seem to prevent the incorporation of "subsequent Temporary Revisions" in the Directive. However, the Committee understands that s.98(3A) of the Civil Aviation Act 1988 enables regulations made under that Act to incorporate other written instruments as in force not only at the time the regulation takes effect, but as in force from time to time. The Committee has written to the Minister seeking advice as to the effect of s.49A on instruments such as Airworthiness Directives, which are not strictly regulations, but are made by virtue of regulations.
Civil Aviation Orders, Section 40.1.0, made under the Civil Aviation Act 1988
This instrument makes a number of amendments to the Section in relation to aircraft endorsements.

In a number of cases these amendments confer discretions on the Authority. For example, an amendment to subparagraph 6.1(c) proposes to replace the objective phrase "overseas aeroplane type endorsement that" with the subjective phrase "overseas aeroplane endorsement that the Authority is satisfied". These discretions may be of considerable commercial value. The Committee has written to the Minister seeking confirmation that their exercise will be subject to some form of independent review.
Rules of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (Amendment) Statutory Rules 1994 No 464

Among other things, the Rules make amendments relating to certification of agreements, approvals of enterprise flexibility agreements and appeals under the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act 1991.

New paragraphs 30A(3)(cc) and 30G(3)(fb) provide that an application for certification must, among other things, state the number of employees covered by the agreement who are included in each of seven classes of person. Also, paragraphs 30A(3)(d) and (e), and paragraphs 30G(3)(g) and (h), require the specification of employees, other than those included in the seven classes, who may be relevant employees under the Act.

Under s.170MG of the Industrial Relations Act 1988 the Commission is required to identify employees whose interests may not have been sufficiently taken into account in the terms of a certified agreement. This section refers only to employees in three specified categories.

The Committee has written to the Minister seeking advice on the legality and appropriateness of the Commission going beyond the three statutory categories, and on the lack of certainty involved in requiring the identification of other employees whose interests may not have been taken into account.
Statistics Determination (Amendment) Statutory Rules 1994 No 465
The Regulations authorise the Commonwealth Statistician to disclose certain types of information in particular circumstances.

Some of the information released under these provisions might be sensitive. Its disclosure seems to be a matter where the Privacy Commissioner should be consulted as a matter of course. However, the Explanatory Statement makes no reference to any such discussions. The Committee has written to the Minister seeking confirmation that such consultations have occurred.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I thank the Senate for granting me leave to talk about this matter. It is my intention to speak to the opposition, the Australian Democrats, the Greens and Senator Harradine about what would be suitable programming in terms of which nights we negate the adjournment before the conclusion of these sittings. There will be a need on a significant number of the remaining evenings for us to sit later than the usual time that the adjournment is moved at 7.20 p.m.

PARA.TAB: It is my intention to talk to senators about their availability to ensure that we deal with the program but it is my intention to try to be as flexible as I can. Senators would be aware that we have fallen behind in our program of business for these particular sittings. As senators may wish to plan ahead, I indicate it is not my intention to propose a negation in any sense on the Wednesday nights—unless that would suit senators around the chamber—because traditionally that has not been the case.

I wanted to indicate to senators that I will talk to the various parties and to the independents about their availability. Over the last few weeks I have flagged with everyone the necessity for us doing this on a number of occasions over the next sitting fortnight. Tomorrow it would be my intention to give notice of the government's intentions in respect of negation of the adjournment to give all senators maximum notice of the possible implications for their own diaries.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I understand the concerns of the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Faulkner), but it would be helpful if he could indicate what he regards as necessary in terms of the number of hours. He is obviously flagging that he wants us to consider what evenings we might be prepared to forgo, but in order to make any sensible judgment on that we need to know what quantum of hours is involved. I would hope he might at least be able to put some sort of indicative figure on that, and then indicate whether he is proposing that we spread that out over whatever period of time it might be but not beyond 10.30 or whether he is proposing that we try to knock it all off in one hit beyond 10.30 p.m.

—by leave—Why does the government consistently leave this to the last minute in each sitting period? Why can't it get its program in reasonable order so that bills can be dealt with during the course of the sittings rather than constantly building up to this backlog at the end of the sitting? The consequence of that, whether we sit late or not, is that bills are not dealt with in the way this chamber would like to handle legislation; that is, to do it properly. This is the house of review, the house of scrutiny of legislation in the Australian parliament, and we should be given reasonable time to do our job properly.

PARA.TAB: The government changed the procedures to three sittings each year and said that bills would now be introduced in a way that they might be dealt with orderly and that such time would be allowed. But in each instance since giving that undertaking to the Senate we have still ended up with a backlog at the end of the sittings with a consequential loss of our capacity to properly scrutinise the legislative program. With proper management on the part of government, that should be unneces sary.

We will cooperate. We are sitting this morning, which is an additional period of time. We did that without complaint because there was a good reason for having lost time in the last sitting week. But why is the government telling us at the beginning of the last sitting fortnight that it is now going to need extra time?

In actual fact, as Senator Reid knows, we had to press the government at the end of the last sitting week for a list of the bills that it wanted to deal with in this sitting and for an estimate of how long the government thought it would take. Why is it our job to press the government for its program? Why can't it get its affairs in order? It is in charge of programming in this place. Senator Faulkner has had a lot on his mind in this particular sitting in relation to his own portfolio and the difficulties that he has got himself into in that regard. We understand that he has been distracted from his role as manager of government business. But if he feels he is not up to the job then there are plenty of others who would like to have a go at it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I'll bet there's not!

—The record of managers of government business on your side, Senator Faulkner, has not been a happy one. It has not been a success story. Nevertheless, that is not an excuse for not attempting to get it right. For you to come in here on the first day of the last sitting fortnight and suddenly reveal to the Senate that further time is going to be necessary and that you want to start the process of negotiation is just leaving it all too late. It is not sensible and orderly management, and that is all we constantly seek of you. Over the years you have been in government we have simply not been able to achieve that objective. We regret that.

PARA.TAB: We will cooperate, but we will also remain true to our responsibility to perform the job of scrutiny properly and to take the time that is necessary to do it properly. If there is not time in this sitting to do it properly, then our attitude is that unless the bill is of utmost urgency it should be put over until the next sitting, which is only a couple of months away in any event. That is the way we will approach the detail that apparently you are going to bring to our attention some time in the near future.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I appreciate the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) taking the Senate into his confidence and giving us some warning about the matter. I would also say to him that, as I see it, there are 18 pieces of legislation to be determined between now and the time we get up. The second reading debate has already finished on at least a half a dozen of those pieces of legislation. Most of the legislation is now at the committee stage. I imagine there will be one other—and that will be the Land Fund Bill—that is not listed here for consideration and presumably those for which you have sought exemption from Senator Chamarette's cut-off motion of November last year.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the manager of government business, when discussing the matters with us, should canvass whether or not those particular pieces of legislation are urgent. I agree with what Senator Hill said. Those that are not urgent should be put over to the next session and we can then deal with them at that particular stage. I feel that the extra time should be sought on the basis of what are the urgent pieces of legislation and what are the times that the government considers need to be devoted to those particular pieces of legislation. I emphasise to the minister through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that he should now set down what are the urgent pieces of legislation and what are the times that the government considers those pieces of legislation deserve for debate in the second reading stage, in the committee stage and so on. Then he should let us have a good talk about that.

As to the particular times that we might have to extend to, my preference is to have an additional day rather than going late at night and into the wee hours of the morning. I have been here long enough to have seen the effect that that has on people. I know Senator Herron has done a medical report on that particular question, as I think the manager of government business knows full well. I am sure that he is not terribly anxious to extend the sittings of the parliament into the evening. I think those three matters that I mentioned ought to be considered: what are the urgent bills; how long does the government propose that we spend on those bills for the second reading stage and for the committee stage to conclude the passage or otherwise of the legislation, and; finally, is there any other way that we can deal with extra hours that are thus required other than sitting until quite late?

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—There are no surprises in anything that I said earlier on. I merely said those words as a courtesy to the Senate. I have spoken to Senator Hill privately on no less than three occasions, and all other senators, about my intention over this last sitting fortnight. I think everyone is aware of the constraints that we face in terms of the significant amount of legislation that still needs to be dealt with in this last fortnight of sittings.

PARA.TAB: I take account of the point that Senator Alston made. It is very difficult to predict what will occur in terms of some parts of the Senate's routine of business. I do not think it is possible for any government, or really any senator in this chamber, to rub a crystal ball and predict what is going to occur. We had matters such as urgency motions and MPIs and the like in the last sitting period. We had a situation where the sitting of the Senate was suspended for a day as a result of the death of Senator Zakharov. It is not easy to be able to make assessments about these things early in the sittings. At this stage, of course, we have had 60 per cent of the sitting time and dealt with about 30 per cent of the legislation.

What I want to do in response to Senator Harradine's question—he and other senators have the value of the forward legislative program for these two weeks of sittings—is to talk these issues through in terms of senators' availability for evening sittings. It is not my intention to have extra sitting days, unless that were absolutely necessary. I believe that, if we approach the task with some determination, we can actually see the program achieved with perhaps three or four moderate negations.

It has never been my practice nor is it now my intention to see the Senate sit late into the night. I think even every single member of the opposition would have to say that that is the case. We have managed to achieve what we have achieved in terms of our sitting program during this parliament without a string of late night sittings. I would be proposing three or four moderate negations to allow us to complete our program. That is what I have in mind. I will be asking the parliamentary liaison officer, and I will involve myself in discussions with senators, to ensure that we—

TALK.START.PARA: —Including tonight.
—There is no proposal to sit late—
—If you take out Wednesday, you've only got this Thursday, the following Tuesday and the following Thursday. So that is three maximum.
—I want to talk to senators about their availability on four sitting nights next week.

PARA.TAB: Senator Alston interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I appreciate that: three sitting nights this week, unless it was the strong view of senators to sit until, say, 10.30 tonight. It would not be my intention to do so, but I would be happy to establish that early in the day and not sit on Wednesday nights, unless there is a view of senators that that would be a suitable way for us to proceed. So I merely flag that with senators and indicate what my intention is in terms of approaching this, which I hope senators find useful in terms of their capacity to plan for these particular matters. As I say, I will follow it through with discussions prior to the giving of notices tomorrow morning, so all senators have a capacity to plan in advance in this sitting fortnight.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Murphy) agreed to:
That the following matter be referred to the Committee of Privileges:
Whether false or misleading statements were made to the Select Committee on Public Interest Whistleblowing, and, if so, whether any contempt was committed in relation to these statements.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that general business notice of motion No. 1392, standing in my name but as amended by the amendments that have been circulated in the chamber today, be taken as formal.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Is leave granted to amend the motion?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just been informed—
—I am seeking formality of the motion as amended.
—First I have to ask whether there is leave to amend the motion. Having done that, I will ask if there are any objections. Is leave granted to amend the motion?

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there any objection to the motion as amended being taken as formal?
—Yes.
—There is objection to the motion being taken as formal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Chamarette moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 1392 standing in her name for this day, relating to the consideration of the Racial Hatred Bill 1994.

SPEECH.PARA: I will speak only briefly on this matter. I do not intend to delay the Senate but I believe this is a matter of urgency. I will not be debating the content of this notice, but merely the need for urgency; the need to pass this motion today. I gave notice originally on 6 March as follows:

PARA.TAB: That further consideration of the Government Business order of the day relating to the Racial Hatred Bill 1994 be postponed to the day of sitting immediately after the release of the findings of the committee established by the Attorney-General to review the ability of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to make determinations following the decision of the High Court in Brandy v. Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason for giving that notice—and it was requested that it be considered as a formal motion—was the obvious concern that the operations of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission have been affected by that determination in the High Court. It seemed obvious to me that, because the Racial Hatred Bill is so dependent on the operation and constitutionality of the operation of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, it was appropriate that that question of its constitutionality be resolved prior to debate on the Racial Hatred Bill 1994.

PARA.TAB: It was pointed out to me that if the Attorney-General's committee was to do a thorough job it might take a considerable time and this might constitute an unreasonable delay, especially in light of the fact that the Attorney-General's Department has been working on some amendments to restore the constitutionality of the operation of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. That is why the amendments merely add, `or the day of sitting after the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986 has been amended by the parliament to ensure its constitutionality in the light of the decision of the High Court in Brandy v. Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, whichever is the sooner.'

On the Notice Paper for today both those bills appear in sequence with the first being the Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 and the resumption of the second reading debate. I believe the government is putting amendments that would, in its view, restore the constitutionality of operation of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. However, we have not been through that consideration and those amendments have not been supported in the Senate. Neither, as yet, have we heard any assurance about the reception they might get in the House of Representatives. For that reason it is urgent to put this motion that we successfully deal with the first matter which I believe will affect the consideration of the second matter, the Racial Hatred Bill.

The fact that the Racial Hatred Bill comes immediately after the Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill, in my view, does not necessarily deal with the concerns because there may be a delay or a deferment of that first matter in which case we would move to the second. Because that is inappropriate, I wish to move urgent consideration of the motion that we delay considering the Racial Hatred Bill until after the successful completion of consideration of the Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill. The motion is self-explanatory. I trust that my colleagues will see the logic of it and accept that this is a sensible motion in relation to having logical and sequential debate in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition does not support this motion being made formal, albeit it is very much in support of the principle behind the motion and is in support of the spirit of what the Greens are trying to do. What they are basically saying is that we should not be asked to deal with the Racial Hatred Bill 1994 until these matters have been resolved one way or the other. We need the release of the findings of the committee established by the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) or to have the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act amended in such a way as to fix the errors isolated by the Brandy decision.

PARA.TAB: Rather than support this motion and lock us into following its exact wording, we would prefer to maintain a degree of good faith with the government. When the human rights legislation comes on for debate, we will say that it is fine for the government to introduce its amendments but after that we want the matter postponed. We want it postponed because it should go through the proper processes. It is one thing to deliver some amendments and have some officers of the department and officers from the minister's office say, `These amendments are all okay,' but it is another for an opposition to say, `Yes that's all right. Parliament will sit and just rubber-stamp this little private conversation that we had and that I had with some officers this morning.' I was offered a telephone brief on Friday I think on these amendments. That is clearly not the way parliament should work.

The amendments are in response to a decision of the High Court. Parliament is not only entitled but also obligated to go through the amendments and ensure that they are what they purport to be, which is a simple turning back to the pre-1992 position. I spoke to the officers this morning and asked, `Is that all there is?' One said, `It is just going back to 1992.' I asked a simple question: what about the delegation powers? I was told that there were a few minor extra things. They might be right in that the extra things, the changes, over and above shifting back to 1992 might be minor. Senator Chamarette, Senator Harradine and I might agree with them. We all might agree with them. All we are saying is that parliament is entitled to look at them first and give them proper assessment. For my part, I want to take them to my shadow ministry and then to my party room. I want to give everybody who is elected, paid as a member of parliament and obligated to look at these things properly the opportunity to consider what is in these amendments.

There should be no difficulty in dealing with that course. If, as the government says, the amendments it wants to move to that bill are relatively minor in that they either simply put it back to the 1992 position or make some very minor inconsequential amendments, there will be no problem. They will go to my shadow ministry on Monday, be dealt with on Tuesday and could be debated here Tuesday afternoon. I do not think that is a lot to ask for amendments that were delivered to me on Friday. In fact, it is improper of a government to ask for them to be dealt with any sooner.

Then it would be sensible immediately after the human rights legislation to deal with the Racial Hatred Bill. We assume that the government in good faith—we will take it on good faith at the moment—wants this matter to be fixed. It clearly sees by the listing it has put on the order of business that it is sensible to deal with the Racial Hatred Bill after the human rights legislation has been dealt with in this chamber. On that basis, we would look to having the human rights amendments shifted until next week so that they can go through the proper processes.

We agree with the government's scheduling and ordering that the Racial Hatred Bill should come after that. On that point, I think Senator Chamarette is in agreement. What she is concerned with is that it will try to proceed in any event if there is a problem with the human rights amendments. We are saying, `Why don't we wait and see? Why don't we assume good faith? Assume that the government is simply wanting to put it back to the pre-1992 position. Assume good faith on the part of the officers I spoke to this morning who said that the other amendments are minor and inconsequential.' If all that is the case, there should be no problem in proceeding with this next week. I say to Senator Chamarette that, if we find that the government does not want to play ball and be sensible, we might have to look at dealing with this in another way on another day. Just for today, we are happy to say that we will put some good faith in the government and see whether it is prepared to deliver.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the comments of Senator Vanstone. It was only recently that the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee looked into the Racial Hatred Bill and, in the course of that inquiry, took evidence from the Attorney-General's Department. Extensive evidence was given as to the ramifications of the case of Brandy v. Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. The ramifications are such that the determinations of such commissions do not have any sanction attached to them and that there are great problems in relation to the enforceability of those civil sections of the Racial Hatred Bill.

PARA.TAB: It became apparent during the taking of that evidence that this was indeed a complex area. This bill that has been put to us at the last minute has not provided us with any opportunity to closely scrutinise it, which is required of any responsible house of review as, after all, this Senate is. It particularly does not afford the opposition the democratic chance to inquire into this legislation.

There is no urgency as such for the Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill to be dealt with today. No grand social damage will be caused by not dealing with it today. I support Senator Vanstone entirely when she says that this matter could easily be put off until next week. We would then have an opportunity to scrutinise this bill and ensure that it will do what it says it will do. After all, our role is not to simply accept proposed legislation on the face of it; our responsibility is to make legitimate inquiry and be afforded ample opportunity for scrutiny.

That does not mean to say that you hold up the business of governing this country unnecessarily—quite the contrary—but there is no need for this bill to be foisted upon us. The first notice we had of it was last Friday and here we are on Tuesday expected to debate the bill. It is entirely inappropriate that that be done. The sensible course is to put this all off until next week. Then we can have a look at it and, all being well, move onto the Racial Hatred Bill.

There is no attempt to delay that. There has been due inquiry into it by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, but there has not been due inquiry into this Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill, and that is what needs to be looked at. There is no question of suspicion or cynicism on our part. As Senator Vanstone says, we are taking this on the assumption that the government will be returning to the pre-1992 position. We just need one week, nothing more and nothing less, to have a look at it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the compromise as suggested by the shadow Attorney-General, Senator Vanstone, and also the comments of my colleague Senator Ellison. Senator Vanstone's proposal is a sensible compromise in all the circumstances, and I commend it to the Senate. All it does is defer the consideration of the Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill and the Racial Hatred Bill for a period of seven days.

PARA.TAB: This government has had some considerable time to develop a racial hatred bill. In fact, it had one before the last election, withdrew it and reconsidered it. Although it is on the agenda of this country, it cannot be argued that it is of absolute vital importance it be dealt with today as opposed to next week. I do not think there is an argument for urgency. Nevertheless, there is an argument to ensure that it gets dealt with in due course. I would have thought a period of seven days would fit into that category.

This house is supposedly a house of review. It is vital in the discharge of that function for us to look at the legislation, consider it and, if appropriate, seek some independent legal advice apart from that which comes from the Attorney-General's Department.

In my brief period in this place, on a number of occasions I have seen the Attorney-General's Department give legal advice and considered opinions to Senate committees. While clearly given in good faith, at the end of the day they were overruled by the High Court of Australia. Therefore, it is appropriate for an opposition to seek advice from outside the Attorney-General's Department and, indeed, to rely on the legal brains within the ranks of the opposition—people such as the shadow Attorney-General, Senator Ellison, Daryl Williams QC in the other place, and other people.

But for that to occur, we need more than just the Friday, when we were given notice of this bill, an intervening long weekend, and the Senate resuming today. I believe that it is appropriate, as suggested by the shadow Attorney-General, that we accept the government at face value but ask that we be given appropriate time to consider the proposed amendments to ensure that we on this side of the chamber are satisfied as to the propriety of the amendments, the legality of the amendments and their implications.

We could not face the people of Australia if we said that we just took the government at face value without looking into this in any way, shape or form ourselves. We need to satisfy ourselves that the proposals are appropriate and I would anticipate, without having gone into it at any great depth at this stage, that that would be our finding. Nevertheless, we have to give it due consideration. I believe that the delay of one week, as proposed by Senator Vanstone, is appropriate and I commend that course to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem that we are faced with here is that, unless we have it clear as to how the human rights and equal opportunity legislation will be amended, we are buying a pig in a poke. That is the problem I have. I have not seen the proposed amendments so I am flying well and truly in the dark.

PARA.TAB: The whole ball game has changed since the High Court case of Brandy v. Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. On 17 February, I was at the hearing on the Racial Hatred Bill conducted by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee chaired by Senator Barney Cooney. At that particular meeting on that particular day, which was before the decision in the High Court, the question was raised as to whether we should delay this matter until after we had heard what the High Court said. The Attorney-General's Department was quite confident that the High Court would rule in its favour. Have a look at the Hansard on that day if you do not believe me.

In the event, there was a judgment of seven to nil against the Attorney-General's Department. I will be dealing with the Attorney-General's Department's opinion on a few other things later—not least being the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1995—because it was wrong on that occasion and it is wrong on this occasion. It went down seven to nil in the High Court.

We are now being asked to proceed with consideration of the human rights and equal opportunity legislation prior to having a particular grasp of what the amendments will be or what implications they will have. I actually support what Senator Chamarette is trying to do, which is to delay the consideration until we have the findings of the committee established by the Attorney-General to review the ability of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to make determinations following the decision of the High Court.

In general terms, I actually support the Racial Hatred Bill but I am not prepared—I mean that quite literally—to debate that legislation when the effectiveness or otherwise of its provisions depend on what will be the amendments to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission legislation. I hope the Senate understands where I have come from in that particular regard.

I think it is only reasonable that this proposal be explored. I am not too sure where the opposition is going. I can understand what Senator Vanstone has said, but she is leaving it up to the government to do the decent thing. Frankly, as I said the other day for the first time in my many years in this place, I do not think this government is doing the decent thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had some soft statements this morning, but this is all about one thing. When we look at the history and the background here, this is really about deferring the Racial Hatred Bill until after this week. It is all about opposition members protecting their mates in New South Wales—the decaying government in New South Wales. They are not prepared to face the music on the racial hatred issue this week because they know the enormous backlash it would cause in the New South Wales electoral context. That is what this is about. That is why those opposite are part of this procedural sting to ensure that they do not face the music on this legislation this week.

PARA.TAB: In coming in here those opposite have made all sorts of mealy-mouthed statements asking the government to do this, that and the other. Senator Ellison raised the issue of the analysis of the legislation in the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee chaired by Senator Cooney, but he failed to mention—and it is an important failure to mention—that that committee, in recommendation No. 1.57, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee does not consider it necessary to make any amendments to the Racial Hatred Bill to accommodate the High Court's judgment in Brandy v Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission . . .

What we are on about this morning is a two- or three-step approach to avoid discussing racial hatred. That is going to happen as we go through the court case this morning. It is all because those opposite do not want to face the issue this week. It is not the way to approach policy formulation. One of the broader problems those opposite have—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you have your amendments ready last week?

—Senator Vanstone is the last one to laugh. If anyone has no credibility in the community in relation to policy formulation, it is Senator Vanstone. Having promised legislation and consultation, she comes out with something out of a brown paper envelope and then shows it the light of day with some limited representation from the ethnic communities.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I take the minister's remark personally as a reflection on me.
—Of course it is.

—If I may put my point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President, the suggestion that the bill I produced came out of a brown paper bag is a clear implication by the minister that I have produced a bill under someone else's instructions, possibly for money. In common usage, the meaning of the term `out of a brown paper bag' is `Go around and do what people paying you money say.' If the minister does not want to take the good faith that is offered on this side—if he wants to misunderstand the nature of this debate and say that he can come in here with amendments that no one saw before last Friday and that parliament should then debate the matter—let him say so, but do not let him abuse me at the same time. Do not let him attribute to me bad faith that is not there.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—I am not sure that it is unparliamentary. I do not have great experience with brown paper bags.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I can help you, Mr Acting Deputy President, I was not saying the comment was unparliamentary; I was saying it was a clear reflection on me.
—It would be unparliamentary if it was a reflection on you.
—It is offensive.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order, the relevant standing order, No. 193, clearly says that it is highly disorderly, as the minister well knows, to make personal reflections. We might debate whether it is a personal reflection, but we do not really have to because the minister actually conceded that it was a personal reflection when Senator Vanstone said that she considered that it might be a personal reflection. I do not think it requires a great deal of judgment from you, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—A plea of guilty.
—The minister has quite clearly pleaded guilty to it and it is quite clearly a breach of standing order 193(3). I urge you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to order that way.
—I am not sure it is, but I will listen to the point of order.

—I also wish to raise a point of order. In response to Senator Vanstone, I said that I had made a reflection on her handling of this issue, and that is something that we do of each other in this place all the time. It does not go to her personality. Senator Vanstone, `out of a brown paper bag' can relate to pornography and can relate to unacceptable documentation. It does not relate just to money and brown paper bags. Senator Vanstone, in trying to distinguish it from a personal reflection on you, the point I was making was that your alternative legislation on this—
—Are you on the point of order?
—I am on the point of order.
—Then speak to the Acting Deputy President and not to me.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, the point I was making is that the performance of the shadow Attorney-General on this matter was such that she was tawdry not only in her process but in the product that has come out of that process.
—Time.

—No, I am on a point of order, Senator Short, and I want to speak to it. The product is also unacceptable, and that is not just my judgment. It is the judgment of the Ethnic Communities Council of Australia and many people in this community that you have cynically manipulated the ethnic communities. This morning you have taken up my time in this debate, and that is also part of that manipulation.
—You are wandering a bit, minister.

—The points of order raised by opposition senators in my five minutes have had no other effect—and a deliberate effect at that—than to stop me from speaking on this point. That is the way opposition senators want to play this. They are wasting the time of the Senate, and they ought to be pulled up for it rather than me.

—On the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President, I put it to you that `out of a brown paper bag' has a widely understood political meaning; that is, that somebody is being secretly paid or given some financial advantage to assume a political position. I cannot think of much that could be said in relation to any senator in this place that could be more offensive than that.

PARA.TAB: The minister got up and said, `No, it may have some other meaning to do with pornography.' What is he talking about? Nobody has any idea. The community would believe that the reference Senator Bolkus made—and, clearly, I suspect it is what he intended—was that Senator Vanstone was being bought off. Nothing could be more offensive and nothing could reflect on her more adversely than that. I would have thought that that was clear. The meaning is well understood in the community, and Senator Bolkus should be required to withdraw it.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order, I think Hansard will show that the minister said a `brown paper envelope'. I do not know whether that helps the Senate.
—I am unconvinced that there was a personal reflection intended, but perhaps the minister could withdraw the reference so that we can get on with the business of the Senate.
—I do so.

—by leave—Mr Acting Deputy President, I do not want to waste time, but I am concerned by your ruling. I ask that you refer this matter either to the procedure committee for further consideration or to the President so that he can come in here with a considered opinion on it. Certainly, for those of us on this side of the chamber, it is clearly unparliamentary because it is a reflection on a senator's character. It has been withdrawn and, therefore, the matter is at an end, but I am concerned about the precedent of the ruling. Mr Acting Deputy President, I wonder whether further consideration might be given to it. Perhaps it might be better to refer it to the President rather than the procedure committee at this stage.
—I shall certainly refer it to the President.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the negative.
Debate resumed from 9 March, on motion by Senator Woodley:

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Economics References Committee for inquiry and report on or before 11 May 1995:
(1)The proposed Eastlink high voltage powerline between Armidale, New South Wales, and Springdale, Queensland, with particular reference to:

TAB.TAB: (i)the possible impact of the powerline and the accompanying land resumptions on:
(A)the health of people and animals in surrounding areas, with particular reference to the likely effects of electromagnetic field radiation,
(B)the vegetation and overall environment, and
(C)the social fabric and local economic viability of surrounding communities, including the likely loss of agricultural land;
(ii)the overall economic impact of the powerline;
(iii)the likely impact of the powerline on overall levels of electricity consumption, with reference to Australia's obligations and commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emissions;
(iv)the viability of renewable energy sources to provide electricity to Queensland consumers, instead of expanding the consumption of coal generated electricity; and
(v)the adequacy of the community consultation process undertaken by Government bodies with those people and local authorities in the areas which will be affected by the powerline.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (2)That the committee, in the context of the Eastlink powerline, review relevant Federal and State Government reports on electricity supply, including the 1992 report of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology into gas and electricity, to assess whether issues raised in these reports have been adequately addressed in the Eastlink proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying when this motion was last before the Senate, this is certainly an issue for which there is a desperate need for more information. Mr Acting Deputy President, you might recall that back in 1992 the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology recommended that Queensland not be included in the initial assessment of the possible national electricity grid extensions until it could be demonstrated that its inclusion could be achieved economically. The government response to that recommendation of the committee was as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Not supported.

The main concern of the Committee over the Northlink proposal derives from the view that transmission losses could erode the environmental benefits of the sharing of spinning reserve, with consequent fuel savings. The economic benefits of new links are addressed in response to Recommendation 6. However, such grid augmentations or extensions should only proceed where they can be demonstrated to be economic.

A major part of the assessment work being carried out by the States is to determine the economic merits of various proposals. At the present time Queensland is considering the construction of new generating capacity to meet the State's projected electricity needs from the end of the decade and beyond. The Commonwealth considers that this evaluation should also consider the merits of Northlink, which would enable the construction of expensive new capacity in Queensland to be delayed. The link would enable some of Queensland's power needs to be met by New South Wales which has considerable excess capacity.

That was how this matter was first raised. There is no doubt that many people in my state of Queensland have a very great concern. I know my colleague Senator Boswell and my other Senate colleagues Senator MacGibbon, Senator Herron, Senator Parer and Senator O'Chee, and I believe all of my Labor Senate colleagues as well, have received a great many letters and a great many representations from people about this issue. There are a myriad of those. I will quote some words from a submission that a person made to the Senate standing committee considering the Eastlink proposal. The excerpts from that letter I refer to indicate some of the concerns being expressed. The letter indicated that the writer was concerned about, and I quote:

. . . injustices imposed upon a minority in the name of progress supported by the majority. Eastlink will also have severe environmental effects, both physical and aesthetic, and the decision-makers do not have to live with these effects every day of their lives as people in and near the path of the cables are expected to do.
The letter goes on:
The so-called consultation going on now is no more than a public relations exercise to try to placate opposition as the important decisions have already been made.
The letter continues:

The level of compensation spoken of is TOTALLY INADEQUATE. Farms and properties are being made inoperable by restrictions on land use in the vicinity of the cables which can only get worse if overseas experience is any guide. People's lives and futures are being destroyed. To many ageing farmers their farm is also their future retirement and reflects a lifetime of effort.
The letter further states:

If this project is to go ahead, and it should not for a host of reasons, TOTAL BUYOUT of all affected properties where owners want that, at prices that include a premium on PRE-EASTLINK and pre-drought prices, plus compensation for dislocation/relocation is the only way for fairness to apply. If this is not done, the minority bear the cost while the majority get the benefits.

Those are just some excerpts. Further, a number of petitions have been forwarded to all members of the Senate in which the point is made by petitioners that the proposal is contrary to the recommendations of the Senate standing committee to which I have referred. One of the petitions further indicates that Eastlink:
Is proceeding without proper comparison of other options for meeting Queensland's future energy needs.
The petition states:
There has been no proper comparison of impacts on rural productivity, economic, environment, health, development or lifestyle issues.
The petition further states:
Work on Eastlink easement acquisition occurred prior to parliamentary or public debate on the options for Queensland.
Finally, it states:
Eastlink itself will not be adequate for Interstate trading and would entail considerable further upgrading and expenditure on . . . Lines and switching station.
Those are just some of the concerns. I emphasise that we have all received many more of those types of concerns over time.

PARA.TAB: This matter was raised in the estimates committee hearings in February because it was of great concern to me and involved the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth seemed to have little understanding, knowledge or even interest in the proposal at all. My understanding of the Eastlink proposal is that it is to be a third funded by the Commonwealth government. If that is the case, one would have thought that the Commonwealth would be intricately involved in what is happening with Eastlink.

As a result of an enormous number of representations received from Queensland which indicate to my colleagues and I that work is about to commence, resumptions had begun and the procedure had gone to the point of no return, I tried to ask the Commonwealth government some questions about the matter at the Senate estimates committee hearings. When I asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins, about the Eastlink process at the estimates hearing on 15 February relating to the primary industries and energy portfolio, he said—and this is page 101 of the Hansard:

SPEECH.PARA: It will be quite a long process, as it always is with these transmission line proposals, to consult with all of the people.
Later on in that hearing I asked Senator Collins:
Can your department let me know what you have allocated towards the Eastlink project, what you have actually spent so far and where you have reached as far as your department is concerned?
In answer to that question Senator Collins said:
We will take that on the notice.
I then asked Senator Collins:

Is there just one line being looked at? It has been suggested to me that if you build one you then have to build a separate one in another position as a reserve, which I must confess I do not quite understand. Are you aware whether that is correct?
In answer to that question Senator Collins's said:
It is far too early to get into that detail.
I asked him later in the hearing:
So you believe that it is still in its very early stages?
Senator Collins responded by saying, `Yes'. Later on Senator Collins said:
All I can say is that in terms of the detail of actual routeing of the line, which is all important to those concerns, there is a long way to go yet.
I raise those issues to indicate that, as far as I am concerned, the information I am getting from my constituents is quite different to the information I am getting from the Commonwealth government.

PARA.TAB: Having pursued the matter quite unsatisfactory at the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee on 15 February, I then raised the matter with Senator Faulkner on 16 February at the environment estimates committee. I asked Senator Faulkner whether his department had been involved in any way in the path of the proposed major transmission lines. Senator Faulkner said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think the answer is no, but I will just seek some advice from the world heritage unit officer.
Dr Kay, the relevant officer, then came to the table and answered by saying:

Yes, we have had some involvement, as the Queensland electricity authorities have made public a number of proposed options and sought comment from us and from a whole series of other authorities on that. The proposed electricity transmission routes, or at least some of the proposed routes, have a proximity to the central eastern rainforests world heritage property. Our comment has really been in relation to that issue and that issue only. My understanding is that comments are still being sought on the report.
Later on in the hearing I asked whether those proposed routes traversed world heritage listed forests. Dr Kay said:

Yes, it includes several world heritage forests. The central eastern Australian rainforest is a single world heritage property. There are several compartments making up that single world heritage property. The range of routes have different impacts on different parts of the property. Some of the options, of course, are quite distant from the rainforests.

There was some understanding of the issue. Later on in the estimates committee hearing I asked some further questions. In answer to a question on where the actual routes went, Mr Carbon from the department said:
May I indicate that there is not a proposed route.
That is what a senior officer from the department said. Mr Carbon then went on to say:

The minister for the environment has yet to make a decision about how the Commonwealth will be involved in that. I understand that there is quite a bit of angst amongst the people out there, but the discussion is about choosing the preferred corridor stage for a proposal, rather that about a precise proposal at this stage.
In answer to a further question, Mr Carbon went on to say:

My understanding is that not only are routes being looked at but there are variations around those routes which are still being discussed, so there is not an exact proposal for even those particular three routes.
When I asked him whether he was aware of the ones that have been proposed, he said:
I do not know the details of them. I am aware that there are multiple routes being looked at.
Later on I asked Mr Carbon a further question:
At this stage do you have any part in the consultation process with people living in these proposed areas?

Mr Carbon replied, `None'. I have gone through the Hansard record of those Senate estimates hearings in some detail to indicate that there does not seem to be a lot of information on which senators could make a decision on this particular proposal. It is one that concerns me and my colleagues on this side of the chamber quite considerably.

PARA.TAB: The coalition feels that, whilst Senator Woodley's proposal should not be rejected at this stage, we are not in a position to fully understand the exact position of the Commonwealth. Our concern at not having the information comes from those extracts that I have read from Hansard. There seems to be some real misunderstanding in the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. There seems to be a bit of uncertainty in the department of the environment. Compared with what we have been told by our constituents, it just does not seem to make sense. It is important that, before we embark on a major reference to the Senate Economics References Committee, we should be sure of our facts.

As I said, the matter is proposed to be referred to the Senate Economics References Committee which is chaired very capably by my good friend and colleague Senator Ferguson. That committee already has two rather major references before it. Whilst I cannot speak for the committee and whilst I am sure that Senator Ferguson and his committee would cooperate and accommodate the Senate as best they could, there are obviously some concerns in getting that committee to look at it at an early date—although I am sure the committee would do whatever is necessary to accommodate the Senate.

At this stage of the debate—Senator Woodley having moved and spoken to this particular reference on behalf of the Democrats; Senator Faulkner having spoken on behalf of the government; and I having briefly indicated the coalition's position—I intend to move that the debate on this particular motion be adjourned to enable the Senate estimates committee to look further into this matter. I should just explain that statement.

When we raised this matter at the Senate estimates committee and there was that uncertainty, it was then agreed by the Senate estimates committee that perhaps the best way to go about it would be to get a full briefing from the department of the environment and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. We can then find out exactly what the Commonwealth's involvement is; where the Commonwealth has got to; what expenditure the Commonwealth has made; and what power the Commonwealth has in relation to the matter. Senators would then be fully informed of all those aspects. Once we have that information, we on the coalition side feel that we would be much better able to make a sensible assessment of Senator Woodley's motion.

Senators will be aware that the briefing for the estimates committee was set down for the day that the Senate adjourned as a mark of respect following the passing of one of our colleagues, and so the briefing could not go ahead at that time. I understand that it was to be done this week, but it has just been pointed out to me by the chairman of that committee that it cannot actually happen this week because the briefing is for members as well as senators. A number of members of the lower house have been inextricably involved in this. Two members that I know for certain would want to be included are Mr Bill Taylor, the Liberal member for Groom, whose electorate is traversed by the path, and Mr Bruce Scott, the National Party member for Maranoa, again whose electorate is traversed by it. If it is not done this week, it will no doubt take place next week.

My suggestion is that, the Democrats having spoken, the Labor Party having spoken and my having spoken on behalf of the coalition, we adjourn the debate to perhaps Wednesday of next week, depending on the Manager of Government Business, on the assumption that we might be able to have the briefing—I am not in a position to arrange this; committees have to make their own decisions—before the estimates committee on the Monday or Tuesday of next week.
Debate (on motion by Senator Boswell) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the resumption of the debate be made an order of the day for 29 March.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ian Macdonald has explained the position that the coalition finds itself in. I, too, have received numerous representations by mail and by phone from people, including state members of the various electorates that the powerlines are proposed to run through. All those people have supported Senator Woodley's motion for a Senate inquiry. We were proposing to do this last Tuesday but, as the previous speaker explained, the Senate, as a mark of respect, adjourned because of Senator Zakharov's untimely passing and that left us without the opportunity to have a briefing by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy.

PARA.TAB: If we are going to have a Senate inquiry I think it is up to the whole Senate to get full information so that Senator Woodley's terms of reference can be agreed to. Alternatively, some information may come up in the briefing by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy that may cause us to want to amend, with Senator Woodley's agreement, his motion. We may come up with some other problems that are unforeseen at the moment. We may want to go to Senator Woodley and say, `There are certain problems here that aren't included in your terms of reference.'

So, in the interest of getting the right result and getting full information, I think the right way to go is to seek that briefing by Wednesday next week and then, after having that briefing and having all the information that that briefing will allow us to get, to come back and put our position down. So I ask Senator Woodley, in the interest of getting the right information, whether he supports this motion for an adjournment—it will only take another week. I am sure that we can assist him in respect of his motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to Senator Boswell, I did oppose the adjournment, but I will now support the reopening of this matter next week.

—This proposed reference to the Economics References Committee is very important, and I do not think the opposition has been entirely honest in its reasons for seeking an adjournment. I think there is some rationalisation going on here—one has to bear in mind that there is an election coming up in New South Wales next Saturday—and that there are certain members on the opposition side who would prefer not to have this matter debated now but have it debated after the election. This is a very important matter; therefore, as Senator Woodley said, we will support the bringing on of this reference next week.

PARA.TAB: Its importance lies in the fact that the electricity industry throughout Australia, particularly along the eastern seaboard, is undergoing very considerable restructuring under the rubric of privatisation. Nowhere in that process of dividing up the electricity utilities into generators, distributors and suppliers—

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Senator Coulter, could I just draw your attention to the fact that you are speaking to a motion regarding the resumption of debate on this issue and not the substantive motion itself for the reference. I ask you to direct your remarks to that issue, not to the substantive issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am underscoring the importance of bringing this motion on next week. Very briefly, I am just making the claim that on the figures available it would be possible to achieve a much greater saving in electricity generation without the Eastlink powerline and with the move towards energy efficiency, which should be built into the system of privatisation. It is for that reason, and given the rapidity with which the move towards the privatisation and the splitting up of the utilities is proceeding, that it is important that this matter be brought on and debated through the committee system as quickly as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the order of the Senate of 29 November 1994, relating to the consideration of legislation, be amended as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Omit paragraph (1), substitute the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: `(1)For the reasons set out in this resolution, where a bill:
(a)is first introduced in the Senate by a minister in a period of sittings; or
(b)is received from the House of Representatives and was introduced in the House of Representatives in the same period of sittings,

and a motion is moved for the second reading of the bill, debate on that motion shall be adjourned at the conclusion of the speech of the Senator moving the motion and resumption of the debate shall be made an order of the day for the first day of sitting in the next period of sittings without any question being put.'.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand there is a strong level of support for this motion in the chamber. In fact, the government amendment to the Senate cut-off order of 29 November replaces the two government notices of motion which were given on 7 February 1995 and on 6 March 1995. The Senate order of 29 November last year sought to give effect to the objective of making bills available for public scrutiny and consultations as early as possible. It reflects the government undertaking that had been given by Senator Gareth Evans, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, on 18 August to work towards the objective of managing legislation on an introduce-one-session debate-the-next basis.

PARA.TAB: The application of the order as currently worded has prevented, as I have mentioned on many occasions in the chamber, debate in the current sittings of the Senate on bills which have been introduced or passed in the House of Representatives in previous sittings. Strict application of the order as it currently stands would mean that it would take at least three sittings for such a bill to pass through the parliament. The government amendment to the order seeks to allow debate in the Senate on such bills in order to ensure that the passage of bills will not be unduly delayed in the parliament.

It is a motion that is entirely consistent with the government's commitment to the objective of making bills available for examination and consultation as early as possible prior to debate in the Senate. The Senate order, if it is amended as proposed, will fully meet the objective of the principle of introducing a bill one session and debating it in the next session. The government will still need to seek exemption from the application of the order on a case-by-case basis, as senators are aware, for urgent bills and budget bills to be introduced and debated in the same sittings. This is a motion that will allow for good management of legislation in the Senate. It comprehensively allows us to meet and to manage the commitment that we made in relation to the introduction of legislation in one session and for debate in the next. I commend this important motion to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion, if carried, modifies the provision that is currently in place. Basically, the argument is put that if a bill has been introduced in the House of Representatives during a previous session then that is adequate notice for this chamber and gives senators warning that they can anticipate that it will be coming up in the next sittings of the parliament and they can be prepared for that debate. We, on this side of the chamber, accept that argument. That reasonably satisfies the issue of notice.

PARA.TAB: The other issue, however, is proper planning. The Senate simply having had notice that a bill is likely to be debated in the following sittings does not mean that the government will, within its planning of the program, allow adequate and proper time for the consideration of that bill. That is our disappointment. (Quorum formed) Before the quorum I was arguing that, whilst the motion before the chamber may be sufficient to give the Senate notice of the government's intention to move in this place a piece of legislation, it does not of itself ensure orderly planning and sufficient time for proper consideration of that legislation. The government's practice has been to stack bills at the end of the session, which inhibits the capacity of the Senate to do its job properly. This motion, unfortunately, is not a step towards resolving that shortcoming.

We have, from time to time, moved various motions—referred to commonly as cut-off motions—which have required the government to have matters debated in this chamber in an orderly way during the course of a sitting of the parliament. Those motions have been vigorously opposed by the government. In fact, the most effective motion that we moved and had passed in that regard brought down the wrath of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) upon the House of Representatives. In effect, he closed out most of the opposition's democratic rights to hold a government answerable.

He unilaterally decided that there would be no right of the opposition to move censure motions or to bring on matters of public importance. He undermined the capacity of an opposition to meet its constitutional responsibility. That is the attitude of this Prime Minister when the parliament seeks to resist his somewhat unique method of government. He fails to recognise that government in this country includes the parliament as an essential part of the process—and the parliament has a right and responsibility to debate legislation and to have adequate time to do it properly. He might regard us as unrepresentative swill and a nuisance in his legislative program, but we have a responsibility to the Australian people and we will not be bullied by him.

Yet he used his numbers in the House of Representatives to take out his wrath on the capacity of that chamber to fulfil its constitutional responsibility. That was a dark day in Australian democracy and the people ought to hold the Prime Minister accountable for that. I simply say in passing that whilst we support provisions that give this chamber more notice of the government's program, it does not resolve the fundamental problem that the government still will not meet an obligation to have orderly planning and will not bring bills before this chamber in a timetable that will allow proper and adequate consideration of them.

When the time is appropriate we will try again to introduce and have carried cut-off motions that will enforce orderly programming. I presume the Prime Minister will act as he did on the last occasion, which was to the detriment of democracy in this country. But we are determined, one way or another, to ensure that this government is forced to orderly programming. It has a responsibility to manage the place. Sometimes we think it likes to pass that responsibility to us. It is its legislative program; it controls the business before the chamber. We have always said that we will meet that responsibility according to the government's program. It is about time it started to get that program in order. So I support this motion but I nevertheless say that it does not address the fundamental problem before us in relation to procedural matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is giving nothing. It is not giving notice at all. What it is doing by this action is reducing the amount of notice that the Senate will have to deal with legislation and to seek public reaction to legislation. That is the important thing. We do not want to have another three or four weeks to cogitate on legislation; what we want is to have our minds informed about what the people think about the legislation.
