PARA.TAB: Do not make any error about it: what the government is doing here is amending the orders of the Senate of November last year to enable it to dump 50 bills into the House of Representatives on the last day of sittings and expect us to deal with all of those pieces of legislation in the next session. You did not know that, did you? That is precisely what you are agreeing to.

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect, you are missing the point. The fact is that, if they bring them in here on the first day of the session, it does not mean that they are going to debate them until the last day.
—What the government is proposing here is exactly that. It is proposing in this particular amendment:

PARA.TAB: For the reasons set out in this resolution, where a bill:
(a)is first introduced in the Senate by a minister in a period of sittings; or
(b)is received from the House of Representatives and was introduced in the House of Representatives in the same period of sittings . . .

SPEECH.PARA: Do you follow? It does not say anything about the previous sittings. The government can dump 50 pieces of legislation on the table—not debate them but just introduce them, as it sometimes does, on the last sitting day in December—and expect us to deal with them in February. I am not going along with that. That is a disgrace.

PARA.TAB: We have to keep these people honest. This was an undertaking given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) as part of the accountability package. He said, `We the government will attempt to ensure that we will work on the principle of introducing legislation in one session of the Senate and debating it the next.' I was fully aware of what he was saying under those circumstances. Now you are allowing him to weasel out of that.

Senator Hill, by his interjection to me, has obviously misunderstood what the government is talking about. He did not realise that this means 50 pieces of legislation can be dumped on the table in the House of Representatives, not be debated until the last sitting day in December, and then we will be expected to deal with them the next session. I am not having a bar of that. That would not allow us sufficient time to consult our constituents, the people that elect us. Why? Because everything in Australia tends to close down over Christmas. Now, with the new sitting patterns, we are sitting in February. We will not have the opportunity of properly canvassing these very important issues.

I invite honourable senators to look at the orders of the Senate on page 38 of the Notice Paper. The current order of the Senate that has been agreed to by the Senate after Senator Evans gave his undertaking for accountability states:

For the reasons set out in this resolution, where, during a period of sittings, a bill is first introduced into the Senate by a minister or received from the House of Representatives, and a motion is moved for the second reading of the bill, debate on that motion shall be adjourned at the conclusion of the speech of the Senator moving the motion and resumption of the debate shall be made an order of the day for the first day of sitting in the next period of sittings without any question being put.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the first paragraph of the motion. It is an order of the Senate. The government is now trying to dilute that particular order of the Senate, and in such a manner as would quite seriously place a question mark over the government's credibility and undertaking through its leader in this place, Senator Gareth Evans.

PARA.TAB: Why does Senator Evans not come in here now? Why does he let Senator Faulkner carry the can? Why does he not come in here and defend what is being done here? He does not do it; he cannot deliver. He has not delivered on anything as far as I am concerned, and he is not delivering on this matter either. Senator Evans's credibility is under question in this particular matter. The opposition should now have a think about what it is going to do, since it is evident from the interjection Senator Hill obviously did not understand the situation.

I would not mind if the motion were amended to say that pieces of legislation that were introduced in and disposed of by the House of Representatives could be debated in the Senate if they had not been received by the Senate in that particular session, because that would mean that there would be debate in the parliament, the issues would be canvassed publicly and people would know what was going on.

As I have said, I cannot agree to the proposition that is before us today. A previous notice of motion was put forward, and I am sure it must have been the motion Senator Hill was considering. (Quorum formed) I can now indicate that page 7 contains the amended notice which the opposition may well have been considering. I understand this debate might be adjourned after the next speaker, so I will hold fire until tomorrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was caught unawares a bit by this motion, although it has been on the Notice Paper for some time. Basically, it defeats the purpose of the procedural motion that was agreed to in this place in November which supported the principle of introduction in one session, debate in the next. It does that by saying that, provided a bill is introduced in the House of Representatives, it can be discussed in the Senate in the following session.

PARA.TAB: While from a community scrutiny point of view that is satisfactory because it addresses a concern raised by the procedural motion during debates we have had in previous sessions, it does not satisfactorily address the problem of log jams. I have an amendment which would redress the problem of legislation being able to be introduced in a great rush in the House of Representatives on the last day or in the last week of a parliamentary session which would then inundate the Senate and prevent us from conducting orderly business. I move:
After paragraph (b), insert the following word and paragraph:
";or (c)is received from the House of Representatives after the expiration of two-thirds of the total number of days of sitting of the Senate scheduled for that period of sittings".

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Pursuant to the communication by Senator Vanstone early today, I move:

PARA.TAB: That government business orders of the day Nos 1 and 2 relating to the Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 [1995] and the Racial Hatred Bill 1994, be postponed to 28 March 1995.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to unnecessarily take up the time of the Senate. However, in view of the nonsense argument put by the Senator Bolkus in an earlier debate today as to why we would seek to postpone debate of these matters for one week, let me put on the record that we are more than willing to debate the Racial Hatred Bill, except for the fact that the government knows that it is currently flawed. It is not a debate about the politics of the issue and whether the government legislation is the best way to address a particular problem in the community. It is simply a matter that has arisen out of the interpretation in the Brandy case which puts in some serious doubt the enforceability of parts of the Racial Hatred Bill.

PARA.TAB: It seems to us, in accordance with sensible process and normal Senate process, that such a flaw should be overcome before debate proceeds in this place. To do that in strict terms, we could have agreed with the Greens' motion earlier this day, but, because we are anxious that the Racial Hatred Bill debate be proceeded with, we do not want to go that far.

We simply say to the government at this stage that it should meet its normal obligations in relation to the preceding bill, the Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill. The government is seeking today to overcome its problem of the flaw by debate on substantial amendments to the Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill, amendments which we only received at the end of last week. That has precluded us from the normal opportunity to consider those amendments at a shadow ministry level and in the party room process, and we seek to do that in accordance with normal process. That will allow sufficient time in this session to deal in an orderly way with the first bill, the Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill, and then the Racial Hatred Bill.

There is no suggestion that we are seeking to delay debate, other than to force the government again to get its house in order. The government can put to this chamber today no reason why the normal processes should be abandoned at this time or why it needs the bill to be debated today rather than next Tuesday. In such circumstances I urge the Senate to support this motion and ensure that debate on both of these bills progress next week in an orderly and proper way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to put the Australian Democrats' position on record, we think there are good arguments for deferring the Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill. One of the arguments is that it landed on our doorstep only a couple of days ago. I think we need a careful assessment of what the bill is trying to do. We do not believe that the Racial Hatred Bill falls into that category. It has been before us for a considerable length of time. It deals with a substantive issue of importance, and the Australian Democrats would certainly not seek to delay debate on the Racial Hatred Bill.

PARA.TAB: If the coalition wishes to amend its motion and put it in two separate parts, we will certainly vote for deferment of the Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill, but not for deferment of the Racial Hatred Bill. If it does not do that, the Democrats will oppose the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make some remarks in support of the motion moved by Senator Hill. I understand in a sense what the Democrats are saying, except I think that they missed one fundamental point. It seems that the majority of people here agree that the Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill should be postponed until the amendments that everybody received only last week can be properly dealt with. There seems to be sufficient majority agreement on that. The Democrats, Senator Harradine and the Greens agree with that.

PARA.TAB: The question we now face is whether it is appropriate for us to, at the same time, defer the Racial Hatred Bill. Senator Spindler says, on behalf of the Democrats, `You don't need to defer that.' I am at a loss to understand why he said that, because an integral part of the government's bill that Senator Spindler wants debated is the civil remedies and the possibility of enforcing those. We have discovered—via the Brandy decision, and as Senator Harradine said in the committee hearings on this bill—that the government was quite confident it was going to win that case. Now we find a different situation: amendments have to be dealt with.

Opposition senators who participated in the committee that Senator Harradine went along to—and those who did not participate—are very interested in this bill. They very much want to comment on the civil remedies and the enforcement procedures. They do not want to simply come in here and tack on a few remarks in the committee stage. They want to have the proper time to amend the speeches that they might have prepared—either on paper or in their heads—on the racial hatred legislation. They want to include in their speeches in the second reading debate comments vis-a-vis the enforcement procedures. We do not think it is reasonable that they be asked to do that without the enforcement procedures having gone through the proper processes. That, of course, brings us back to where we were this morning.

Senator Bolkus will undoubtedly say, `Look, all we are doing is returning this back to 1992.' I have already established this morning that that is not the case. Government advisers freely admit that. There are a few other changes. The government says they are minor changes but, as Senator Harradine pointed out, it also said that the Brandy case was not going to get up. So what confidence should we have in the view that the government puts?

When I was mistakenly offered one of the adviser's briefing notes this morning and, doing the right thing as I generally try to do, gave it back, I could not help but see a page headed `Matters that might come up in debate'. I said, `Perhaps I could have a copy of that as well. I'd like to be informed when this matter is considered.' But I could not have a copy of that. Why not? Because the public servants are there as advisers to the executive, and they do not want to give me the things that might come up in the debate. They want to keep me as ill-informed as they possibly can.

We think it is fair enough that the government clearly thinks the Racial Hatred Bill should follow the Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill. That is in its programming this morning. It is the sensible ordering of the two bills. The reason it is the sensible ordering of the two bills is that there are several provisions in the government's Racial Hatred Bill. The enforcement of those provisions was thrown out of the window by the High Court's Brandy decision. The government now says it has some amendments that will at least be a holding position to fix that problem. The government wanted us to deal with those today, without proper consideration and just by taking its word for it.

Given that those enforcement procedures need to be fixed, we think it is unreasonable for the government to ask us to deal with the Racial Hatred Bill before we have ascertained the propriety of those amendments to the enforcement procedures. It is important to postpone the human rights legislation in order to establish the propriety or otherwise of the enforcement procedures that are now going to be suggested so that we can check that everything is as the government advisers say it is. It is sensible to make sure of that before the government proceeds with the second reading speech on the Racial Hatred Bill.

The reason for that is that the second reading speech is not meant to be bits and pieces of information pulled out of the air that will do today because it suits the government to deal with this bill today or because the Democrats do not care whether it is dealt with today. The second reading speech is meant to refer to the problems that the government thinks are in the bill. The basic principles behind the bill can be included, but the second reading speech is designed to give the government the opportunity to outline what it thinks are the problems. Until the enforcement procedures are settled, how can someone refer to that in their speech in the second reading debate? They simply cannot.

There will be plenty of bills where we could split the second reading debate and the committee stage—bills where a matter is looked at by a committee and then comes back, there having been adequate time to consider the committee's report, and we proceed. But an integral part of the Racial Hatred Bill is the civil remedies, and an integral part of those civil remedies is the enforcement procedures. Surely it is appropriate to get those settled before we ask people to debate the second reading of the Racial Hatred Bill. For that reason, I urge the Democrats to reconsider their position and to recognise the need for people to make sensible comment in their contributions to the second reading debate that refers to both the criminal and the civil remedies and the enforcement procedures for both. I urge them to do the sensible thing and at least get the enforcement procedures settled.

We are prepared to meet the government halfway. We had the opportunity to support the Greens and refuse to debate any of this until the human rights legislation amendments had been completely dealt with by both houses. We thought that was an unreasonable request because, for one reason or another, there might be a scheduling problem, but all parties might be in agreement—I emphasise `might be in agreement'—that the amendments the government seeks to move are nothing more than what it says they are. There may be no problem with them. Had we supported the Greens' motion this morning, simply because of some minor scheduling problem we could be held up from debating the Racial Hatred Bill. We do not want to be in that position.

What we want is the proper time to consider the amendments to the human rights legislation and to assess the position we will then be in when we are looking at the enforcement procedures in the Racial Hatred Bill. Once that is settled, after we have all had the proper time to consider this—for us that will be Tuesday of next week because that is when we will have taken those amendments to our shadow ministry and to our party room and probably got independent advice; we will probably seek that because, as the government admits, it is also making what it describes as some minor technical changes—and it has gone through our proper processes and Senator Harradine, Senator Chamarette, Senator Margetts and the Democrats have had the time to consider it, then we think it will be fair enough to start the Racial Hatred Bill.

Even if the human rights amendments are not technically passed by both houses, by then everyone will be in a position to know where they are going to go and they will know what they want to say in their contributions to the second reading debate of the Racial Hatred Bill and with respect to the enforcement procedures in the civil remedies, which are an integral part of that bill. For that reason, we think it is very sensible on this occasion to keep the second reading debate and the committee stage together rather than separate them in some way for whatever reason.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I also do not want to prolong discussion on the debate for too long, but I am sure there is a given life to this part of the proceedings. We have an amazing coincidence here. This is a shameful way for us in this place to commemorate the International Day of the Elimination of Race Discrimination. That is what today is, and the Senate is not prepared to grasp the issue, not prepared to confront it.

PARA.TAB: We have spent most of this morning watching opposition senators struggling and torturing themselves and us about whether they can confront race discrimination, racial hatred, this week. That is the timing that we are involved in at the moment. It is the International Day of the Elimination of Race Discrimination, and the opposition once again cannot understand race issues, cannot understand our society and cannot understand the importance of what is going through this place and what will inevitably, one way or the other, go through this place.

The reality is that for a few hours now we have seen a concerted attempt by those on the other side with an agenda to ensure that this week we do not debate this issue—that this week, in the lead-up to the New South Wales election, we do not debate racial hatred. That is what all this is about. Let us not shy away from that. This is precisely what this is about: the Liberal Party playing once again with Australia's ethnic communities and not being able to grasp policy issues. It is doing it in a very cynical way. The timing is shameful. That is what we are involved in now.

Not only are those opposite not prepared to decide on the bill but also they are not prepared to debate it. They are not prepared to have the second reading debate. There are many speakers on the second reading debate list. We often have in this place second reading debate before final amendments are even produced to the parliament. We often have amendments coming from the opposition's side at the end of second reading debates. It is even more shameful that those opposite are not prepared to allow this process to continue with respect to this bill's second reading when they already have the amendments. That accentuates what they are on about.

We often debate bills in this place. However, you are not prepared to confront this issue this week because there is an election in New South Wales and you do not want to be exposed on the issue of race and exposed to the ethnic communities. I can tell you something—you have been. That has been acknowledged both inside and outside the Liberal Party. There is a chorus of voices out there in the community saying precisely one thing, `The Liberals do not care about race and they do not care about our multicultural society.' This cynical manoeuvre this morning has reinforced that view. The Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, has come in wishing to make a new profile for himself. Every step he has taken with respect to race issues has reinforced the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who got rid of the White Australia policy?

—Who dismantled it? Who put it to bed? Al Grassby interred the White Australia policy. It was to our shame that it dragged on for so long. Every issue dealing with race that the new opposition leader has confronted has been handled with the same insensitivity as has been shown in the past. I refer to the shameful performance in the House of Representatives relating to Hindmarsh Island and the insensitivity shown to our core indigenous people and their cultural and spiritual rights. That issue has been tossed around in that chamber in such a way that most Australians find it abhorrent. That is how the opposition treats race and that is how the new opposition leader treats race issues. We have seen evidence of that again this morning in relation to this particular issue.

PARA.TAB: Those opposite say that they have not had time to look at the issues. Let us look at the time they have had in respect of this bill. This bill was introduced late last year at the end of some three or four years of discussion, debate, parliamentary committee hearings and broad consultations with the community. For instance, we had the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, the ALRC report on multiculturalism and the law and the National Inquiry into Racist Violence. All these inquiries were conducted in 1991-92 as predecessors to this legislation which was introduced before the last election. The government followed it up last November.

This legislation has had a very long gestation period. What has happened in the meantime? The only thing that I have seen happen in the meantime is a rise in the incidence of racial hatred. There was a demonstration of this in the streets outside the bureau conference in Adelaide a few weeks ago. This hatred hurt a lot of people in a very personal sense. We witnessed the igniting power of racial hatred when we saw scenes from the football in the United Kingdom a few weeks ago. Racial hatred was very much at the core of the violence there.

Those opposite say that we have had the bill, but what about the amendments and the final outcome of the court case? That has been considered by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. It has taken the approach that any reasonable person who does not have something to hide or does not want to run away from this debate would take in relation to this matter. The position that that committee took is outlined on page 20 of its report and goes to the core of what this debate is about today. The other incidental amendments go to other aspects of the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't be so misleading.

—They have been explained to you. You have been a bit disingenuous in describing them. The report of that committee made it very clear that we could go ahead with this bill because appropriate amendments would be made to the Race Discrimination Act 1975 in subsequent legislation. We will challenge you on this issue. We are prepared to have the debate on the second reading this week. Let us have that debate.

PARA.TAB: Senator Vanstone admitted five minutes ago that it is part of the normal process in this place to have amendments at the end of the debate on the second reading, but she is not prepared to do it on this issue. Why not? Ethnic Australia and multicultural Australia are asking why Senator Vanstone will not allow the same rights of passage for this bill as she does for any other legislation. The reason is that she cannot come up with an answer. The reason she cannot come up with an answer is that she is involved in some sleazy process of deferral. That is what this is about.

I am prepared to take on Senator Spindler's amendment because that seems acceptable to the government. We are about getting business through this place this week and we are not about deferring important legislation. Those opposite are not responding to the needs of our community. I think this is a very shameful way to spend this day.

This is not something that the Liberal Party is not used to. Whether we are dealing with native title legislation, Mabo legislation, spiritual rights of indigenous Australians, race discrimination acts or racial hatred legislation we have a consistent position from the opposition side. No wonder Gerard Henderson, who was once an adviser of John Howard, writes continually about the fact that the opposition will not win government in this country unless it understands the diversity that exists in this country, understands multicultural issues and understands issues of race.

It is not just a matter of social issues; it is also a matter of economic issues. Unless we get the issue of race right at home, we will not be able to project ourselves to the rest of the world as a country that understands it well. What do we do to commemorate International Day for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination? We have this tortuous debate where Senator Vanstone and her colleagues try to find any manoeuvre to put off debating this legislation.

In any person's reading, failure to pass involves failure to consider. Failure to consider is the first step towards failure to pass. We will come back to this legislation. We will find ways of bringing it back. It is a shameful, sleazy effort by you to defer this legislation this week when your colleagues in New South Wales are in fact asking you to support it. The reason why you are not even prepared to debate it is that you are embarrassed by your own side. You are embarrassed that the Fischers and the Katters will come out making the sorts of insensitive statements that they have continually made on this issue. There is no doubt about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, get lost!
—They are not in the Senate, you goof!
—You can crow and chirp over there all you like but the reality is that, every time Tim Fischer or Bob Katter open their mouth on this issue, as they are prone to—

PARA.TAB: Senator O'Chee interjecting—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Order! Senator O'Chee, I have been trying to turn a deaf ear to you but the last time I was not able to. You will withdraw that statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw calling Senator Bolkus a fool. We all know what he is.
—Senator O'Chee, you know that that is disorderly. You will withdraw the statement.
—I did.
—I ask for an unreserved withdrawal.
—I think it is required after the comment that you made when I initially asked you to withdraw. You will withdraw unreservedly.
—I withdrew unreservedly the comment that he was a fool. We all know what he is.
—Senator O'Chee, that is not satisfactory. You will withdraw unreservedly.
—I will withdraw unreservedly—
—That is all you need say. You no longer have the call.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. In the course of his remarks, Senator Bolkus made comments about both Mr Fischer and Mr Katter. Not only were those comments not in an appropriate form; they cast aspersions upon members of the House of Representatives. I want those comments withdrawn.
—If you wanted them withdrawn, you should have asked at the time.
—I am asking now.
—I am not aware of the comments.
—I am sorry, Mr Acting Deputy President. I see those comments as being unparliamentary and I would like them withdrawn.
—I am not aware of the comments. If you had asked for them to be withdrawn at the time that they were made, I would probably be aware of them—
—It was 30 seconds before you pulled me to order.
—I was probably listening to your comments at the time.
—This is a joke.
—I call Senator Bolkus—

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: I ask you to indicate to the Senate the basis of your ruling demanding that Senator O'Chee provide the words `I withdraw unreservedly'. When we made that same request earlier this day of Senator Bolkus, all he did was half-heartedly get to his feet and I say, `I do so.' He was not required to repeat the words `I unreservedly withdraw'. I am just wondering what is the standard required by the chair to accept that something has been withdrawn unreservedly.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: when I withdrew earlier on, I withdrew without reservation. I said, `I withdraw.' That is all Senator O'Chee had to do. But Senator O'Chee went on to repeat the offensive words, and in doing so incurred the wrath of the Acting Deputy President. That is the difference, Senator Abetz.
—That is the explanation I would have given. (Quorum formed)

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I would request that you require the minister to refer to members of the other place by their appropriate titles and not solely by their surnames. I am sure that would not have passed your ears and you would have heard that, and I am sure you know that that is unparliamentary. I would ask you to direct the minister accordingly.
—It had not passed my ears and I intended to say something about it at the conclusion of the minister's speech.

—If everyone is ready, I will get back into it. The point I want to make in conclusion is that this has been a bill of long gestation; there is no need to defer it. As Senator Spindler said quite rightly, enforcement mechanisms are already available under existing legislation. We know what is going to be happening through the amendments pursuant to Brandy.

PARA.TAB: The point I made earlier is worth referring to. On this International Day of the Elimination of Race Discrimination your side is playing politics with this issue by not having it debated this week. We on this side of the parliament are prepared to conclude the second reading debate this week. But the reality is that you want to keep people in the closet, you want to keep your arguments in the closet this week, so you do not embarrass your colleagues in New South Wales.

The communities out there do not need this debate to know about you. For instance, when your alternative bill was brought up they saw through that very quickly. Victor Rebikoff from the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia condemned the draft legislation as a farce and a con. He said that it was an attempt by the coalition to create an illusion that it had a position on racial hatred when the party had not endorsed the bill. They can see through you. They can see through you not only by your position on our bill but also by the farce, the con, that you call your bill.

They can also see through you by they way you handle ethnic communities. It is quite timely that in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning the vice-president of one of your branches in New South Wales had this to say—it is worth remembering; it does not matter what you do this week to try to keep the personalities and the arguments in the closet because what is known out there is what Mr Neville Shalhoub said on the weekend—about the Liberal Party:

"I have been a member of the Liberal Party for years, and it is my belief that the Liberal Party in NSW not only ignores the ethnic communities, but they want them to have no effective involvement inside the Liberal Party.

"The Ethnic Affairs Minister, Michael Photios, is a puppet who is controlled by the Attorney-General and Minister for Justice, John Hannaford, and the Minister for Energy and Local Government, Ted Pickering," he said.

"They think all they have to do is send Michael Photios out with a bagful of money cheques and spread them like confetti throughout the community and that will suffice to show they represent the ethnic communities."

SPEECH.PARA: I think he is right. That is what they think you have to do. It did not work in the Parramatta by-election. It does not work with ethnic communities because they are too smart for that scheme. It treats them with disrespect to think that you can spend $50,000 here and there and win their votes. The reality is that they are concerned about racial hatred in our community. They are concerned about this legislation going through. They have sat back for four years wondering whether it will get through this place. On this International Day of the Elimination of Race Discrimination ethnic communities are confronted with the reality that the opposition not only will not let the bill be passed through this place but also will not even let it be debated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the next speaker, I would like to make two comments. Firstly, it is normal courtesy in this place to use proper titles when referring to a person from this place or from the House of Representatives. Secondly, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs mentioned an amendment. There is no formal amendment before the chair at the present time.

—The fact that I stand here today as a representative of the Liberal Party is proof positive that the Liberal Party of Australia does care about the ethnic communities within Australia. As I indicated in my first speech to this house, I am very proud of my heritage. I am an immigrant to this country and I am also very proud to be an Australian.

PARA.TAB: I do not believe it does the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) any credit to cast aspersions across the chamber as to who is seeking to champion the cause of the ethnic communities. What we are on about is trying to get legislation which will be of benefit to the people of Australia and those who suffer as a consequence of other people's behaviour.

The Racial Hatred Bill is relatively short; nevertheless, it is complex. It was interesting to hear the minister quote Mr Victor Rebikoff from FECCA, the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia, a man for whom I have a general high regard, who is a great advocate for the ethnic communities within this country and who has done a lot for the ethnic communities. However, when the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee was looking at the Racial Hatred Bill, even Mr Rebikoff made an unintentional error—nevertheless it was an error—as to how this legislation would apply. The Hansard will show that the legal adviser to the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia, Mr Ian Lacey, corrected Mr Rebikoff as to the impact and implementation of the government's legislation.

It is not wise for the minister to seek to rely on that sort of advice in condemning the opposition's version of the bill, which I might add is only a draft exposure at this stage. Unlike the government, we on this side of the chamber are willing to say that we will take into account community opinion; that we will consider the views of the ethnic communities as to the best way to deal with a problem which clearly offends all decent Australians. I would have thought discrimination on the basis of race is abhorrent to everybody within this chamber regardless of their party or political persuasion.

It is quite inappropriate and very unstatesmanlike for the minister to try to score points on the basis of who looks after the ethnic communities better. The simple fact is, Mr Acting Deputy President, as you would be well aware, having served in this chamber a lot longer than I have, that this question of racial hatred legislation has now been on the Labor Party agenda not for weeks, not for months, but literally for years.

In fact it introduced a bill, as I understand it, before the last federal election. The bill lapsed because the government did not pursue it. It then introduced another piece of legislation, which is currently before us. So it is hardly appropriate for the minister to assert that the government has acted with all due haste when we are talking about years of delay on the government's side and we, on this side, have given a date—namely, 28 March, seven days time—for reconsideration.

Why have we asked for that seven-day delay, Mr Acting Deputy President? The reason, as outlined by you from the chair just a few moments ago, was that, technically, there are no amendments to the Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill before the Senate. They have not hit the Table Office as yet, as I understand it. If that is the case, then the minister is asking us to consider this legislation before the proposed government amendments have been tabled and presented to backbenchers such as me who do not necessarily get the advantages that the shadow minister obtains by getting an advance copy of them.

If I am to take my role seriously in an issue that I believe, in my short time here, I have shown a very real interest in, it is appropriate for me to at least have the proposed government amendments before me in relation to the Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill. Those amendments will have a substantial impact on the way the Racial Hatred Bill will be implemented and provisions of it enforced. Before I consider the whole regime of the Racial Hatred Bill, I want to know exactly how provisions of it will be enforced and implemented. I would have thought seeking a seven-day delay of that so that especially we on this side of the chamber can satisfy ourselves as to those amendments is a reasonable, sound and proper stance for us to take if we are to take seriously our role as reviewers of legislation in this house.

The enforcement procedures clearly are an integral part of the legislation. Indeed, why have the legislation unless there is some enforcement aspect to it which will give some teeth to what the government is trying to achieve? That makes sense, but we on this side want to know what those teeth are and how they will be implemented. It would be quite improper for us to accept in a sealed envelope from the government certain amendments and to say that we will just accept them without having read them. It would be inappropriate and it would not be a proper way for us to conduct our business.

It is interesting that the two people whom the minister plucked out of the air as possibly causing us embarrassment and whom he does not want on the public record during this debate are both members of the House of Representatives. The House of Representatives is not sitting this week, so they would not have the opportunity to make comment during the debate. This is a week in which only the Senate is sitting and, of course, the minister could not think of one senator he could mention to support his argument.

This is a serious matter. It has taken considerable time for the government to get itself together in relation to this legislation. This is the second attempt at the legislation. In fact, during the hearings of the legal and constitutional committee, I was convinced that, although the Brandy case was about to be considered, we ought to proceed anyway because the government was confident that it would win. Clearly that advice was incorrect, as Senator Harradine pointed out earlier. The score was 7-0 in the High Court.

Given that history in relation to this legislation, it would be highly inappropriate for us on this side of the chamber to accept carte blanche the assurances of the minister and the same department that got it so wrong in relation to the Brandy decision. All we are asking for is another seven days to consider the enforcement aspects of this legislation. I do not think that is unreasonable. I think it is highly proper. For Senator Bolkus, the minister with the carriage of this matter, to seek to cast aspersions on the opposition as to its reasons and to come up with what I consider to be inappropriate political commentary on the opposition is not fair or appropriate.

If we as a nation are to be unified we need to deal with these issues on a sensitive basis and not seek to divide the ethnic communities as unfortunately has occurred with this minister under his control of the immigration department. There are legion numbers of people within the ethnic communities who will tell us that if we go around and listen to what they have to say. It is highly inappropriate for the minister to grandstand in this place about the importance of this legislation on this particular day.

The importance to Australia is not whether this legislation gets passed today or in a week's time—or whether it should have been passed a year ago. The importance is that we get it right, to ensure that those who have to live under the law have certainty and know what it is all about. That is the best way to achieve a good and cohesive society. Certainty under the law is one of the most important principles for a democratic society that is governed by the rule of law. We on this side of the chamber are simply asking that we be given due time—only seven days—to consider the legislation so that we can deal with it in a way that is appropriate, given the trust that is placed in us by the electors of our various states.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the next speaker, I indicate that in case Senator Abetz misunderstood a comment made by the chair, when I was referring to an amendment I meant an amendment to this motion before the chair.
—I misunderstood you, Mr Acting Deputy President.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek to put the Greens' position on the record. It might clarify the way the discussion is going. Essentially, the Greens' position on the motion moved by the opposition is a mirror image of that on the motion presented by the Australian Democrats. We do not have any objection to entering into a consideration of the Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill. We feel that it can certainly benefit from a seven-day delay, which has been requested by the opposition and by the Democrats. We would not seek to oppose that. It is always good to give maximum consideration to such matters—and we received the amendments so recently.

PARA.TAB: We do object to dealing with the Racial Hatred Bill prior to the consideration and resolution of the anomalies raised by the Brandy case in relation to the operation of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. Obviously we want to see that logical sequence followed and we would not agree with the amendment proposed by Senator Spindler that we defer only the first bill, the Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill for seven days, but nevertheless go into the Racial Hatred Bill. It has been stated that we should just go ahead into consideration of the Racial Hatred Bill, even if it is only the second reading debate, because the constitutionality questions over the operation of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission can be resolved later.

That is neither a satisfactory nor a logical position in our view. I do not think there would be any argument with the fact that the Brandy case threw a spanner in the works of the operation and enforcement mechanisms of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. I will read from the government amendments outline on the Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill. It is not yet an explanatory memorandum, but I think it will be the supplementary explanatory memorandum. The outline states:

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments respond to the consequences of the High Court's decision in Brandy v. Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and Others on 23 February which held that the mechanism for the enforcement of determinations by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, (the Commission), under the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 other than determinations made affecting respondents who are Commonwealth agencies was constitutionally invalid.

The government is taking seriously its response to that High Court decision. It has set up a committee to consider some long-term changes to the operation of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. We have an interim series of amendments which reverts back to the November 1992 operation of the commission. Whether those amendments are accepted or not, whether the commission reverts back to the pre-November 1992 operation or not, materially affects the consideration that we will be giving to the Racial Hatred Bill.

PARA.TAB: The explanatory memorandum of the Racial Hatred Bill states on page 2 that criminal sanctions are set out in clause 4 of the bill. It further states:

SPEECH.PARA: By contrast, the civil prohibition in clause 6 of the Bill addresses acts done because of race, colour or national or ethnic origin, otherwise than in private, which are reasonably likely to offend, insult, humiliate or intimidate people. Under the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 ("RDA"), there are already a number of other prohibitions the contravention of which may be investigated and conciliated by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission ("HREOC") under the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986 ("HREOC Act"). The proposed prohibition on offensive behaviour based on racial hatred would be placed within the existing jurisdiction of the Commission to conciliation and/or determine complaints alleging breaches of the RDA.

I think it is a very tenuous argument to say that only the enforcement of determinations will be affected and that therefore we can go ahead because it does not necessarily affect the capacity of the commission to conciliate or determine. I think it is a materially substantial matter.

PARA.TAB: The operation of that commission, which is so crucial to half of the Racial Hatred Bill, has not been and will not be resolved until such time as the amendments being considered in relation to the Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill are resolved not only in this place but also in the House of Representatives, which as we know meets next week. For that reason, in my view there is an irrefutable logic that connects the two bills and says that we should deal with one before the other. If we defer the first bill for seven days, the Greens feel that it is utterly appropriate to defer the Racial Hatred Bill for an equivalent period. That was essentially the meaning underlying the motion I proposed this morning which was defeated.

It is interesting that there may well be, as Senator Bolkus mentioned earlier, political motivations involved in this deferral. As Senator Vanstone said in the earlier debate, it may be that opposition members felt it totally appropriate to defer the human rights legislation amendments because they had not had sufficient notice but that they did not wish to be seen to be delaying the Racial Hatred Bill. That is why they did not agree with the kind of connection that I raised in the motion we put forward earlier. It may well be that they want to avoid the kinds of political insinuations that Senator Bolkus was so free with in his comments.

In fact, I thought that Senator Bolkus's criticisms of the opposition's timing was quite revealing. One often finds that motives ascribed in criticisms reveal more of the accuser than the person may realise. I had no idea until Senator Bolkus spoke that the New South Wales election at the end of this week is very important to the government's timing in relation to its consideration, even to the second reading, of the Racial Hatred Bill. If he can say that the opposition has a political motivation to delay it—I do not actually think that has been evidenced by the opposition, but it may be so—he has certainly put it on the record that the government is motivated to bring it on before the New South Wales election. I think that is quite ironic.

My main point is not just to make a crack at Senator Bolkus but really to repeat the question: why are we having a racial hatred bill? What is the motivation of it? What is the impetus? Surely it has nothing to do with the New South Wales election because New South Wales has a perfectly adequate piece of racial vilification legislation in place already. Instead of seeing it as support for what has been rightly mentioned as today's International Day of the Elimination of Race Discrimination, it may be that there is going to be some politicking at a federal level that may be ascribed in some way to and have some part in what happens in the New South Wales election. I do not think that is a very good reason either for delaying this legislation or for making it urgent.

The point at issue is whether a racial hatred bill is this parliament's best possible response to the occurrence of racial discrimination and racial vilification within our community in Australia today—a situation nobody would want to tolerate. We would want to seek the most positive response to that issue, and whether this bill provides it or not is debatable and will be debated. Also, the degree to which the operation of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission is affected by the Brandy decision is of crucial importance to the way in which that is addressed.

That is a fairly longwinded way—I apologise for taking up the time—of stating why the Greens will be supporting the opposition's motion. I was not here when it was put forward by the opposition, but we agree that the two bills need to be linked in a sequential manner.

TALK.START.PARA: —I start out by fully endorsing the comments made by Senator Chamarette. Indeed, one could question why the government is so anxious to have the Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill dealt with prior to the New South Wales election. In fact, I would have thought the New South Wales election, or any mention of it, was entirely irrelevant to what we are debating here.

PARA.TAB: We are debating here the question of democratic process. That is, the government affords the minority parties and the opposition in this Senate with an opportunity to scrutinise a bill which is being introduced. That applies to every piece of proposed legislation, not just to the legislation before us. That opportunity simply has not been afforded to the minority parties and the opposition in this case. I say to those people who are listening, to the people of Australia, that no doubt you would expect that to be a fundamental democratic rule that would be practised in the national parliament.

What has been proposed here today is an abrogation of that fundamental rule. What has been proposed, with very little notice and with no opportunity whatsoever to scrutinise this legislation, is that the opposition and the minority parties should simply rubber-stamp it, to fly by the seat of their pants, to venture with a blindfold, as it were, into the debate of this issue. That is entirely inappropriate, undemocratic and something that should be abhorrent to the people of this country.

The Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill does have relevance to the Racial Hatred Bill. I was a member of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee which looked into this matter. I appreciate that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) says that this matter has been ventilated a great deal and that it does in fact go back some years, but we have an intervening cause, an intervening event, which changed things dramatically.

It was whilst the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee was conducting its inquiry that the High Court handed down its decision in the Brandy case, and that changed things radically. It changed things so much that the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee called before it the Attorney-General's Department to give evidence as to the effect this case would have on the Racial Hatred Bill.

That is an unusual situation. It is not often that a Senate committee, during the course of its inquiry, has a decision by the highest court in this land which affects the subject of that inquiry, but that is precisely what happened. So all the years of inquiry, all the years of discussion might basically count for nought. That is what the committee had to inquire into.

Senator Bolkus is entirely wrong when he quotes the Senate committee as saying there is no problem with continuing the debate on the Racial Hatred Bill. In the dissenting report, which was signed by Senator McGauran, Senator Brownhill, Senator Short, Senator Abetz, Senator O'Chee, Senator Baume and me, it was stated that, given the recent decision of the High Court in the case of Harry Brandy v. the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, it would be necessary to await the government's response to ascertain the mechanisms whereby enforceability for a complaint can be achieved.It was not the unanimous decision of that committee that we could proceed with this debate; the coalition's dissenting report said that we needed to wait and see what the Attorney-General's response to that case was.

When we questioned officers from that department, it became apparent that they were faced with a very complex question indeed and were looking at the interim period, going back to the pre-1992 situation, trying to fathom out a response. The Brandy decision basically says that these commissions, which are looking at human rights matters, equal opportunity matters and sexual discrimination, could not function as a court, that it was an abuse of that part of the constitution which requires a separation of powers; that is, you cannot confer judicial powers on non-judicial bodies. That was a fundamental flaw, so fundamental that all High Court judges saw it and, in an explicit judgment, cut down the operation of these commissions.

That brings us to the Racial Hatred Bill because the second half of that bill deals with civil remedies; that is, civil sanctions for people who might offend or insult any individual or section of the community by virtue of racial comments. So if we were to have the debate on the Racial Hatred Bill, we would get to a point where we would have to talk about the enforceability of those civil sanctions, those civil provisions in the bill, and it would be at that point that the debate would run into a brick wall. We would have the application of Brandy's case, saying there is no enforcement, no sanction. We could then only assume that the civil section is not worth the paper it is written on because you do not legislate against something and then not provide the sanction to back it up.

The government is saying that it is okay to proceed with the debate on the Racial Hatred Bill, to debate the niceties of a civil remedy for some act of racism. But we would be doing so in the light that its provisions are unenforceable. So why have it on the statute books? Why outlaw something if there is no sanction, if there is no force? It is an absolutely facile argument.

The coalition is saying, `Let us have a look at what the government is proposing here in its bill and make sure it does what the government says it does; if it returns the matter to the 1992 situation, so be it.' At least we can then conduct the debate on the civil sanctions contained in the Racial Hatred Bill on that basis.

At the moment we would be debating in the dark. We would be arguing about a hypothetical situation because we are putting the cart before the horse. In fact, to maintain any form of logical democratic process, we should debate firstly the Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill and then the Racial Hatred Bill. That is the sensible, democratic course of action and it is one which will not cause this country any prejudice. Greater prejudice will be caused if we are forced into debating a matter where we know not the answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I want to respond briefly to comments made by Senator Vanstone, Senator Ellison and Senator Chamarette. Much is made of the fact that we have not resolved the consequences of the so-called Brandy decision of the High Court. It would be useful to briefly traverse just what the substance of the situation is. In the pre-Brandy situation, it was possible for decisions or pronouncements by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to be registered with the Federal Court, thus ensuring enforceability. The High Court decided that was not appropriate. We have now amendments before us. For a minute I thought that Senator Abetz said he had not seen them, but I think that was clarified. We have certainly had them before us since Friday. We consider that inadequate timing but they were certainly available.

PARA.TAB: Those amendments substantially return us to the pre-1992 situation where separate action needs to be taken in the Federal Court to ensure enforceability. We rather regret that because it means that more cost is incurred by people seeking civil remedies before the human rights commission. No doubt in time some way around it will be found which is easier for people who take their case to the human rights commission. However, it seems to me that in this particular situation whether we have enforceability one way or the other does not really touch on the substance of the Racial Hatred Bill. I think it would only have some relevance if either the coalition parties or Senator Chamarette suggested they might be happy not to vote for the amendments ensuring post-Brandy enforceability by returning the situation to the 1992 position thus leaving us with no means of enforcement for civil remedies before the human rights commission.

I believe that is not the case. I would find it extraordinary if that were the case. If that is not the case, surely the second reading debate on the substance of the Racial Hatred Bill can proceed on the assumption that we will have enforceability as suggested by the amendments of the government to the Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill that is before the Senate. I do not wish to prolong the debate unduly, but if it is appropriate for me to move my amendment formally now I would like to do so.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—You may move the amendment now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Omit "orders of the day Nos 1 and 2 relating to the Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 [1995] and the Racial Hatred Bill 1994", substitute "order of the day No. 1 relating to the Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 [1995]".

TALK.START.PARA: —I am now inclined to support the motion that has been moved. I was not inclined to support it until I had heard the arguments that have been advanced. The arguments advanced by Senator Chamarette were very lucid and have particularly influenced my consideration of this matter. They were so logical. From what she said it followed that, if we logically assessed whether or not to vote for the motion, we would vote in favour of the motion. I am not suggesting that the other speeches were not influential. I understand the point made by Senator Spindler.

PARA.TAB: I must say that the other thing that has convinced me to vote for the motion is the speech made by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) in opposition to the motion. In fact, if there was any politicising of this very important matter, it was by Senator Bolkus. He should really think about that. If he is going to use the refugee situation and the question of racial hatred as a political football—as he and Senator McKiernan are doing—the chamber should discuss that. That matter weighs very heavily on my mind at the present time. I will not discuss in detail—because I would be out of order—my concern that has been developing over the last three or four months with what Senator Bolkus is doing and how his statements have divided the community. A minister in his position should not divide the community.

We are trying, as a country, to create a society in which all persons can live with freedom and dignity and pursue their spiritual development and material wellbeing in conditions of equal opportunity. This is particularly for persons who come to Australia from other lands and for persons who are given international protection because they have a well-founded fear of persecution if they are returned to their persecutors and torturers. This minister is not doing this. This minister is injecting a political element into the arguments on those life and death issues, and I cannot condone that in any shape or form.

As I said this morning, I am inclined to support the racial hatred legislation. I have found it rather fascinating that the government, over a period of time, has denigrated the concept of the educative role of the law. I have sat here for 20-odd years and listened to government senators and other senators denigrate the idea of the educative role of the law. That is what the Racial Hatred Bill is all about, to a large extent. To that extent, I support it.

Obviously one cannot legislate to make people moral, but we ought to have a framework of legislation in which basic human rights principles are upheld. One of those human rights principles is that not only should you not treat people as objects for utilisation for some other purpose but also you should always affirm the person as a person. That is a matter that should be beyond politics.

Here we have the minister, as Senator Chamarette pointed out, virtually admitting that the reason that the government wants to have this debate this week is the New South Wales election. So what! New South Wales elections come and New South Wales elections go. To be quite frank, I could not care less about New South Wales elections. This is a matter which should be above party politics and the grubby politicking of politicians.

As has been quite rightly said—I cannot remember who it was but one of the opposition speakers mentioned this—an essential element of the racial hatred legislation is the matter of civil remedies and enforcement procedures. They all depend on what occurs with the human rights and equal opportunities legislation. I ask the minister to find out from his advisers whether I was informed at all about the proposed amendments to the human rights and equal opportunities legislation. Was I? If I was, I did not get a copy of them.

Apparently some people have privileged positions in this chamber. I do not recall receiving any proposed amendments to that legislation. That is another reason why I am not prepared to support even a second reading at this particular juncture. So much depends on those amendments, in my view. Under those circumstances, I support the motion that has been moved by Senator Hill. I hope we can give mature consideration in a non-partisan way to the matters that are before us. I believe these measures deserve to be treated in a non-partisan way.

I urge all honourable senators to treat this matter in a non-partisan way—not try to make political points for a tin-pot election in New South Wales. They should bear in mind the importance of this matter for the future of a harmonious society in Australia. They should bear that in mind also when it comes to the other matter: the attempt that is being made by the government to send back people to their persecutors and to send back people who are under threat of coerced abortions, coerced sterilisations and other grave sanctions. I ask honourable senators to bear that in mind because if we pass that sort of legislation, as the government wants us to, we can make no claim to being a civilised country.
Amendment negatived.
Original question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—Order! It now being after 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Labor Party: New South Wales Branch

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I want to raise a matter of some significance relating to the financial capacity of the Australian Labor Party and in particular the New South Wales division of the Australian Labor Party, which is technically bankrupt. We know it is morally bankrupt; we know it is intellectually bankrupt; we know it is politically bankrupt. We see evidence of that every day in the newspapers. We see it all through the election campaign presently going on in New South Wales. But the fact that it is technically bankrupt financially says a lot about the sort of government we would get in New South Wales if the Labor Party were given the opportunity of getting back into the position of power that it had some years ago when it became renowned throughout Australia for the level of its corruption and its incompetence.

PARA.TAB: The Labor Party simply cannot be trusted with money. That is evident from the way that the New South Wales branch of the Labor Party has got itself not only into debt but also technically bankrupt. Its assets are massively outweighed by its liabilities. If that is the way the Labor Party runs its own party, how would it run New South Wales?

We have seen examples in other states of how the Labor Party runs a state. Generally, the word `runs', in the Labor Party sense, means `runs down'. In Western Australia, WA Inc. ran down the state to a situation where significant people—even the former Premier—were indicted, put in gaol and so on.

In Victoria, we saw what Labor running a state meant. It meant the collapse of the state's bank. There were a whole series of financial disasters resulting in the state itself becoming the poor relation of the rest of Australia. Fortunately, Mr Kennett and his Liberal government, in association with the National Party, have been able to rescue Victoria. We have seen a similar disaster in South Australia.

Let us see how much of this financial incompetence—and, one must say, regrettably in some instances evident financial dishonesty—directly relates to New South Wales. At the moment the New South Wales Labor Party owns a building which is worth only a fraction of what it paid for it. As a result, the New South Wales Labor Party is hugely in debt—some $10 million—of which more than half is owed to the Commonwealth Bank, the people's bank.

One can wonder why on earth the Commonwealth Bank became the lender of so much money to such an incompetent crew. One wonders how it is that this bankrupt organisation, the Labor Party in New South Wales, can be financing the biggest advertising campaign that has ever been seen in a state election in New South Wales. It is outspending the Liberal Party enormously. It appears to have a dominance of television commercials of something like seven to one on my quick count last night. Whatever it is, there is no dispute about the fact that the Labor Party is massively outspending the Liberal party and it appears to be able to spend something like $4 million on advertising alone apart from all its other costs.

The federal Labor Party president, Mr Jones, let it slip that the federal body of the Labor Party was thinking of intervening in New South Wales. I understand it has already put up about $1 million to help the state out, but there is the suggestion of intervention which Mr Jones has since resiled from by saying that when he said `intervention' he did not mean intervention; he meant intervention. To what extent this means taking over the state or simply trying to bail it out is a matter that will be found out on 31 March—conveniently just after the New South Wales state election.

A whole series of questions is now emerging that, quite frankly, the Labor Party must answer if it is to have any credibility at all in New South Wales. At the moment all that happens whenever this matter is raised, as it has been by the media, particularly by Mr Alan Ramsey who wrote a very interesting article in Saturday's Sydney Morning Herald, is that the Labor Party says, `That is just an organisational matter. The fact that we cannot run ourselves has nothing to do with our incompetence and inability to run New South Wales.' That is the Labor Party's response. Until it answers these questions, the Labor Party in New South Wales should not be trusted with pocket money, let alone the treasury of the state.

What we have to ask—and I think we have a right to ask—is: what deals have been done to stop the Commonwealth Bank foreclosing on Labor over its debt in New South Wales? I do not know what has been done. All I do know is that the Commonwealth Bank has foreclosed on many people in New South Wales who seem to have a far better debt to asset relationship than the New South Wales Labor Party, but it has not foreclosed on the Labor Party.

The other question is: how will Labor keep financing its rising debt? How is it paying the $10,000 a week interest bill on its debt—over half a million dollars a year? Where is the money coming from? If the Labor Party will not tell you where the money is coming from to pay the interest on its own debt, you can ask: where is the money coming from to pay for its political promises? It will not tell you that either.

I submit the reason the Labor Party will not tell you where the money is coming from to pay its interest bill on its huge debt is, quite frankly, that it would be very embarrassed to reveal the sources of that money. Maybe we could look at some sources of funds that have been revealed in the Courier-Mail recently to examine that. I will deal with that if I have time on another occasion. How is the Labor Party financing this huge $10,000 a week? It will not tell you because it would be far too politically embarrassing to reveal it.

Where is the money coming from to fund Labor's election campaign which includes, as I said earlier, something like $4 million in advertising expenditure? How can the Labor Party get that sort of money? Is the Commonwealth Bank funding its overdraft even though the Labor Party is technically bankrupt?

Where on earth will this kind of expenditure, only part of which will be refunded by the state for electoral funding, come from? Will it come from the union movement? Let me remind the Senate that the union movement is owed about $2 million in New South Wales in back rent by the Labor Party. Is the union movement prepared to forgo what it is owed and put even more money into this bottomless pit in New South Wales? This incompetent bunch could not run a lolly shop. I say that because, according to the way in which New South Wales Labor governments have been run in the past, they have regarded government as a sort of lolly shop where you get your lollies while you can. This is what intrigues me.

If the Labor Party has been able to avoid foreclosure because the Commonwealth Bank says, `Look, we'll wait till after the election,' what is it that would prompt the Commonwealth Bank to think that a New South Wales Labor government would somehow significantly change the financial capacity of the New South Wales Labor Party to pay off its huge interest bill and pay off its debt? Why would this magically happen? Why would an election win mean that all of a sudden the Commonwealth Bank's losing investment in Labor could be paid off?

It seems to me that there is no honest reason whatsoever why Labor coming into power in New South Wales, if such a terrible thing were to happen, would mean that it would suddenly be able to pay off its huge debt and emerge from its technical bankruptcy. I presume that the Commonwealth Bank must take the view that it expects the Carr government to be like the previous Labor governments in New South Wales—back to the good old days of graft, corruption and lolly shop mentality. The ALP will be able to make enough out of being in government to pay off the debt. Otherwise, why is the Commonwealth Bank giving the Labor Party this special benefit that it does not seem to give so many other debtors?

We can also ask quite reasonably whether or not the particular style of the classic New South Wales right wing, which would dominate any Labor government if people in New South Wales were unfortunate enough to end up with one next Saturday, has already been foreshadowed. I refer to the way a Labor government `will hand over the Sydney Showground to Mr Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation for a planned film studio complex without a formal tender'—that is, if it wins Saturday's election. The New South Wales Labor Party spokesman on finance, Mr Michael Egan, said at the weekend:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Labor Party did not believe it was proper or necessary to have a formal tender. A Labor Government would negotiate directly with News Corporation to ensure the film studio complex was built on the Showground site.

The fact is that other people are interested in that site, but the traditional way that the Labor Party in New South Wales does deals is with a mate, and one way or another some benefit to the Labor Party emerges out of that deal. Is this the sort of deal that the Commonwealth Bank has in mind when it thinks that it might be able to resolve the loss that is staring it in the face if the Labor Party is to win the next election? I am overjoyed to see the editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald today, which reads:

The Treasurer and Arts Minister, Mr Peter Collins, is right to reject the private threat from Fox Filmed Entertainment (a wholly owned subsidiary of Mr Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation) that it could move its planned film studio from Sydney to Melbourne if the State Government insists on retaining the tendering process.
It goes on to say:

PARA.TAB: Mr Collins . . . while continuing to insist on the proper tendering process, has put his finger on the necessity for such a process to be observed:

SPEECH.PARA: He states:
Secret deals were the very thing that brought Western Australia and Victoria to its knees under the administrations of Labor Governments.

Exactly the same sort of deal that bankrupted those states would be imposed on New South Wales if the bankrupt state ALP were to get its hands on the lolly jar. I can understand why the Commonwealth Bank is prepared to let the New South Wales Labor Party maintain its huge indebtedness until after the election.

PARA.TAB: One wonders in that context what the Labor Party would do about the Sydney casino. What sort of secret deal would it come to in that situation? We have, in fact, a clear warning to the people of New South Wales. If they want to go back to the days of those secret deals—particularly secret deals, I might say, in this instance; both of those things I have mentioned could bear some relationship with media proprietors—and I do not believe they do, then clearly to get that they would vote Labor.

It is interesting that the Labor Party's subsidiary company, Labor Centenary House Pty Ltd, has not yet lodged its annual return. The latest on record is for 1993. There is no annual return for 1994. It is in breach, yet again, of Australian Securities Commission requirements. It breaks the law. It does not pay its bills. It does secret deals. That is what the Labor Party in New South Wales is all about. That is the party that, frankly, has no credibility, particularly when it is outspending the Liberal and National coalition in New South Wales in this election campaign.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today is the International Day Against Race Discrimination. In view of the tirade we had from Senator Bolkus just before 12 o'clock in which he accused honourable senators on this side of being racists and all sorts of things, I thought it might be appropriate to examine the government's credibility on the issue of race discrimination.

PARA.TAB: Race discrimination is not combated by what you say so much as how you behave yourself. I want to tell the Senate today how the Labor Party tells the ethnic community of this country one thing in relation to a commitment to do away with race discrimination but then quite happily tolerates behaviour by members of its parliamentary party which is quite contrary to the standard it would have the ethnic community believe it supports. In other words, the Labor Party is hypocritical when it comes to the issue of race discrimination.

The evidence I wish to present to the Senate is contained in a radio interview conducted on 6PR on 10 March this year in which a Labor senator alleged that there was some dark, sinister conspiracy between the Liberal and National parties, the National Civic Council, the refugee associations and the legal profession to populate northern Australia with Asians. This ludicrous nonsense—it is quite simply ludicrous nonsense—is part of a long-running saga in which this senator has shown himself incapable of examining issues of migration with an open mind. I will read to the Senate portions of this interview that demonstrate the point that the Labor Party is quite happy to tolerate less than satisfactory behaviour from its own people. The senator in question, when speaking in relation to Migration Amendment Bill (No. 4), said to the interviewer:

SPEECH.PARA: But behind all this Rob is the hidden agenda of that very secret of organisations the National Civic Council, who want to populate the northern end of Australia.
The interviewer, Mr Broadfield, said:
I'm sorry.
And the Labor senator continued:

No accident that the NCC have infiltrated and influenced a number of refugee support groups around Australia, so much so that there are some of those groups now who do not even talk about refugees any more, they only talk about asylum seekers.
Mr Broadfield, quite puzzled, said:
Now the National Civil Council, Bob Santamaria's mob, as most Australians would know it, you are saying what, he's in league with the Opposition now?
The Labor senator said:
No, no, no I'm saying that the NCC have infiltrated political parties, refugee support groups and others in our community. . .
Mr Broadfield interrupted and said:
To what end?
This particular senator, so full of himself, continued to say:
. . . legal profession.
Mr Broadfield said:
No, but to what end, for what purpose?
The Labor senator said:
To populate the northern end of Australia.
Mr Broadfield questioned him and said:
With Asians?
And the Labor senator said:
With—
and he was going to say `with Asians' but he changed his mind and said:

With, to populate the northern end of Australia, to take the pressures off countries in the Asian region which they say are over-populated. Now it's not by accident that we've got the full-time secretary of the NCC in Western Australia, Mr Richard Egan, who is also the secretary of the WA representative of the Indo-China Refugee Association.

This must be the most disturbing manifestation of a psychological disorder that I could possibly imagine. If it is not a disturbing manifestation of a psychological disorder, then it is quite clearly the case that what we have is a Labor Party that is doing this sort of thing for deliberate political purposes.
