In other words, it is trying to whip up a little bit of anti-Asian sentiment in Western Australia for its own political purposes, yet it comes to this parliament and berates the coalition and says that the coalition is not fair dinkum about race relations in this country and that the coalition does not understand the issue of race.

PARA.TAB: I understand the issue of race and my colleague in the Liberal Party Senator Abetz understands the issue of race because we live with it every day. The sanctimonious piffle with which we are bombarded is quite simply offensive, but it is something with which we have to live. But when the sanctimonious piffle from the other side of the chamber is accompanied by this sort of crass paranoid delusion, it is quite clear that the Labor Party, in attempting to get the ethnic vote in this country by spreading dishonest statements about the coalition in relation to ethnic affairs, is totally and utterly hypocritical. No honourable senator could defend the behaviour which I have just outlined to the Senate. No honourable senator could come into this chamber and say that that sort of speech was anything other than a crude attempt, the very crudest of attempts, to whip up the old fear of the yellow peril.

Is it not interesting that there are a lot of people who have come to this country on boats? Not all of those people who have come to this country on boats have come here from South-East Asia. Is it not interesting that some of the people who have come to this country on boats as economic refugees now love to point the finger at another group of people who come to this country on boats, simply by virtue of their race?

What honourable senators on this side of the chamber say—I know Senator Abetz shares my views entirely in relation to refugees—is that this country has a right to determine who is entitled to be a refugee and otherwise. We have real concerns that this country should not be flooded with refugees, but we also accept that there are certain people who have such real and well-founded fears of persecution—the committee on which Senator Abetz and I sat heard evidence of that—that they should not be automatically precluded from a right to at least have their case heard as to whether they are refugees.

Certainly, people who are faced with the threat of forced sterilisation, who are faced with the threat of forced abortion and who are faced with the threat that, if they are returned to the People's Republic of China and deliver a baby it will become a victim of infanticide, have a reasonable case for their claim to be heard and properly determined. That is all Senator Abetz and I say: they should have their case properly heard and determined. But, for some reason, the Labor Party is quite happy to allow this sort of bigoted opinion to be aired on the national airwaves. For what purpose? For what good? I do not know. I cannot see any good in any honourable senator whipping up the old yellow peril argument: when you get into trouble, say that we are going to be deluged with hundreds of thousands of Asians. It always makes good copy.

Unfortunately, I am one of the Asians in this country whose family has had an association with Australia that goes back to 1888. Our family has made over 100 years of contribution to this nation. The suggestion that somehow the Asians are here to rape and pillage this country is to me, and to the entire Asian community in this country of Australia, offensive, disgusting and is designed to lower the standing of the Asian community.

The Asian community in this country is united in one thing. There are ethnic, religious and geographical differences, but the Asian community is united in a desire to see a better future for their children as Australians than they would have had had they grown up in another place. That means a real commitment, a deep down commitment, to the betterment of Australia and to an acceptance of their role as Australians first and foremost in order to achieve that.

This sort of behaviour from the Labor senator in question demeans that commitment to Australia at a time when this Labor government is spending millions of dollars to encourage people to become Australian citizens. I think a fair few people in the Asian community in this country would say, `Why bother if this is what we are going to be subjected to, if we cannot be judged on our achievements but only on the colour of our skin?' That seems to be all that matters on the other side of the chamber. If this sort of behaviour is tolerated, I say that it is time for the Labor Party to act if it is to have any sense of honour and decency in this matter. It is time for the Labor Party to abandon the mere words and to act to stamp out this intolerance and this blight—not just on its party but on this parliament—that such views are allowed to continue.

I want to reveal here and now the name of the honourable senator on the other side who gave this radio interview. The name of the honourable senator is Senator McKiernan, who happens to be the chairman of the Joint Committee on Migration. These are his balanced, reasoned and rational views.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was he a boat refugee as well?

—I understand Senator McKiernan did come here on a boat. I checked out his maiden speech. He was a #10 migrant to this country. I assume he came here by ship; he may have come here by plane. He made it very clear in his maiden speech that he came here seeking a better life. What is the difference between coming to Australia on a boat from Ireland and coming on a boat from somewhere in South-East Asia? You are entitled to have your case heard. All that we on this side of the chamber ask for is equality and fairness before the law.

PARA.TAB: If the Labor Party is to be taken seriously on the issue of race, Senator McKiernan must resign as chairman of the committee. The Labor Party put him there. If he will not resign, the Labor Party should sack him as chairman of the committee; otherwise the word can go out from here to every ethnic organisation in Australia, to every media outlet in Australia, to every newspaper, to every radio station and to every television station in this country that the Labor Party is not fair dinkum on the issue of race relations. Today is the day on which it can repair this egregious fault. Today, on the International Day of the Elimination of Race Discrimination, it should either sack Senator McKiernan or hang its head in shame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to speak on a matter of public interest. It is Seniors Week in both New South Wales and Victoria. The week of 19 March to 26 March is the week in which we in those two states celebrate with seniors, acknowledge their contribution to our community and make a commitment to the needs of seniors in our community. As I mentioned in the notice of motion this morning, there were 2,109,109 Australians aged 65 years and over as at June 1994. That represents 11.82 per cent of the population.

PARA.TAB: We need to address this issue because, as we will see over the next 35 years, the number of people in that age group will increase to 2.52 million or to over 20 per cent of the population—that is, one in every five people in Australia will be over 65 years of age. Many issues are of great concern to seniors today. Many seniors are pioneers who are actually paving the way for those of us who are going to be in that age group in the 21st century. They are making a mark and making it easier for those of us who will follow.

The issues that concern them are age discrimination in the work force and compulsory retirement on the basis of age; retirement incomes and superannuation; the area of social security—you only have to listen to talkback radio, as I was doing over the weekend, and hear how long people have to hang on to the telephone when they are ringing up the Department of Social Security; health, health funding, health insurance, access to health and waiting lists; community care that enables real choice for older people when they need assistance to either have care in their own homes or live in residential care; those who care for older people, many of whom are old themselves and, in particular, older women; residential accommodation and its funding; and mental health such as the increase in the number of people with dementia and Alzheimer's disease.

As I said, this is a week and a time when we should celebrate and take the opportunity to acknowledge the contribution seniors have made to our great nation. Many of them fought in wars. Many of those gallant young men and young women who gave up their lives and their health to fight for the security of Australia and to fight for the freedoms that we enjoy in Australia and take so much for granted are in their twilight years—the older years of their lives. It is through them that we have this freedom which we so easily and often forget about.

We also acknowledge the contribution that they have made through their participation in the paid work force. Many of them are working now in their 60s, 70s and 80s. In fact, I met a man the other day who said to me that he had just retired from his butcher shop at 86 and that he was missing the contact with his customers. So many of them are working and contributing to our community at what many would have considered some years ago to be a very old age.

Not only are older people in the paid work force, but also they are doing unpaid work as carers of other older people, as carers of grandchildren—and many grandparents now take enormous responsibilities in caring at home for young children whose parents are out working—and as voluntary workers in the community. We see examples over and over again of older people playing their roles in hospitals and community organisations. They also undertake work in respect of interacting in their families. I was talking to a colleague only today—and I will not obviously discuss who it is—who told me what an important role the grandparent had played in a particular issue that faced their family in the last few weeks. Often we forget the role that they play in giving guidance and assistance and sometimes being a linchpin or a conduit between the younger person and their families when communication breaks down.

We find that the government has done much to undermine the certainty and lifestyle of many seniors. In the area of superannuation we have seen continual changing of the goalposts, with complicated and constantly changing sets of rules. There is increasing uncertainty with the compulsory superannuation guarantee charge that there will be adequate superannuation for the majority of Australians. For women, the situation in regard to superannuation is even more grim. It is generally acknowledged that, because of the broken work patterns of women, lower incomes and the effect of taxes and charges on superannuation accounts, many women will be severely disadvantaged in their senior years.
I would like to refer to a poem that Joyce Grenfell once used. I do not know whether I can remember it all, but it read:

SPEECH.PARA: I have joined the old time dance band.
The trouble is that there are too many women over and no gentlemen to spare.
It seems a shame it is not the same, but still it has to be.
Some ladies have to dance together, and one of them is me.

That is a very poignant example of the fact that a significant proportion of people who make up the older population, those over 85, are women. The government has not addressed the issue of women and their particular needs with regard to superannuation retirement incomes. It is a sad reflection on this government that it really has not done enough to address that issue, particularly in respect of the many women born during the baby boom who will come into that age group and who will be faced with inadequate incomes to live out their older lives.

PARA.TAB: The other area in which the government has failed seniors is in regard to the income and assets tests for the assessment of pensions. Time and again in this chamber we have pointed out to the government the inequities associated with the treatment of unrealised capital gains on shares as income for the purpose of assessing the pension. We might have seen a decline in the number of letters coming into our offices from pensioners on this issue because of the state of the share market, but once those shares start to increase again we will start to see a fluctuation in income for pensioners that is totally intolerable. When the value of shares was going up, my colleagues and I received letter after letter from people with a small amount of money, $20,000 or $30,000, in shares pointing out the huge effect that this was having on the flow of their income from fortnight to fortnight.

The coalition has said that in government it will rescind that unfair legislation. The government was forced into an inquiry. Although the inquiry has been undertaken, we have yet to see a proper response or any action from the government. Pensioners are still waiting, and I still get letters asking what the government is going to do about it.

The government has failed older people in another area. We have had report after report—the Gregory report and a number of others—talking about the inadequacies in the funding for nursing homes and hostels. The government has failed to address that.

There has also been a failure by the government to address the needs of older people with dementia. Various groups are coming together and saying to the government, `It is intolerable. It is impossible now to run a dementia specific unit. If you run a dementia specific unit, you can do it more cheaply than you can in a nursing home but it is more costly than a hostel.' The government fails to acknowledge that and very few, if any, organisations are now venturing into the area of caring for people with dementia in residential care because it is not financially viable to do so. The government has failed to address that.

Nor has the government addressed the need to have flexible respite care. It is not always appropriate for older people to have respite care in a nursing home or a hostel. Many carers find that it is not worth the effort to get the people for whom they are caring into respite care in a nursing home or hostel because after two or three weeks respite care they have to settle them back into their own environment. It is more than it is worth having the two or three weeks off. Yet we do not see the government addressing creative programs.

I will give you an example. Aged Cottage Homes Inc. in South Australia runs a program which was triggered off and seeded by a donation of something like, I think, $250,000. This organisation has 600 volunteers providing respite care. That respite care is designed to meet the needs of the individual. We should not try to squeeze the individual into the program. What should happen is that the program is designed to meet the needs of the individual.

If a person who has dementia used to like to go fishing at Victor Harbour, then what that organisation might do is find a volunteer or a couple who would take the person away to fish at Victor Harbour—back to where he used to go when he was younger. Some of the earlier memories of many people who have dementia are much clearer and they are not as confused if they go to somewhere they know. People do not see that they have failed by having to say, `My husband or my wife is in residential care while I go on holidays.' They can say, `I have never liked fishing. My husband has gone fishing,' so they do not perceive themselves as having failed.

The carers may take the couple away together. What they do is tailor the respite care to meet the needs of the individual. They are the sorts of programs that we ought to be seeing assisted and funded by the government programs. The programs should be flexible and meet the needs of individuals, not programs into which individuals are squeezed.

We have had report after report on the HACC program and the need for review. Some of the COAG meetings and the meetings of relevant ministers have pointed out the need to actually reduce the overlap. I think Mrs Tehan, the Victorian Minister for Health Services, told me that there are 39 various programs in the home and community care program. Because of the lack of case management, an overriding organisation and good cooperation between the state and federal governments, we find that people are falling between two stools. What we need to ensure is that the service is not there for the bureaucrats, for the service providers and for the state or federal governments, but that it is there for the individuals who need the care.

As I said before, one of the things that older people face is age discrimination. We have compulsory retirement. The government has done nothing. Mr Connolly and I have introduced private members' bills into the parliament to eliminate age discrimination in the Commonwealth Public Service. Nothing has been done about it. Why should we fix the retirement age at a particular age? It makes no sense and makes no allowance for individual differences in fitness or capacity in older people. The government has been very tardy in addressing this issue.

The other thing the government has been tardy in addressing is the issue of age discrimination. We constantly hear how it is hot shot on women's issues, but where is it when it comes to age discrimination? When I was teaching at the Lincoln Institute I remember seeing an advertisement for furniture which showed an older lady sitting in a four-sided structure drinking a cup of tea. The bottom of the ad said, `Make a playpen for your grandma out of this modular furniture.'

If you go through advertising material, you can often find such age discrimination. Fortunately, it is being reduced. My students wrote quite a heated letter to the people who put in that advertisement. You can still see discrimination in the media in particular, and also in government policy, where older people are portrayed as being dependent, frail, inflexible, passive, unproductive, mentally deteriorating or even needing institutionalisation. Now that is not—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commence my comments by simply congratulating Senator Patterson on her very genuine approach to the topic that she just spoke about. In this matters of public interest debate I want to give recognition to the fact that today is the International Day for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination. This international day was agreed to in 1966 pursuant to resolution No. 2142 of the 21st session of the General Assembly of the United Nations. Australia voted for that resolution. It is noteworthy that at that time it was a Liberal-National government which controlled our vote at the United Nations for the purposes of designating today as the International Day for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination.

PARA.TAB: When we look at placitum (xxvi) of section 51 of our constitution, we note that in 1967 an amendment was made deleting the words `other than the aboriginal race in any State'. In other words, the Aboriginal people were incorporated into the Commonwealth constitution—once again another initiative of the Liberal side of politics. That referendum won the overwhelming support of the Australian people.

Given the earlier debate in the Senate today, it is with a note of sadness that I feel it necessary to get up and talk on the International Day for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination. In the past there has been what I consider to be a fairly bipartisan approach, as was taken with this amendment to our constitution to give Aboriginal people the same status as those of us who have a different coloured pigment in our skins or lack pigment in our skins. It is important to note that the Liberal Party has a very strong and proud tradition in this area.

We were submitted to some revisionist history earlier today by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus), who suggested that it was a former Labor minister who had, in effect, got rid of the White Australia policy. It is worthy to note that the current Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was a great supporter of a former premier of New South Wales, Jack Lang. The current Prime Minister moved within the New South Wales division of the Labor Party to allow Jack Lang's membership to be reinstated. Indeed, the Prime Minister comments about the fact that he sat at the feet of Jack Lang and that Jack Lang had a great impact on his life.

Let us look at Jack Lang's policies. They were unashamedly supportive of the then White Australia policy. Also, Mr Lang was, on any interpretation of the events, anti-semitic. He was concerned about the role that the Jewish community allegedly played in the black market. He sought to paint all Jews with a particular brush.

Today Senator O'Chee has highlighted another example of the departure from what I would have hoped would have been a bipartisan approach to these important issues of tolerance and elimination of racial discrimination. It saddens me greatly that the Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration should say in a media release:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia could become flooded with hundreds of thousands of boat people from China and . . . other Asian countries.

That was in relation to a bill that was once before us, but is now no longer before us. It has been withdrawn and, undoubtedly, will surface again here later on in a slightly different form. That legislation seeks to talk about the fertility control policies of countries. Another subclause says that, for the purposes of this legislation, the fertility control policy of China is considered to be one such example.

PARA.TAB: Why did Senator McKiernan find it necessary to talk about hundreds of thousands of boat people from China and some other Asian countries? The legislation, as I understood it, was not designed to victimise Chinese and Asians; it was designed, allegedly, to be a response to a perceived problem as to what might happen with fertility control policies being used for certain purposes. Why the need to refer to Chinese and Asians? Why could he not have just said, `This is designed to stop people from using the fertility control policies in their countries'? But no, he had to pick on Chinese and other Asians.

One really has to look behind the mentality that would allow a senator to make those sorts of comments. Clearly, lying behind that is a thought process which is not necessarily in tune with a concept of elimination of racial discrimination. I found that comment by Senator McKiernan, the chairman of the committee, particularly unfortunate and unhelpful.

The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs sought to impute improper motives to the opposition when we sought earlier today to delay—for only some seven days—the discussion of a bill so that we could consider it. He sought to claim that the Labor Party was the champion of abolishing racial discrimination. Given the few examples that I have just mentioned—the Prime Minister's wholesale embrace of Jack Lang with his outrageous racial policies and the Labor Party's current embrace of Senator Jim McKiernan as chairman of that important committee—I would have thought the Labor Party would be the last party to stand up and give a patronising lecture to people on the opposition side about their attitude to ethnic groups within this country.

Senator O'Chee is an Australian by birth, but he has certain physical characteristics that clearly indicate he has a heritage other than Anglo-Saxon. The National Party found no hindrance in endorsing him for a safe Senate seat—indeed, a casual vacancy; a guaranteed introduction to the Senate. I was not born in Australia. By looking at me you would not necessarily be able to tell that I was not born in Australia, because I do not have the distinguishing features that Senator O'Chee does, but the `z' in my surname gives it away. Most people would say, `Well, that is a foreign name. Where's it from? What's your heritage?' A lot of people ask me that question.

The Liberal Party in my state found no difficulty in endorsing me—once again, for a casual vacancy—for straight entrance into the Senate to represent the people of Tasmania and to be a representative of the Liberal Party. The Liberal Party has had a very proud tradition of supporting the ethnic communities, working with them, endorsing them and having them sit in this chamber and in other houses all around this country. It really does ill-behove the minister and the Australian Labor Party to try to score points off the opposition by saying that somehow they are better managers of the ethnic groups within Australia.

I used an analogy once and I will repeat it here. Whilst there is a lot of talk within the community about Australia being a multicultural nation, my view is that we are drawn from a lot of different backgrounds, but it is like a good curry—that is, there are a whole lot of different herbs and spices mixed into one, but you do not give preference to one particular herb or spice. It is described as a curry and it is the full flavour of all the different components that gives the food a distinct flavour.

It is in Australia today that Australian culture has a distinct flavour because of the Chinese contribution, the German contribution, the Dutch contribution, the Asian contribution and, above all, the English contribution which has had such a very significant impact on our country and on the formation of this parliament and the way our legal system operates. I believe that all the ethnic communities working together can achieve a result which will make Australia a standard bearer in the rest of the world in our approach to the intermingling of the different races.

Therefore, it is sad that on this the International Day for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination we had to suffer the sort of commentary we heard from the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I would have thought that if there was one thing a minister for immigration ought to be seeking to do, it would be to bring about harmony within the portfolio of immigration between the different ethnic communities and, above all, to get a bipartisan approach to the question of any legislation that is required to deal with migration and matters such as racial hatred.

There is no-one on this side of the house who would in any way condone racial discrimination or racial hatred. The rally in Melbourne that we saw on our TVs over the weekend is an event that deeply disturbs every decent thinking Australian—to think that people would hold those views. However, we on this side of the house take the view that no matter how obnoxious those views are, people ought to be allowed, in general terms, to express them. Nevertheless, we will work without ceasing to ensure that there is, within the community of Australia, an acceptance of all the different racial groups as full Australians and as a part of mainstream Australia without trying to marginalise them by treating them the way the minister has.

Today is the International Day for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination and I believe that Australia has already come a long way in achieving that as a result of the golden age of Australian politics, which was the Liberal era under Robert Menzies, John Gorton, Harold Holt and Billy McMahon.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I remind the minister that Labor Party President and member for Lalor, Barry Jones, has had the guts to admit that there was not a secret deal between Mr Howard and Mr Packer over changes to cross-media rules. Mr Jones has confirmed that there was no deal. Why shouldn't Mr Keating be brought to account for his lies and attempted character assassination and be forced to resign? Why shouldn't the same standards be applied to Mr Keating as he would seek to apply to others?

—Mr Jones also had the good sense to acknowledge that he did not know what he was talking about on that or, indeed, on anything else that he opened his mouth about in that unfortunate interview on Sunday. The truth of the matter is that Mr Jones is not in a position to know what the nature of any information that was held privily by the Prime Minister might be about this extremely sensitive matter. The truth of the matter is, as I have said on innumerable occasions, that the evidence for that belief on the part of the Prime Minister does not need anything more than the public record to substantiate it—a public record which amply demonstrates that, save and except for that little time in 1991 when Mr Howard was doing a deal of a different kind with another media proprietor, there has been absolute consistency of approach on the part of Mr Howard about his belief that the present cross-media rules are inadequate, inappropriate, in need of review and in need of amendment.

PARA.TAB: There is also on the public record a very clear statement by Mr Howard and various of his acolytes about the necessity for the Trade Practices Act to possibly have a role in that particular area as the appropriate way of dealing with any monopolisation that might exist. There is also on the public record, however, clear statements from the Trade Practices Commissioner, Professor Fels, that the Trade Practices Act has no such potential application, because you are talking about different markets.

You have also had on the public record an absolute unwillingness on the part of Mr Howard over and over again to respond to specific questions about what the nature of his policy commitments will be and what he will do in fact in practice. You have had a failure to produce any such policy, of course, and there will continue to be such a failure all the way through until the next election. You are talking about someone here on the opposition side without any shred of credibility at all on that particular issue and the government's case stands very firmly in the way that it has been put.

TALK.START.PARA: —Barry Jones, for his honesty, has now been bucketed by the minister—I would have thought that there would have been some sense of loyalty to his party president—whilst the minister continues this farce of arguing that the secret evidence for a secret deal is in fact on the public record. What are these extra matters that you say that the Prime Minister holds privily? What is this extra evidence that we do not know of? If he is not prepared to put up that evidence, why shouldn't we assume—as did Barry Jones—that he in fact lied to the Australian people? Why shouldn't he resign?

—The President of the ALP, Barry Jones, made no such assumption and no such statement; he just expressed his own rather idiosyncratic view of the circumstances of the particular occasion, not a view that was conceivably based on any information at all. The situation is as I have described. Mr Keating is not in a position, Mr Lee is not in a position and I am not in a position obviously to disclose sources that do not want to reveal themselves.

PARA.TAB: But you do not need sources to make the point that what we have on the opposition side is a squalid willingness to trade in a way that is seen by the opposition as politically advantageous and beneficial. That is what we have on the other side of politics and you ought to be ashamed of that. You ought to be ashamed of your utter incapacity and unwillingness to be frank and honest with the Australian people about what your media policy is. Your media policy is one that would clearly accommodate a major proprietor in print having a major interest in a major television network in the same city. That is what you have said and you have not denied it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery of a parliamentary delegation from the Russian state duma led by the Deputy Chairman of the state duma, Mr Aleksandr Vengerovsky. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate and trust that your visit will be both informative and enjoyable.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. What are the implications of the High Court decision last week for the future of the native title legislation? What is the government's reaction to the statement by the Western Australian Premier that he will continue to fight against that legislation? Will the government accept the opposition leader's proposal to make the legislation more workable?

—The High Court decision on Mabo and the Native Title Act is a complete and absolute vindication of the stance the Commonwealth government has taken on the constitutionality of our legislation as well as on the principles of justice which underlie that legislation. It is now open to the Western Australian government to come on board and cooperate as other states and territories are doing in putting together a sensible and equitable regime for providing justice for the first time to Aboriginal Australians.

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth is certainly concerned about the uncertainty relating to the new titles issued in Western Australia since 1993. Premier Court has deliberately ignored the processes that were set down in the Native Title Act. He has to take ultimate responsibility for the effect of his decision in Western Australia. He has to take responsibility for the waste of at least $4 million of taxpayers' money and for the uncertainty that now surrounds some thousands of titles that have been issued since 1993. The uncertainty, such as it is in Western Australia, is wholly of that state government's doing—and it is up to it to decide how best to fix the mess it has created. We are nevertheless prepared to work with the Western Australian government to ensure that issues arising from this decision can be addressed cooperatively. Preliminary talks have already been held at ministerial level with the Court government and further discussion at both official and ministerial level will obviously be needed.

Mr Howard tells us that the act needs to be made more workable. He has not given us any information about the respects in which it needs to be made more workable except to say that he will respond appropriately to the responsibilities and interests of the states in this respect. There was not a word about the interests of those whom the legislation is designed to assist. There was not a word about anything other than state interests. That is typical. We do not know what in detail the prescription is going to be because there was not a word said about this in the otherwise extremely lengthy statement on a whole variety of policy issues that was made by Mr Howard to the Liberal state conference over the weekend. This is not an issue on which he feels comfortable. The reason for that is perfectly obvious.

We have no doubt that the Native Title Act is perfectly workable in its present form. Mr Howard's reference, as Michael Lavarch said over the weekend, is simply code for gutting and filleting this legislation as the opposition wanted to do with the land fund act. Perhaps he will get Richard Court to draft the legislative amendments for him.

We have always said that we will see how the provisions of the act operate before we consider any question of amendment, as is normal practice for legislation. It has been in operation for only a year and we will not compromise any of the principles in the act which presents an appropriate balance between competing interests. Any amendments we make will go only to improving procedures under the act and will not affect the spirit of the law. Nor will we accept any prescription from the opposition that goes to the spirit of this law or anything else we have been doing so far as Aboriginal legislation and social justice programs are concerned. The heart of this legislation is the spirit that we understand to be at issue here as far as Aboriginal people are concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Social justice? Look at Aboriginal health, jobs—
—I understand that you do not want to talk about Aboriginal people's interests because you simply do not understand them.
—Order! Address your remarks through the chair.

—You did not understand the issues at stake when you took your opposition to the Mabo legislation; you did not understand them when you played the role you did in opposing the land fund legislation and, when you took the position you did, you certainly did not understand the sensitivities involved of Aboriginal people. Mr Howard continues to support every inch of the way the squalid and tawdry position you took on the Hindmarsh Aboriginal documents affair. You have had three major opportunities to get it right so far as Aboriginal affairs over the last year is concerned—Mabo, the land fund and Hindmarsh. On every one of these occasions you have been wrong. Three strikes and you are out. You have demonstrated an absolute unwillingness to acknowledge the nature of the issues involved. I contrast your stance with that of the CRA. (Time expired)

—My question is also directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I hope that he will at least attempt to be a bit more honest in his answer to this question than he was in his previous answer to Senator Hill. I refer to the sudden, sharp fall in the value of the Australian dollar against the United States dollar and the trade weighted index, which includes most other currencies, including the Japanese yen, against which we have now reached a record low. Has the US merchant bank Goldman Sachs compared the Australian economy with the Mexican economy and predicted a further large fall in the value of the dollar because of the blow-out of the current account deficit expected in the next six months and the government's inability to deliver on its responsible fiscal policy? Does the plummeting value in the dollar and a continuing concern about its prospects greatly increase the likelihood of further interest rate hikes and tax increases once the New South Wales election is out of the way, or will you categorically rule out these increases in interest rates and taxes? (Time expired)

—We are not in the business, as Senator McMullan says, of trawling around every second-rate commentator trying to find skerricks of commentary that drag this country down. We are proud of the economic performance of this country. We are proud of the capacity for sustainable growth that we have now introduced in this country. We are proud of the achievement that we have made so far as employment is concerned, with more than 500,000 jobs having been created over the last two years compared with the promise to do it over three years. That performance is there on the record.

PARA.TAB: I will not comment specifically about the dollar. We never do. I am prepared to concede that the current account deficit at the moment is higher than any of us find comfortable. However, what I am also saying and what this government has been saying since day one is that the government is committed to a significant tightening of fiscal policy in the May budget in order to boost national saving and, as a result, reduce Australia's call on overseas capital. That is the way in which we are going to address the problem of the current account deficit. That will be there for all to see when it comes to this budget in just a few weeks time.

The growth in the Australian economy is perfectly sustainable when you take into account the enormously strong productivity performance that this economy has accumulated. It is sustainable when you take into account the extraordinary low rates of inflation that we have managed to hang on to for three years in a row, with inflation headline rates now running at around 2 1/2 per cent. This is an absolutely extraordinary achievement, not one that has been seen for decades in this country. It is a proud record. The economy is in good shape, and there is no need to act in any other way.

The nonsensical notion that somehow interest rate strategy is being governed, or directed, or somehow influenced by current political events utterly fails to acknowledge the reality that the government does not single-handedly control interest rates even if we were irresponsible enough to want to behave in that way. That is a function of the Reserve Bank's decision making authority, in consultation with the government, but in its own authority and based on its own sense of monetary responsibility. To make the accusation of the kind that you continue to make and have been making over the last few days and weeks is to demonstrate an absolute contemptuous lack of respect for the credibility of those people who make up the Reserve Bank board. The point is that we have a responsible monetary policy. We are determined to put the primary weight of the necessary economic adjustments on fiscal policy for the reasons that I have explained, and we have a sustainable deficit target that will be reached as a result of that budgetary process.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of that totally equivocal non-answer, I ask: just how soon after the New South Wales election will the interest rate hike occur and the increased tax proposals be announced? Will it be late March, or April, or will you perhaps wait until May?

—To ask that question is to demonstrate exactly the kind of irresponsibility that has kept that mob out of government since 1983 and that will continue to keep them out of government for the indefinitely foreseeable future. That is the way you think; that is not the way we think.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. As senators would be aware, the Australian meat and livestock industries have now developed a significant trade in live sheep and carcass meat to the Middle East. A point of concern has been the difficulties that have existed in terms of live sheep trade into the Saudi Arabia market. Can the minister advise the Senate of progress in industry and government negotiations to have that trade recommenced?

—I am pleased to announce that Australia is to recommence the live sheep trade with Saudi Arabia. This is an important development and one that is going to be welcomed by the Australian industry. I certainly know that my colleague the Minister for Trade, Senator McMullan, is also very pleased to see this matter finally resolved.

PARA.TAB: The position follows what has been a very protracted period of discussion between the Australian government and industry and our Saudi counterparts. Over the last few months our ambassador in Saudi has had a series of meetings with the Acting Minister for Agriculture and Water, the deputy minister and other key officials regarding the Saudi requirement for the importation of Australian live sheep. A clear understanding now exists of those requirements.

The Australian industry is confident that it will be able to supply live sheep in full compliance with the tight conditions that have been established. The first shipment is likely to occur early next month. The conditions include strict age requirements, direct shipment to Saudi and the presence of a certified veterinary officer with each shipment.

The decision to reopen this trade is a further economic boost to the rural sector, which is of course still struggling with the severe impacts of the drought. The Middle East meat and livestock trade was valued at about $300 million last year, and this included, importantly, $140 million worth of chilled and frozen sheep meat products. The access to the premium Saudi live sheep market will potentially add another $20 million to the Middle East trade per year.

The Australian government welcomes this significant development that will further build on our already strong bilateral trading relationship with the kingdom of Saudi Arabia. It is yet another example of how the government is working with Australian industry to build a stronger, more diversified and competitive rural sector. The industry and the government will continue to closely monitor this trade to ensure that its long-term development and stability is guaranteed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and concerns his attitude to the powers of approval he has over projects with environmental impacts such as woodchipping and coastal developments. It was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald that he has a submission before cabinet on the use of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act, which has as an option to effectively exempt from environmental assessment all projects that are currently in existence, including those projects that are having a significant effect on the environment. If you were to put that position, does it mean effective abandonment of environmental concerns in approvals for woodchipping licences? Will a similar attitude prevail towards developments for which you have responsibility under other acts, such as the project at Port Hinchinbrook in North Queensland?

—Naturally, I have seen the article in the Sydney Morning Herald on which Senator Kernot has based this particular question. The only thing that is correct in that article is the statement that this government does have a strong stand on environmental issues.

PARA.TAB: While I do not intend today to pre-empt cabinet's discussion on this issue, I do feel that it is important to correct those very misleading reports and allegations about proposed amendments to the administrative procedures under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. Let me say straight up that any changes, any amendments, to the administrative procedures will not affect the objectives of the act. The administrative procedures are subsidiary instruments and can give effect only to the object of the principal act.

I am not proposing any amendments to the act itself. This act is one of the centrepieces of the Commonwealth's environment protection legislation. There is no way that I would put forward any proposal that would undermine the act in any way. The object of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act is to see environmentally significant projects assessed—but assessed only once, unless there is an environmentally significant change in circumstances.

Here, I am responding to the uncertainty that was created by the Gunns decision about the application of the act to ongoing operational decisions. For example, one of the potential consequences is that each individual coal shipment from a coal mine that has been assessed under the act needs to be designated and reassessed. I think nearly everyone would accept that that is undesirable, that it is unworkable and that it is not consistent with the government's understanding and interpretation of the act. It is also contrary to plain, good old-fashioned commonsense.

Mr President, since the Gunns decision the government has overcome these potential operational difficulties through issuing short-term individual exemptions for decisions relating to export approvals. This also is clearly not a satisfactory longer term remedy. The amendments to the administrative procedures which I am proposing will provide a more satisfactory working arrangement and will restore the government's previous understanding of the intent and the scope of this act.

Senators would also be aware that there is a full scale review of the act currently under way. The act has been in place now for over 20 years and it needs to be brought up to date. The EPA has released a discussion paper which forms the basis of a public consultation process, and that finishes at the end of this month. There is a number of fundamental issues relating to environmental legislation being considered by that review.

I do not propose that the government will make any decisions which might pre-empt the outcome of the review process, and it is not my intention, having said those things which put the government's position clearly on record, to make any more comment prior to the cabinet decision. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, in relation to the last part of my earlier question, which relates to Port Hinchinbrook, are you currently finalising terms of reference for the study assessing the impact on World Heritage values of the next three steps of the Port Hinchinbrook project? Considering what you have just said about assessing things only once, will those terms of reference look at the cumulative environmental impacts of the entire proposal over time, not just each step in isolation? And the same with the aesthetic impacts, will they be looked at over time, cumulatively, not just each step in isolation, in the same way, as I understand it, you are talking about coal shipments?

—In relation to that aspect of Senator Kernot's question, on 22 February I met with the Oyster Point developer, Mr Williams. Officers of my department have also met with Mr Williams. Through those meetings he has been made very well aware of the Commonwealth's position in regard to the proposed development.

PARA.TAB: On 23 February we received from the developer a request for consent to undertake a range of works on the site, including a breakwater, dredging of an access channel, and matters pertaining to the foreshore and the foreshore management plan. Currently, that request is being evaluated.

I have made it clear to Mr Williams and all the other interested parties that my responsibility with regard to this development is to ensure that it does not damage the values of the adjacent World Heritage area. The evaluation of any requests for consent will bear this in mind and we will look at all those issues concurrently.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Indonesian Major-General Sintong Panjaitan: Visit to Australia

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, my question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I ask: one, when did former Indonesian General Sintong Panjaitan arrive in Australia and when is he due to leave; two, on what basis was the former general granted entry to Australia; and, three, how does the government reconcile its high international stand on human rights with its sponsorship of a visit by this general who was so closely linked with the Dili massacre in East Timor in November 1991?

—Major-General Panjaitan has been visiting Australia as a member of an advance party for a planned visit by the Indonesian Minister for Research and Technology, Dr Habibie. He is now the Deputy for Armed Forces Affairs in the Agency for the Assessment and Application of Technology within Minister Habibie's portfolio. It was, of course, in that context that he was visiting Australia.

PARA.TAB: Major-General Panjaitan was the commander of the ninth military district in 1991 and did have overall responsibility for East Timor. He was not in East Timor at the time of the Dili killings on 12 November and there is no evidence that he was personally culpable or responsible in any way for giving the orders in question.

There is no doubt that he was held responsible in the sense that he had to assume the commander's responsibility for the acts of those subordinate to him, which responsibility he did accept. He stood down and was forced to resign from the position in the armed forces that he had previously held. But there is an important moral distinction between the nature of the behaviour and responsibility of someone who was personally involved, and was in that sense culpable, and someone who essentially is formally responsible.

The government certainly had that distinction in mind in deciding, after careful consideration, not to object to his presence in Australia. I hope that it will be seen in that context and not in any way as the government being prepared to acknowledge that somehow the events of Dili were less serious than was previously said, or that the culpability of those directly involved was any less.

I do make the point, finally, however, that it has always been the government's position that a distinction is to be drawn between the events in Dili and those, for example, in Tiananmen in Beijing in 1989. In the Chinese case we clearly and unequivocally had a deliberate act of state policy carried out at the direction and with the knowledge of those at the highest levels of government, as compared with the situation in Dili in 1991, which was clearly aberrant, albeit grossly aberrant, and outrageous behaviour by local military commanders.

I do not have at hand any information as to the precise date of Major-General Panjaitan's arrival in Australia or his intended departure, but it was a relatively short visit for the purpose of setting in place arrangements for the long awaited visit by Minister Habibie.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It is my understanding that Major-General Panjaitan may have left yesterday, in which case I ask why the government did not, as a good international citizen, take any action to collect the $14 million damages awarded by a United States court against Sintong Panjaitan for the murder of a New Zealand citizen in the Dili massacre and whether the government will refuse him a visa for a future visit to Australia. If not, why not?

—As I understand it, a civil liability was recorded in the American courts by way of default judgment in the absence of any attempt by General Panjaitan or the Indonesian government to respond to the plaint. Executions and civil judgment are a matter for civilian plaintiffs to pursue through proper process and it is certainly no responsibility of this government to pursue that matter, even had we some belief in the moral responsibility to do so, which, for all the reasons I have indicated, we do not.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Australian Labor Party: New South Wales Branch

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is it a fact that the New South Wales branch of the ALP, already more than $10 million in debt, has been served or threatened with a notice of foreclosure by the Commonwealth Bank unless it makes suitable arrangements to service the debt? What steps has the bank taken to achieve a reduction of the principal of this massive debt or has it in fact blown out in recent weeks? Will the government obtain an assurance from the managing director of the Commonwealth Bank that the bank is not simply bankrolling a very politically privileged and technically insolvent debtor and that ordinary Australians can expect the same sympathetic overdraft accommodation?

—This is not a matter of Commonwealth government responsibility, my responsibility or the Prime Minister's responsibility. Let me nonetheless make the point that there is substantial mortgage over the property in question belonging to the New South Wales ALP, which is servicing interest on this mortgage at $10,000 per month to the satisfaction of its bankers. There is no substance, to my knowledge, to any suggestion that that debt is about to be called in or is in some other way being pursued in the way that was mentioned.

PARA.TAB: It is, of course, the case that the ALP lost a considerable amount of money on that transaction as a result of the collapse in the Sydney property market. Lots of people lost money in property investments and have been in some financial difficulty as a result of those events. The Premier of New South Wales, John Fahey, knows all about that because he is in charge of the state superannuation scheme which has had a write-down of $1 billion as a result of the collapse of the Sydney property market in the early 1990s. That is $1 billion of taxpayers' money that has been written down as a result of that little exercise in property speculation; $1 billion of taxpayers' money in New South Wales has been put at risk by the property investments of the state superannuation scheme under John Fahey.

If opposition senators do not want to acknowledge any kind of responsibility or any inappropriate behaviour on the part of the government instrumentality under John Fahey in producing that debt, they should not shed crocodile tears in here about the similar problems that the ALP got itself into as a result of that exact situation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that you simply say that the debt is being serviced; in other words, presumably, the principal is not being reduced on a $10 million debt. I ask you further: how many Commonwealth Bank representatives attended the recent $2,000 a plate fund-raiser for the ALP, and how much was contributed on behalf of bank shareholders to ALP funds? Has the ALP overdraft been considered by the board of the Commonwealth Bank and, if not, why not? Seeing you are interested in state politics, I simply ask you to answer the question so eloquently asked by Alan Ramsey in last Saturday's Sydney Morning Herald. He asked:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . how do you convince the voters you know how to run the State if your own party is so demonstrably exposed as having mismanaged itself into insolvency?

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that some parts of that question are very tenuously relevant to the minister's responsibility.

—But it was a lunatic question. I am asked how many Commonwealth Bank shareholders have contributed to ALP funds. Does Senator Alston know how many millions of Commonwealth Bank shareholders there are now? You goose!

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. Obviously, the minister did not want to hear the question. I asked: how many Commonwealth Bank representatives attended the recent $2,000 a plate ALP fund-raiser, and how much was contributed on behalf of bank shareholders?
—Senator Alston, that is not a point of order.
—It is, Mr President. It is precisely to do with relevance.
—Senator Alston, be seated. It is not a point of order and you well know it. I call Senator Evans.

—Mr President, on a point of order. You say that I know it is not a point of other. The fact is that Senator Evans himself would concede that he was answering a question he thought related to how many Commonwealth Bank shareholders have contributed.
—It is not a point of order.
—I am simply saying, on the question of relevance, that my question asked how much money was contributed on behalf of shareholders. I would have thought that that was a pretty simple proposition.
—That is clearly not a point of order.

—It is a distinction without a difference: how much was contributed on behalf of the millions of Commonwealth Bank shareholders. You goose! You would not know the difference. The mortgage debt of the ALP is not $10 million; it is $6 million. The New South Wales ALP has committed to pay off, and will pay off, every cent of the amount owing under the mortgage, capital and interest. We will do this in close consultation with the branch, as is necessary with anyone else. That is the way it will be, and you can eat your rotten little heart out.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. Can the minister inform the Senate of the truth behind the New South Wales Premier's promise during his campaign launch to provide an extra 26,000 places under the national child care strategy? Has the New South Wales government contacted the federal government about this issue? Given that the national child care strategy is a joint funding agreement, what does this mean for the Premier's promise?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like anyone involved in child care, I was astounded by the Premier's announcement that he would provide an extra 26,000 child care places. Mr Fahey knows full well that he has made a promise that he cannot keep. He simply cannot provide those extra child care places, and the reason comes from his own mouth.

PARA.TAB: The Premier, Mr Fahey, said that the cost of these 26,000 places would be about $116 million in one year and the liability for the state would be about $58 million. What this means is that $60 million of that liability would be the Commonwealth's. So Premier Fahey is making a promise to the New South Wales people that is contingent on this Commonwealth finding $60 million recurrent each year for child care when he has not even signed the national child-care strategy for the last five years. It is pretty bold of the Premier to go around promising to spend Commonwealth money—$60 million of it recurrent each year—when he has not been prepared to sign the national child-care strategy for the last five years. It is very interesting indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —This will really turn the polls around, this answer.
—I am very glad Senator Macdonald interjects. Francis McGuire, director of Community Childcare—a peak child-care organisation in New South Wales—has this to say about Mr Fahey's promise:

ANSWER.PARA: Now that they [the Liberals] are facing an election and realise that their track record for provision of childcare is really poor, they're making these outrageous claims . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —What has this to do with federal politics?
—He continues:

ANSWER.PARA: It's just appalling that the Liberal Party has made this announcement knowing that the bulk of people aren't involved with the setting up of childcare places, and they think that they can get away with it, they can make these statements of 26,000 places to be set up, and if they're not it's the Commonwealth's fault and think that people will believe them. I think that's criminal.

I heard somebody over there interject, `What's this got to do with the Commonwealth?' It has everything to do with it. Premier Fahey is not prepared to sign the Commonwealth-state child-care strategy. He has certainly not contacted me about doubling the number of child-care places from 13,000 to 26,000 in one week. He is doing this dependent and contingent upon finding Commonwealth recurrent money of $60 million.

PARA.TAB: Mr Fahey has made a number of blunders about child care. In fact, he had to backtrack and apologise for what he got wrong last week. I ask senators why he is proposing this idea of 26,000 places. It is because this issue is about to be something that matters to the people in New South Wales. They have been duded of over 8,000 places over the last five years because the New South Wales government has refused to sign this strategy. Now, on the eve of an election, not only is the Premier promising the heavens but he is promising to spend $60 million of Commonwealth money recurrent each year. That is a promise he knows that he cannot make. He is just not serious about this issue. He has ratted on families in New South Wales, and he has certainly betrayed the women.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Would the minister explain to the Senate why crucial decisions on national issues have been delayed until after 25 March? I refer specifically to the holding off of the inevitable next round of interest rate rises, the outrageous federal cabinet move to block the release of 33 forest areas for logging in New South Wales, singling out just New South Wales, and the delay in the planned massive increase in flights from 60 to 80 movements an hour at Sydney airport. Is it not the case, minister, that your government has delayed and distorted public policy in this country just to help your mates in their attempt to win the New South Wales election?

—That is an extremely vulgar suggestion from Senator Tierney, and it is utterly without any foundation. I have already responded on the subject of interest rate rises. This is not a government that responds irresponsibly to the needs of this country for responsible economic management. If the Reserve Bank, in consultation with the government, decides that it is not appropriate to raise interest rates at this time, that is the decision of the Reserve Bank and that is one that we will readily accept because of course we would prefer that the economy is managed without the need to go back to further interest rate rises. Of course, we would all like to see any necessary policy adjustments being able to be managed by fiscal policy alone. That has been our position for umpteen months and that remains the position irrespective of the transient fortunes of the political timetable in New South Wales.

PARA.TAB: So far as the woodchips decision is concerned, we made it clear some weeks ago that an extensive process of consultation was going to be necessary in order to make judgments about the status of those outstanding coupes. The timetable was set weeks ago to enable that process to properly take place.

So far as New South Wales is concerned, it has already been explained to those opposite in words of one syllable, and it needs to be in one syllable for Senator Tierney, that particular coupes were not handed back in New South Wales simply because insufficient information was given to us by that government of yours in New South Wales, that brilliant government of yours, which was utterly incapable—not incapable; it was unwilling—of giving us information on which we could make a reasonable judgment about the extent to which those values were in fact represented elsewhere in the state.

If that information had been forthcoming in some credible or useful way from that incredible and useless government in New South Wales it might have been possible for us to produce a decision much earlier. That is the state of play on every one of the issues that you raised. There is no attempt to avoid dealing with these issues. We are a government that is responsible, measured, balanced, sensible and credible in the way in which we approach these issues and we will continue to be so.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Are media reports correct that New South Wales is in danger of losing the substantial investment in film making facilities proposed by Fox and announced by the Prime Minister in Creative Nation? If these reports are correct, what appears to be the problem? What is necessary to ensure that Australia realises the significant opportunities that would flow from this proposed investment?

—I am, of course, aware that the proposal to build an international film studio in Sydney—which was initiated not by the Fahey Liberal government, it did not have anything to do with starting the proposal, but by 20th Century Fox—is in some doubt and as a consequence there is a concern that millions of dollars of investment in the film industry and all that that entails in terms of creative opportunities, infrastructure opportunities and job opportunities for Australians might be lost to Sydney. Senators would be interested in the history.

PARA.TAB: The proposal was first announced by the Prime Minister in Creative Nation in October of last year. The Prime Minister said at the time that the Fox proposal would need to be discussed with the New South Wales state government—this gave us some cause for apprehension because we did not know whether it would ever go ahead; nothing goes ahead once the hand of the New South Wales government gets on it—which owns the proposed site, the Sydney showgrounds. Given the importance and significance of this proposal, the Prime Minister was quick to commit the Commonwealth government to assisting with site development preparation.

It was interesting to hear twice today Liberal senators from New South Wales contend that sleazy deals are involved in coming to an agreement of exactly the sort that Mr Kennett has proposed. I do not think that is a reasonable criticism of Mr Kennett or any of the other states that would love to have the opportunity to have this investment. But rather than grab this initiative which the Commonwealth made possible, the Fahey government decided not to negotiate with Fox but to invite competitive expressions of interest to implement an idea that somebody brought forward.

This is a very difficult prospect for people who have been in opposition for a long time to understand. Obviously, the originators of the idea would not be encouraged to come to the state with ideas if all their ideas are going to be held up for tender and their competitors can come in and bid for their ideas. Obviously, Mr Kennett understands that this is not a proposal that would be attractive to anybody wishing to make a serious investment. He has come forward and sought to steal this project out from under the nose of New South Wales, putting at risk the possibility that Sydney and New South Wales might gain significant employment, investment and creative opportunities.

It is not a question of this being a terrible Labor attack on the Liberals because Mr Kennett is an equally enthusiastic Liberal. He is putting forward this proposal and he wants to attract this proposal to Victoria. This is not inconsistent with the experience of every minister who has ever had to deal with a proposal that requires cooperative proposals from a state. From Queensland, Victoria, South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania you can get an interest, a response and some sort of initiative that leads to a venture proceeding, but if it gets into New South Wales nothing happens. Every time you get a proposal that requires a hand from the New South Wales government, the proposal stalls and stops dead.

It is exactly the same procedure that I have found as trade minister. When people have come in talking about investment proposals in Australia, they come to see us and put forward a proposal. They say, `We wanted to go to New South Wales but we have had a much better proposal from Victoria. So we are proposing to base our investment in Melbourne.'

In the Commonwealth government's own area of initiative, we sought proposals from New South Wales and Victoria because we wanted to spread the proposals between those two cities. The only serious proposal we got was from Melbourne. We have had to commit ourselves to conducting the National Trade and Investment Outlook Conference in Melbourne for the next five years because there was no effective interest from Sydney. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, the also-ran Senator Schacht—I am just quoting media sources. Will the minister rule out leaked Department of Finance budget proposals which would see an end to real growth in Commonwealth funding for non-government schools? Why is the government considering abandoning its election commitment to increase funding to non-government schools and, instead, proposing to slash their funding by $220 million over the next four years?

—To the former failed member for Lowe who could not hold the seat, I just want to say that obviously his question is motivated as being part of his effort to help the New South Wales Liberal Party create a scare campaign. You know as well as I do that it is not the policy of the government to make any comment about speculation on any area in the budget discussions. That does not mean these matters are being considered or not being considered; we just do not comment on them. You know that as well as I do.

—Since the minister is clearly avoiding answering the question, I ask it again. Will he actually rule out the proposal which apparently has the approval of both Treasury and Finance to cut Commonwealth funding for non-government schools? Will he admit that, if implemented, families with two children would actually have to pay more than $500 over the next four years and then, after that, $300 a year? Would this affect 900,000 students from 2,500 schools? Is this not another example of how Labor's l-a-w really spells l-i-e?

—I am astonished that an opposition senator could get up and complain about any suggestion of cutting education expenditure when at the last election the opposition had proposals to cut billions of dollars of education expenditure. The only area the opposition may be interested in showing concern about is private schools. We are interested in the total education system of Australia, both public and private.

PARA.TAB: There will be good announcements made on policy in this area in the budget. I am just astonished that the opposition keeps calling for expenditure cuts all over the place, particularly in the public sector, yet Senator Woods can jump up here saying that any suggestion to cut expenditure, which is in no way verified by the government, leads to concern. It is absolutely hypocritical on your part.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The minister would be aware of the question I asked him in the last week of sitting regarding Australia's $6.6 million assistance for North Korea to build two nuclear power stations. Is the minister aware that, contrary to his assertion that solar energy is of little use in Korea, Solarhart Australia is already selling between $1.5 million and $2 million worth of solar hot water units into Korea? Is the minister aware that, on the very day I asked the question, Solarhart was negotiating with South Korea to build solar hot water units in that country? Is the minister aware that South Korea very sensibly levies fossil fuel sales and uses the money to subsidise the up-front capital cost of solar units? Finally, noting that the paltry $6 million provided in the 1993 budget has not resulted in a single domestic solar hot water installation in Australia, does the minister not think it is now time we followed South Korea's excellent example and provided real assistance to Australia's domestic and export solar industries rather than propping up foreign nuclear technology?

—I am absolutely delighted to learn that Solarhart has $1.5 million or $2 million worth of sales into Korea and that it has the prospects for many more such sales. I do not doubt for a moment that there is a niche capacity for that very sophisticated and effective enterprise to get into that particular market and on that kind of scale.

PARA.TAB: The point about my answer to you last week or whenever it was, Senator Coulter, is that you were suggesting that solar energy could be the answer in itself to North Korea's nuclear needs. The point of the matter was that in order to generate the kind of power that is going to be produced by the two 1,000 megawatt stations that will be supplied under this negotiation to save us all from having bombs dropped upon us, you will recall, Senator Coulter, and in order to pay for the energy equivalent of that in solar energy, you would have to spend something like $15 billion on solar heating appliances scattered around the landscape, and that is on the assumption that there is enough sunlight in North Korea to play upon these installations in order to generate the wattage that is required.

That was the point of my excursion, not to say that there is no market opportunity for solar heaters at all in that environment. Of course there is. There is in every environment in the world almost a niche opportunity, but it can be no more than that when you are talking about satisfying the basic energy needs of the nation.

So far as our $US6 million or $US5 million contribution was concerned, what we are basically doing is demonstrating a commitment to the solution which we hope has now been successfully negotiated of the biggest single security problem we had in the entire region, a problem whereby North Korea was almost certainly engaged right now in the production of nuclear weapons with essentially unsafeguarded facilities in an environment where it was putting at risk the security of not only the Korean Peninsula but also the whole region. It was desperately necessary to get a negotiated solution to that security problem.

I think in a first class feat of diplomatic endurance the United States did negotiate such an agreement with the North Koreans, the trade-off for which was that North Koreans would be assisted with their energy production needs in the future. On a transient basis, pending the construction of those energy power plants, there was going to be the supply of heavy fuel and Australia's contribution was to assist to pay for that, as I said, as essentially a symbolic contribution to the larger peace deal.

That was the only realistic energy alternative available, as I understand it, that was acceptable to the North Koreans. The facilities in question will be fully safeguarded. That is very much part of the arrangement as well. The whole result is one that ought to be applauded by you wearing your peace hat, not poured scorn upon by you wearing a solar energy greenie hat because your solar energy greenie hat just simply does not offer anything of any relevance to the solution of the basic problem that we were trying to address.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Leaving aside the minister's naivety in his faith in the NPT, and just dealing with solar energy, will the minister admit that he is totally misrepresenting the point? The cost of the two units being built in North Korea is $4.5 billion. We are talking about $6.6 million from Australia and it would be very easy for Australia to substitute that small amount with solar energy as is already happening in South Korea, as I indicated in the question.

—We did not have any choice in the matter as to how our particular contribution would be spent. What the North Koreans wanted, what was negotiated in the deal, was a contribution to their transient energy needs which needed the supply of heavy fuel. We would much prefer to have been able to supply lighter fractions of petroleum which we can produce ourselves rather than simply paying for someone else's fuel to be supplied. But we were not in there as an energy policy exercise; we were in there as a peace exercise and wearing your peace hat or your party's peace hat surely you can see that.

PARA.TAB: Yes, it does cost $4.5 billion. It is likely to cost that to produce these two light water reactors but to produce the equivalent amount of energy through solar means, assuming the sunlight was available, would cost, as I said, $15 billion. That is the truth of the matter so far as the energy economics of this are concerned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. I refer to the direction of the US government after the Uruguay Round resolution to use its export subsidy programs for market development, for example, recent subsidised dairy exports to Asia, and ABARE's conclusion in its US farm bill paper, which states:

QUESTION.PARA: If the US subsidy programs are refocused on markets that are important for Australian exports largely in Asia and the Pacific, many of the benefits from less distorted trade which Australia could reasonably expect from the Uruguay Round would be lost.

In view of the great damage to our smaller industries like citrus, tobacco and chicken meat from the Uruguay Round resolution in the interest of at least sustaining benefits for our large industries like wheat, beef and sugar, I ask: does the government agree with ABARE's assessment? If its assessment should eventuate and the benefits are not there, what will be the government's response to both our small and large primary industries?
