TALK.START.PARA: —I am very surprised that I find the day when the National Party is seeking to undermine the benefits that flow to the Australian agricultural industry from the very important Uruguay Round.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order on the basis of truth. At no time have I ever undermined Australian primary industry. Senator McMullan well knows—
—Order! There is no point of order.

—That point of order at least had the advantage of being unique. It is true—it has always been true, and Senator Boswell and I have agreed on this in the past—that Australia is very concerned about the continuing subsidisation of exports by the United States and by Europe and the unfair impact that has upon free traders in agriculture, including Australia.

PARA.TAB: This year we have already had one unfortunate example with regard to the dairy industry. It was of minor significance to Australia in itself, in terms of the particular initiative that took place, but it was a worrying sign to which we on all sides of this parliament responded in common. The extent to which the United States seeks to refocus its export enhancement programs in dairy products and dairy equivalents into market enhancement programs does create the potential for that to intrude upon Australian markets.

We continue to make representations in support of, and to receive reassurances from the United States about, its commitment to seek to implement these programs, even as newly focused, in a manner which minimises the impact on fair traders in agriculture, which includes Australia and the Cairns Group countries. We are continually in liaison with the other members of the Cairns Group, seeking to focus attention on the two things we can do that are positive rather than just sitting back here expressing concern and fear and trembling.

In the United States, it is about seeking to put maximum pressure on the Farm Bill. We have in 1995 a real opportunity to have a significant downward pressure on the subsidies within the Farm Bill. I would love to say that was because of the eloquence of the representations of the Cairns Group countries and others, but that is only peripheral. The core explanation is the budgetary problems in the United States. As they occur, the United States has to face up to the reality of its enormous budget deficit. It will have to realise that it cannot continue to subsidise agriculture to the extent it does.

The evidence of the waste in that program and the domestic impact of that program is starting to emerge. So many of the already affluent receive the subsidies and those to whom the taxpayers think they are providing it do not. All those things are starting to become part of the public debate. The new chairman of the agriculture committee in the Senate, Senator Lugar, is making some progressive comments in this regard.

Every Australian parliamentarian and every Australian citizen concerned with the public debate about trade and agricultural policy needs to be concerned about how these subsidies might be abused. The key thing is that, under the Uruguay Round, we have got agreement to reduce them in the United States and even more importantly—we should not forget this—to reduce them in Europe. Budgetary pressures in Europe and the United States will reinforce the impact of those Uruguay Round commitments and should lead to opportunities for Australian exporters in dairy and other agricultural products to be significantly enhanced during this decade as a result of the Uruguay Round. We will continue to actively address those issues to seek to achieve that outcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. I refer the minister to a prediction by the Australian Ricegrowers Cooperative Ltd that Australian farmers are aiming to capture half of Japan's 1995 rice import market. In this regard, can the minister report to the Senate on the expected growth of the Japanese market for Australian rice growers and other primary producers as well?

—I thank Senator Colston for his question. In the Uruguay Round we did have, amongst the other important initiatives that I was able to outline in the response to Senator Boswell's question, an important commitment from the Japanese government to institute the graduated opening of Japan's agricultural market, particularly with regard to rice, although there were important market opening opportunities in other products which hopefully I will have time to comment on briefly. But we should not underestimate the significance of that. The percentage figures are small—rising from four per cent of domestic consumption in the base year period in 1995 up to eight per cent by the year 2000—but that means 380,000 tonnes of imported rice this year and 758,000 tonnes by the year 2000.

PARA.TAB: Australian rice growers and the Ricegrowers Cooperative Ltd are understandably optimistic about winning a significant share of this because, in the temporary market opening recently caused by the 1993 crop problems in Japan, Australia's rice was very well received on the Japanese market. The type of the rice, the japonica style, and its utilisation and quality were very well received. If the processes that are instituted to implement this commitment enable fair and open competition for that 380,000 tonnes this year, Australia will win a very big share of it. It is not excessive for our rice growers to think they might win half of it. It certainly is a very reasonable objective for them to set themselves and they have been going about the promotion intelligently. A similar opportunity on a smaller scale arises in Korea.

There are other agricultural market opportunities for Australia in the market opening in Japan in wheat, in barley and in dairy. We are already starting to do well in some of those markets. That opening—small as it is and only a first step in what needs to be a much more substantial market opening—could be very important for Australian primary producers and will generate a lot of export income for Australia and a lot of income for many Australian towns. In conclusion, for all those who say that there is a serious problem with the Uruguay Round and that we should not have entered into it—and there were some in the Senate who said that—they should go to Leeton and explain to the rice growers why it is not a good idea that Australia signed up to the Uruguay Round.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Senator Herron asked a question without notice on 9 March this year about how much federal funding had gone towards the production of sexually explicit swap cards. I have been provided with the following information. I am advised that the bubble boy card series produced by the Queensland AIDS Council was funded by the Queensland Department of Health from the AIDS matched funds program, known as the MFP. Under the national HIV/AIDS strategy, the Commonwealth allocates funds to the states and territories on a matched dollar-for-dollar basis for HIV/AIDS activities. Funding is provided to the states under the MFP for education, prevention, treatment and care, training and evaluation activities conducted by state AIDS councils and other non-government groups as well as state developed and administered HIV/AIDS programs. Responsibility for allocating MFP funds rests with the relevant state health authority within the framework of the national HIV/AIDS strategy.

—Under the order of the Senate relating to questions on notice agreed to on 28 September 1988, I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Justice, Senator Bolkus, for an explanation of why I have not received an answer to question No. 1780, which I put on notice on 18 October 1994 to the Minister representing the Minister for Justice in relation to allegations concerning improper actions undertaken by Telecom.

—Earlier today, the Temporary Chairman of Committees, Senator Colston, agreed to refer to me a ruling which he made concerning remarks made by Senator Bolkus about Senator Vanstone. Senator Bolkus said that Senator Vanstone had produced `something out of a brown paper envelope'. Senator Vanstone submitted that this remark raised an implication that she had improperly taken some action in return for a consideration, and that the remark was therefore a personal reflection on her within the meaning of standing order 193. Senator Colston said that he was unsure that the remark was unparliamentary and that he was not convinced that there was a personal reflection intended, but he required the minister to withdraw the reference to Senator Vanstone.

PARA.TAB: Having read the Hansard transcript of the exchange, like Senator Colston, I am not convinced that the personal reflection perceived by Senator Vanstone either was intended or would be perceived by a reasonable listener to the debate. The chair has regard to the context in which remarks are made and, having regard to the context of the remarks in question, it would appear that the expression `brown paper envelope' implied secrecy and lack of consultation rather than receipt of improper considerations. If a senator believes, however, that remarks constitute a personal reflection, the chair leans towards requiring a withdrawal of the remarks; and that is what Senator Colston very properly did on this occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 October 1994 I requested on notice an answer from the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) in relation to allegations concerning improper actions undertaken by Telecom. As Senator Bolkus, the Minister representing the Minister for Justice, was leaving the chamber he said to me, `Somebody from my office is going to ring your office and the answer will be forthcoming tomorrow.' I am pursuing the matter because on 6 January 1995 my office requested a response to that question which had been asked in October. We were told by the minister's office that someone would get back to us.

PARA.TAB: One fortnight ago we were assured that the answer was on the minister's desk or some equivalent—I would not want to misquote somebody as that statement was patently inaccurate—and that it would be forthcoming immediately. That was a fortnight ago, so I do not see that the minister's chance remark on the way out of the chamber excuses him for his failure to give an answer within the 30-day rule. I have no reason to believe his comment that I will receive it tomorrow any more than I should have believed the comment a fortnight ago.

I will not delay the Senate. I know my other colleagues want to take note of answers—as I do—so I will not indulge in a 30-minute speech about the failure of the minister. But I want to put it on the record that questions on notice are one of the few mechanisms available to people like me in the chamber who do not often get the opportunity to gain information from ministers. We deserve the respect of having that 30-day rule honoured. I draw it to the attention of the minister and move:
That the Senate take note of the absence of an explanation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Short this day, relating to the economy.

SPEECH.PARA: During the recent overseas jaunt of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), he demeaned his position and that of the Australian nation by disgracefully breaking the long accepted convention of not pursuing domestic political issues whilst representing his country overseas. I am sure no-one will ever forget his elbowing aside of the Prime Minister of Singapore on the steps of the parliament house there to mount an attack on opposition leader John Howard.

PARA.TAB: When the Prime Minister was not so paranoically and embarrassingly engaged, which was the case most of the time, he made himself look even more ridiculous by telling the Europeans how to run their economies. He told Germany of all places, with the strongest economy in the world, how to do business with Asia, how to rebuild its cities and how to reshape the global power balance. While Mr Keating was feeding his ego by strutting the world stage, sounding every decibel more like a dictator in the making, the Australian economy continued to plunge into further balance of payments deficit, the foreign debt continued to soar and the Australian dollar plummeted against virtually all other currencies, including the deutschmark, the currency of the nation whose chancellor Mr Keating had the arrogance to lecture on economic management. Unbelievable!

Today, when I pointed out to the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) that the fall in the Australian dollar and our chronic balance of payments problem made further interest rate and tax increases inevitable unless the government acted swiftly and surely to put its budget house in order, he refused even to comprehend that situation. The simple fact is that the government is attempting to sweep this inevitability under the carpet until after the New South Wales election next Saturday. That is a quite disgraceful abrogation of the government's responsibility to manage the affairs of state at the national level. It is almost an exact repeat of what the Hawke government did in 1988, when the Prime Minister was Treasurer and when the then New South Wales Labor government under Premier Barrie Unsworth was fighting for survival—unsuccessfully as it turned out.

The delays in taking responsible economic action at the federal level in 1988 simply in a totally unopportunistic domestic political attempt to save the skin of a colleague government at the state level in New South Wales—the delays that were caused for that very reason alone—were what led directly to the then Treasurer pulling on the recession that he said we had to have. In reality, it was a recession we should never have had to have if there had been one ounce of economic responsibility and acceptance of that responsibility at the federal government level. We are seeing the same thing again this year in the 1995 election for the New South Wales government. I am absolutely certain that the result will be the same as that of 1988: that is, desperate attempts by a Labor government in Canberra to save their Labor mates—and I use the word advisedly—in New South Wales will be as unsuccessful in 1995, and deservedly so, as they were in 1988.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Cooney this day, relating to native title legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sick and tired of the government resting on its laurels in relation to Aboriginal affairs when its record in this most sensitive portfolio is absolutely appalling.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, rubbish!

—If ever there were an area of public policy failure, it would have to be in relation to Aboriginal affairs. You only have to start by looking at the facts. Look at some of the figures of the recent census of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The unemployment rate is 38 per cent, but if we take into account those who are working for the dole on Commonwealth unemployment programs, 54 per cent of Aborigines are unemployed. Of those, 60 to 70 per cent are long-term unemployed and 50 per cent are in the 15 to 19 age group.

PARA.TAB: You might smile or laugh at this, but we actually think it is important. Look at income, for example. Aborigines do not have jobs. Six out of 10 Aborigines in Australia—60 per cent—are on an annual income of less than $12,000. It is an appalling record. On education, this government boasts about the number of children who are staying at school to year 12. Of all the 17-year-old Aboriginal Australians, only 30 per cent are in any form of education at all.

Did Senator Reynolds read the census report which said that 29 per cent of Aboriginal Australians are concerned about where their next meal is coming from? Did you read that maternal death rates are eight times higher in the Aboriginal community than in the white community, that 30 per cent of Aborigines are affected by diabetes and that men aged between 25 and 35 are 10 times more likely to die than the rest of the community? We can go on.

Has Senator Reynolds looked at the figures in relation to Aboriginal housing? Have you seen that 40,000 Aborigines living in remote and rural Australia need housing and that one-third of the existing stock—4,500 houses—are in poor repair and in need of major renovation, that 35,000 bedrooms are needed and that 16,000 people need proper access to sewerage systems?

How many times do you need to look at the facts before you recognise that your government has failed in this vitally important and sensitive area? I will go on with housing. Of all Aborigines, 69 per cent—practically 70 per cent—are in some form of rental housing. That in itself is not bad, but why are they treated differently from the rest of the Australian community? The government has failed them in the critically important areas of Aboriginal health, Aboriginal jobs and Aboriginal education—the areas where Aboriginal people have a right to expect more of this government.

All we hear from the government is its boast. I heard on the radio over the weekend, `We gave Australian Aborigines Mabo.' This government did not give them Mabo at all; Mabo was the decision of the High Court. It was the High Court that decided that native title existed, not your government at all. As to the latest land bill, we have said that we will support it, but the point is that it is easy for you to pass legislation to allocate public money for the purchase of an area where state governments have been doing it for years and then boast of your achievements.

When you look at these critically important areas—health, education and jobs—it can only be said on any fair objective assessment that you have failed the Aboriginal community in this country, that your record in Aboriginal affairs is deplorable, and it is about time you faced up to your responsibility in that regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand why you are sensitive, Senator Hill. I can understand why you feel you have to go through a litany of statistics. I do not suppose that anyone on this side of the chamber would try to claim that this government has overcome all the very complex social issues facing indigenous peoples. However, we have been prepared to tackle some of the major issues, the ideological issues, that you cannot come to grips with.

PARA.TAB: You talk about our response to the High Court's decision, but it was quite clear that you could not deal with that issue. You were so divided. You could not deal with it in an open, fair spirited way. You had to nitpick at every turn. Now you have to be very grudging in your approach when you continue to deal with all the issues affecting indigenous people.

This morning, when we should have been debating the Racial Hatred Bill, we debated something else. Again you refused to deal with the issues. I will debate you any day about the fundamentals in relation to health, housing, employment and education. But if you look at the statistics of your administration in the 1970s—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Reynolds, I invite you to address your remarks to the opposition through the chair.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President; I am glad you reminded me of that. I think it is important that in this place we try to get some cross-party approach to race issues and to indigenous issues in particular. I find it very distressing that the opposition loses no opportunity to try to point score and politicise what is a fundamental issue for this nation.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill talks about our reputation. Senator Hill, you are someone who travels extensively. Certainly, when I travel, it is quite common for people to compliment the Australian people and the Australian government on the changes that have been made to indigenous policy in this country. A number of people, particularly from Canada and the United States, are extremely impressed with ATSIC and the way it operates. But all we ever hear in this place is criticism of the commission and—

TALK.START.PARA: —I'm not criticising the commission. I am criticising your government—12 years of failure!
—You might not be criticising on this occasion but you do frequently criticise. Members of the opposition are always criticising ATSIC. You lose no opportunity to take indigenous people to task.

PARA.TAB: On issues in other areas of government, where funds have not necessarily been spent as effectively as they should, do we hear from the opposition? No, we do not. We only hear from the opposition when it wants to attack indigenous people. Let us look at what happened in the Hindmarsh Island circumstance. Was there a spirit of generosity shown by Ian McLachlan? No, there was not. He finally had to resign because he was obliged to resign. He saw that that was necessary.

Senator Hill, I do not think you are in any position to lecture this government until you get your own policies in order. We do not know what your policies are. We do not know what your commitment to indigenous people is. You are continually resentful and resistant in your approach to indigenous issues. It is about time that you put your policies on the table. Then we might be able to make a judgement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen C.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to add a few remarks to Senator Gareth Evans's response to the question of native title legislation. The response made by the Liberal Party to the decision of the High Court the other day is of concern, a concern highlighted by Senator Hill's contribution today. I took his remarks as a re-run of the mark 2 position on the land fund, which talked about amendments addressing issues of education, health, housing, et cetera. That was the Downer position, as different from the Hewson position, as different from the Howard position, which is now to claim that the legislation is unworkable. That shows the total disarray in which the Liberal Party finds itself in relation to Aboriginal issues.

PARA.TAB: The High Court found the other day that the Western Australian legislation was invalid. It ruled seven to nil on that issue. It is quite clear that the Commonwealth's legislation has been upheld while the Western Australian legislation was found to be invalid and, in my view, essentially racist.The Liberal Party has to come to terms with that. It cannot continue to bow to the Liberal rednecks in Western Australia who want to pretend it never happened. The fact is that the Mabo decision did happen; the federal parliament responded and legislated in accordance with that decision.

The High Court has now removed any uncertainty about our legislation's constitutional validity and has ruled invalid the racist attempt by the Western Australian government to take away those rights to native title enjoyed by Western Australian Aboriginal people.But the worrying aspect is not that Richard Court continues to oppose the legislation and continues his fight. I guess he has no option. He has committed himself so far down the track that he really cannot turn back, although it is obviously a severe risk to his credibility when $10 million of Western Australian taxpayers' money has been wasted on this futile attempt to overturn the native title legislation.

The really worrying aspect is the remarks made by John Howard in commenting on the decision following Richard Court's comments. He claimed that the legislation was unworkable in Western Australia. He provided no evidence or basis for that assertion. He is trying to assuage the redneck elements of the Liberal Party in Western Australia who wish to argue the legislation is unworkable in WA.

They do not say what is different about Western Australia other than the fact that there are more mining leases granted than any other state. That is quite true. We have a large amount of mining activity. But the principles that underlie the bill are just as capable of working in Western Australia as in any other state. For John Howard to have this knee-jerk reaction that the legislation is unworkable shows the total disarray on the part of Liberals on the questions of Aboriginal land and native title.

The Liberals are completely out of touch and that is reflected in an article in today's Australian in which the chief of CRA—a well-known friend of the Labor Party and the trade union movement—has hailed Mabo as an opportunity for partnership. The article said:

In a speech representing a sea-change in attitudes at CRA—long regarded as hardline—and praising the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, Mr Leon Davis said yesterday he was "satisfied with the central tenet" of the Act.

Mr Davis said it "laid the basis for better exploration access and thus increased the probability that the next decade will see a series of CRA operations developed in active partnership with Aboriginal people".

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberal Party is not reflecting even the views of the mining industry in its continued opposition to the native title legislation. CRA, one of the biggest miners and explorers in Western Australia, is indicating its support for the basic principles of the Native Title Act. The opposition is all alone, clinging to support Richard Court, who has been proved to be wrong, seven-nil, and who cannot accept the political defeat.

PARA.TAB: The High Court has upheld our legislation and upheld the opportunities in the act to make the system work. I think Richard Court and the Liberal Party are better off looking constructively at the problems that they say exist and using the mechanisms that already exist in the native title legislation to establish state bodies and tribunals to deal with applications. Also they should look at the question of the right to negotiate regime and the possibilities for exclusion and some of those things.

There are opportunities in the native title legislation that can be adopted and usefully used in Western Australia with a constructive approach. John Howard should not go the same way as Alexander Downer in bowing to hard-line Liberal right-wing attitudes. Alexander Downer brought about the downfall of his own leadership. The same will happen to John Howard unless he changes his view on this legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), to a question without notice asked by Senator Neal this day, relating to child care in New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: If Senator Crowley is not aware that after extensive negotiations the New South Wales government agreed to the expanded national child-care strategy on 3 February 1995, then she is not managing her department well. She knows very well that there was in principle agreement by the federal government and the state government to the terms in the strategy at an officer level. Senator Crowley has yet to officially sign the agreement and she is the one at fault in the political storm that she has tried to whip up today.

PARA.TAB: I concur with the comments of the New South Wales Minister for Community Services, Mr Jim Longley, who has accused the federal Labor government of deliberately delaying the implementation of the expanded national child-care strategy as a blatant political stunt.

Senator Crowley has long been critical of the New South Wales government for not signing the agreement. It seems strange, now that the state has finally forced the government to make concessions—only weeks before the state election, in which Labor is not looking good—that Senator Crowley is now holding off signing the agreement. One would almost be led to the conclusion that she is more concerned with playing political games with her state counterparts than actually being concerned about child-care places.

The New South Wales government had not previously signed the agreement, because it was not convinced that the strategy was in the best interests of children or their parents. It was particularly concerned that the Commonwealth's emphasis on child care for children with working families did not adequately address the needs of vulnerable children.

New South Wales accepted the Commonwealth's offer of additional child care places after three points were conceded: firstly, when new places were promised for disadvantaged families, which Labor was not prepared to fund under the previous guidelines; secondly, when the Commonwealth finally ensured that administrative agreements were streamlined, which reduced bureaucratic delays; and thirdly, when long day care places were added into preschools, which is surely making the best use of resources. In negotiating for those concessions, the New South Wales government was not being obstreperous. It had simply taken great pains to work out an agreement that appropriately addressed the needs of families in New South Wales and ensured a high standard of care for children.

The concern with affordability, flexibility and accessibility is not something that the Commonwealth government has a very good track record on. I might just refresh the government's memory of a number of problems with the Commonwealth's child care program which were chronicled in reports which came out last year. These problems included insufficient baby places, insufficient child care places in rural areas, the cost of child care, a lack of flexibility in care arrangements and so on. Parents continually complained about the lack of places, the long waiting lists and the unsuitability of the opening hours for centre based care.

Of course Senator Crowley is going to make these comments in the run-up to the New South Wales election. What needs to be borne in mind is the fragmentation and administrative chaos of the Commonwealth programs compared to the constructive policies of the Fahey government which will provide an integrated child care program so necessary to the needs of the modern family.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have heard many apologies in various guises in this place, but this is the best one I have ever heard. The opposition is apologising for the fact that New South Wales took five years to sign the national child care agreement. That means that 8,000 places in New South Wales have been wanted by families but have not been available for five years, and somebody in the opposition stands up and has to apologise. No wonder people in New South Wales are concerned about the actions of the current Fahey government when that is the sort of thing that has been going on.

PARA.TAB: Senator Troeth talked about the problems of long waiting lists. There would not be such long waiting lists in New South Wales if the New South Wales government had signed the agreement when it was first discussed and put on the table. But it took New South Wales to the eve of an election which it looks like losing before it decided it had to do something for the families with children.

I suggest that Senator Troeth would be well advised to go and talk to rural families in New South Wales about the preschool needs of children and why they cannot get preschools in those areas. She wants to talk about child care and preschool needs, but what about talking to the parents who cannot get their children distance education preschool because the New South Wales government will fund them for only about 70 places? Only 70 places in distance education preschool to cover the whole of New South Wales: you have to be joking!

New South Wales has crazy rules for people in places such as Wanaaring, where there might be only one child of preschool age. Because they live in a settled area, they are not able to have access to distance education preschool, which is the same as the school of the air.

The New South Wales government has been discriminating against families—particularly in rural areas—for a long time on the issue of child care and children's services. What about the issue of accommodation for the disabled in New South Wales? We would have liked a discussion on that issue, but it is not related to this answer. We are talking about child care and children's services in New South Wales. What the Fahey-Murray-Armstrong government has done is totally neglect and disregard the needs of rural families, particularly the child care needs of people in those areas.

That government should talk to the occasional care centre in Broken Hill. It has been trying to get extra funding out of the state government so that an occasional care centre can continue to run. The government should go up to Wee Waa and talk to the mothers and the families there. This year a mobile preschool is being run there because of a rural women's access program grant. But next year the state government will not provide them with anything. These are the sorts of things that people in New South Wales are having to put up with.

As I say, we heard nothing on this issue from the state government for in excess of four years. For four years this went on, and it did nothing. It deprived people access to about 8,000 places. I could not live with that on my conscience. Obviously Mr Fahey is suddenly having an attack of conscience now. We started hearing things from his government when we were about five weeks away from the election, and we have had a few headlines since then.

Why has it taken the New South Wales government four years? It has actually taken five years, because we are now in 1995. Why has it taken that government so long? It has come up with a number of feeble excuses about wanting to get a better deal and is saying that because it waited it has got a better deal. What about the families who have been discriminated against? What about those who have been unable to find the care for their children they have needed in the past four years? They have been totally ignored and totally neglected.

That is the sort of thing that a coalition government would do federally. We have seen it. We know what a federal coalition government would do because we have an example of what a state coalition government has done. This is the sort of thing that people will be opposing and voting against next Saturday.

It is interesting to note that we have not heard anything on this matter from the opposition. By today's performance in the chamber, it is obvious that an election is coming up in New South Wales. The opposition is very concerned about what the result will be. It is pretty clear there will be a change of government. When the current Liberal government in New South Wales has to suddenly, after five years, decide it will sign agreements it highlights to us just how very seriously concerned it is. I think it is an abysmal shame and a disgrace that it has taken a government five years to do something and it has deprived 8,000 families or more of access to child care which they desperately need.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the resolution of the Senate of 23 August 1990, I present the report of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title on the National Native Tribunal Annual Report 1993-94, together with the transcript of evidence, which were presented to the President on 9 March 1995.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen C.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: This report, which is the second report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Native Title, was tabled out of session due to the pressures of business during the last sitting week. This is a report on the first annual report of the National Native Title Tribunal. It is worth noting that this report of a parliamentary committee relating to Aboriginal affairs is again a unanimous report. The committee has representatives from all parties represented in the Senate except the Australian Democrats. I would like to thank the committee members and the staff, and also acknowledge the cooperation we received from the tribunal president and its staff. As always, they conducted themselves in a very professional manner. I think they are doing an excellent job.

PARA.TAB: The process undertaken to complete this report was very constructive. This point is highlighted by a submission from Mick Dodson, the Social Justice Commissioner. He made some very constructive criticisms about the operation of the tribunal, but he did it in a constructive and positive way and contributed to the debate rather than use it as a point scoring exercise.

The overall conclusion contained in the report is that the Native Title Tribunal is soundly established. The early teething problems about which we received evidence seem to have been addressed satisfactorily and the tribunal is playing a very good role in liaising with all the interested parties. The president has established liaison committees in each of the states and is keeping in close contact with industry and the Aboriginal interests to make sure that the tribunal is kept abreast of developments and is sensitive to the needs of both industry and Aboriginal communities.

The report deals with two major issues, but I will not go into them in any great detail. Firstly, it deals with the acceptance process for applications. Secondly, it deals with the president's first suggested amendments to the act. In terms of the acceptance test, there were arguments from industry that the threshold of the test was too low and that Aboriginals were being allowed to enjoy the benefits of the right to negotiate regime without fully establishing their claim to native title. Aboriginal groups were concerned about the delays in having their claims accepted, the pre-acceptance discussions the tribunal was having, particularly with state governments, and the allegation that they were being required to go through hoops that were not envisaged by the act.

The committee in its conclusion unanimously agreed that section 63 of the act, which governs the acceptance of applications, was being applied correctly by the tribunal—that is, that it was appropriately applying the tests set down in the legislation. In essence, the committee therefore rejects the view that the threshold had been set at too low a level. However, the committee noted:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Tribunal to ensure that the pre acceptance consultation is confined to questions of a factual nature and does not amount to mediation or negotiation with parties.

This is a recognition by the committee of the concerns and criticisms raised by the Aboriginal parties with what, on occasions, they considered to be quite long delays at the acceptance stage. We are pleased to note that the president in his submission to the inquiry has responded to those concerns and is amending the tribunal's procedures to respond to the evidence presented to the committee.

PARA.TAB: On the other issue of the president's proposed amendment to the act, the committee took the view that it was too early, given the formative stage of the legislation and the need for more practical experience, to make a definitive judgment on this proposed amendment. The committee concluded at the time that we ought to await the decision of the High Court. As senators would be aware, that decision has now been handed down. The decision upheld the Commonwealth legislation and struck out the Western Australian legislation as being invalid.

In normal circumstances it would be appropriate to consider that early amendment suggested by the president. I must say, however, that the debate has now very much moved on, not only because of the High Court decision in relation to the WA legislation but also more importantly, in my view, because of the decision of the High Court in the Brandy, case which has implications for the Native Title Tribunal. The changed public stance of organisations like the WA Chamber of Mines and Energy and the comments reported in today's Australian by the head of CRA in Australia are indicative that the whole debate has moved on. I think a discussion of the president's amendment is really not very helpful at this stage.

The president has submitted to the government a range of further amendments which address the Brandy decision and the implications of that decision for the Native Title Tribunal. The government will have to seriously look at those suggestions in responding to the difficulties posed by the Brandy decision. They ought to be the focus of discussion about amendments to the native title legislation. It is still the case that it is too early to look at whether or not the principles underlying the legislation have been successfully applied. That is due to the uncertainty brought about by the WA High Court challenge and the fact that most parties have held off proceeding under the Native Title Act until a clear decision had been made.

There are also issues relating to pastoral leases about which judicial decision is awaited. Quite frankly, the states have played a negative role in a number of cases by taking technical legal points during mediation proceedings which have not allowed the tribunal processes to run as smoothly as one would have hoped. All these factors, together with the basic fact that the development of common law in relation to native title will be a long process and will evolve over time, mean that, in my view, it is too early to properly assess and review the legislation and the impact the Native Title Act is having.

The challenge now is to respond to the Brandy case decision to ensure that the tribunal processes and procedures are altered to reflect that decision, but to allow the basic principles of the act to stay in place. Hopefully, the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Native Title will play a constructive and positive role in examining the need for those changes and making recommendations to government and to the parliament. I would hope that all the acrimony that has surrounded Aboriginal issues in this parliament since I was elected to the Senate can be overcome. There have been some good signs during the work of this committee where, despite some differences of opinion, we have managed to produce two unanimous reports. Hopefully, when we get to more contentious issues, that trend will continue.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
