DEBATE.TITLE: LAND FUND AND INDIGENOUS LAND CORPORATION (ATSIC AMENDMENT) BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 9 March, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak on the Land Fund and Indigenous Land Corporation (ATSIC Amendment) Bill 1994 and by our support for the previous motion we were indicating that we are anxious to have this matter passed through the parliament as expeditiously as possible. We do so on the basis that, whilst we have taken a position of principle—and, indeed, I think to a significant extent we have been vindicated by the number of amendments that the Senate managed to achieve to the legislation which the government from the outset maintained did not require any amendments—I think we have demonstrated that the time spent in this chamber has been well worth while.

PARA.TAB: Having reached the deadlock position as a result of intransigence on the part of the government in relation to at least some of the balance of those amendments, it seemed clear to us, as Mr Howard spelt out in the House of Representatives on 2 March, that no point would usefully be served by further delay because it was clear the government was not proposing to go down our path and we were not proposing to go down its path. In those circumstances, the only losers would be those who are intended to be the beneficiaries of this legislation.

In those circumstances, we therefore have made plain that we will support the land fund. Once that is in place, we will obviously monitor progress through to the next election but at that time we will again seek to introduce those amendments which we achieved successfully in this chamber and which we think do go a very significant way towards improving the lot of those who are meant to benefit from the legislation.

It is significant that this time around, as opposed to the time when the Mabo legislation was debated, a significant number of Aboriginal communities and a number of organisations, particularly the New South Wales Land Council, have made it plain that they do not agree with the government's approach or with the position outlined by ATSIC spokespeople. That does not necessarily mean that those who were criticising ATSIC were right. It also does not mean that ATSIC was right. What it does mean is that there is room for intelligent disputation in the Aboriginal community, and so there ought to be in national politics.

It is a great tragedy that whenever an issue relating to Aboriginal affairs surfaces—as we all know, it is a very emotive subject—the Prime Minister takes every opportunity to imply that only he is on the side of virtue and that his critics are hard-hearted, selfish people who are seeking to deny the improvement of the Aboriginal condition. That is clearly not the case. There are a number of ways in which progress can be achieved. I would hope that, in the spirit adverted to a moment ago by Senator Chris Evans, there can be honest differences of opinion.

At this stage, I pay tribute to the work of two of my Senate colleagues, Senators Ian Campbell and Chris Ellison. After considerable consultation, it became clear that there was a significant demand amongst members of the Aboriginal community for much more direct involvement. They did not want to have things decided by so-called official representatives and they did not want to have land simply transferred to corporations. They wanted the approach to be broadened so that individuals would be of paramount importance.

Senators Campbell and Ellison travelled around the country during January, when Senator Ray and I were at the cricket. It was clearly a very important exercise in ascertaining what it was that the Aboriginal community wanted. I do not think we came up with any single view, and nor should we. But we did discover—I hope the government will acknowledge this—that there are very many different approaches that can be taken in good faith. Therefore, the amendments which were carried by the Senate but which the government will now not pursue are ones which we will certainly seek to reintroduce as soon as the opportunity arises, and that will certainly be after the next election. When we go down that path, we will find that the approach that we are proposing will have a much more holistic impact on the Aboriginal community. It will not simply be focused entirely on land, as important as it is. It will also address other fundamental factors which are necessary for human wellbeing.

We all know the extent to which the Aboriginal community is greatly deprived in the areas of health, housing, education, welfare and employment opportunities. Unless and until we focus on those greater criteria, it is unlikely that we will see significant improvement in the Aboriginal condition. One of the great tragedies is that, after 12 years of government and the expenditure of hundreds of millions of additional dollars, it is very difficult to demonstrate that Aboriginal health has improved. Indeed, the statistics would indicate quite to the contrary. In those circumstances, the last thing that a Prime Minister ought to be doing is running around pretending that somehow a land fund designed to assist perhaps five per cent of the Aboriginal population is really going to solve any significant problems.

The problems on the ground relate to very basic human needs which need a lot more attention. They do not just need dollars. They need a lot more experimentation in terms of involvement by the Aboriginal communities themselves. There needs to be a lot more sensitivity on the part of those who are responsible for the administration of those funds. They need to fundamentally address the needs of the local communities. They should not simply be told that land is the answer or that without land they cannot make any progress. The argument has some validity undoubtedly but to suggest that, unless and until you are able to restore to the Aboriginal community an entitlement to land that is tantamount to the freehold that is held by many non-Aboriginal Australians, is almost verging on a cruel hoax.

The fact is that you have to approach these things in a number of different ways and you have to ensure that you are making progress on a number of different fronts. So we will be, in due course, in the announcement of our Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander policy, ensuring that we address all of those issues and that, at the same time, we spell out our commitment to ensuring that the land fund operates in the best interest of Aboriginal communities.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Land Fund and Indigenous Land Corporation (ATSIC Amendment) Bill. In doing so, I apologise for getting up to speak three times in about an hour in the Senate. It is not like me, and it should not give any credence to yesterday's Australian Financial Review stories or that this is somehow prompted by them. I am very much the 12th man type.

PARA.TAB: It is important for at least a couple of government senators to speak to this bill. It is a fact that we occupied a large part of the debate when we debated the previous bill and I do not really wish to traverse all that ground. I acknowledge that Senator Alston did not do that, and that is appropriate, but it is important that we say a few things about this bill because it is important to put it in context. It is the second stage of the government's legislative response to Mabo. It is part of a package of measures the government has initiated to try to respond to the dispossession of Aboriginal people from their land. It is about their relationship with land and about trying to allow them to assert their independence and to assert their relationship with the land.

The land fund will enable indigenous people to acquire land and to manage it in a sustainable way to promote economic, social and cultural benefits. It will address the needs of those who will not benefit from Mabo and the native title legislation—that is, those dispossessed of their land who cannot meet the criteria laid down in the Mabo decision, which requires a continuing connection with the land and waters. The High Court Mabo decision and the native title legislation will always be seen as the landmark, the symbolic recognition of Aboriginal preoccupancy of the land by Australian society. In a practical sense of making land with commercial viability and ongoing benefits available to Aboriginal people, the land fund and the measures contained in the social justice package may prove to be more significant in the longer term.

The resounding rejection of the Western Australian government's land legislation in response to the Mabo decision and the discriminatory way that legislation operated has obviously reinforced the Mabo judgment and the correct approach that this parliament adopted. We can now seek to have those native title laws implemented and properly applied and I think we will make significant progress in the next year or so in developing native title. But it will be a long process. It will rely on judicial judgments and the evolution of common law. There are no easy solutions or quick fixes involved in that native title route.

Despite the rhetoric of some political leaders such as the Premier of Western Australia, Richard Court, the amount of land that will eventually be found to be native title land and granted to Aboriginals will be quite limited in its extent, because the tests applied by the Mabo judgment and reflected in the native title legislation are quite stringent. It will not be a boon to a large number of Aboriginals in terms of granting them land. Nevertheless, it is a highly significant and symbolic decision and it will result in real benefit to a whole range of Aboriginal communities.

Justice French, of the Native Title Tribunal, in his ruling on the Waanyi application recently, highlighted some of the problems that Aboriginal groups will have in establishing native title. Because of these problems, it is imperative that the land fund as proposed by the government be implemented and that we start to address the dispossession issue for those Aboriginal people who will not have any opportunity to prove native title.

These developments will also generally assist in reconciliation within the Australian community as people come to terms with recognising Aboriginal people as people with rights. By recognising Aboriginal dispossession, by acknowledging their right to the land and by purchasing land to be held by Aboriginal communities, Aboriginal people can help regain their self-respect and force non-Aboriginal people to deal with Aboriginals as people with rights. That is a very important development in Australian society. By recognising Aboriginal rights and by people having to deal with Aboriginal people as people who possess rights, a whole new understanding can be developed in Australian society.

At the risk of repeating remarks I made earlier today in a previous contribution, it is very heartening to hear the chief of CRA, one of Australia's largest mining companies, hailing the Mabo legislation as an opportunity for partnership between mining companies and Aboriginal people, expressing the view that he was satisfied with the central tenet of the Native Title Act and generally being quite positive about the role that mining companies can play in dealing with Aboriginal people as people with rights over land. That is a very encouraging development and represents real change in the climate in Australian society. I have also been heartened by some comments by the Western Australia Chamber of Mines recently, which indicate that it too is beginning to come to terms with native title as a fact in Australian common law, especially now that the Western Australian government's challenge to the native title legislation has been ruled out.

The government has been sensible in accepting some of the amendments that were passed in the Senate. A number of them improve the bill, and I am pleased that we have accepted a range of those amendments. It is now a very strong bill and one which will deliver to Aboriginal people in an appropriate way.

I do not wish to traverse the ground that the opposition has covered in this debate in the last year or so through the various positions adopted by Dr Hewson, Alexander Downer and John Howard. Needless to say, it has been a convoluted and quite confusing path that they have trodden to reach their current position. It is pleasing, nonetheless, to see that we will now get the legislation passed. The government's intention has always been to have the legislation passed rather than to have it provide a double dissolution trigger. I am very hopeful that we will soon pass this legislation and start to see the benefits of the legislation realised by Aboriginal people in the form of land that they can purchase.

I want to make some brief comments about one set of amendments which really troubled me—amendments supported by the Liberal Party and the Greens in the discussion of the earlier bill. These amendments sought to have the ILC allow individuals and trusts to own property acquired through the land fund and allow grantees of land fund acquisitions to dispose of that land at any time without the consent of the ILC. I was particularly troubled by those amendments, and I am very glad that the government has held firm in opposing those amendments.

I understand that, in developing their arguments in support of that proposition, the opposition parties and the Greens have seen it as a way of rejecting paternalism being applied to Aboriginal people and that somehow it will make Aboriginal people more self-reliant and recognise their management of their own affairs. I am sure that has some appeal to those with an interest in rugged individualism, as the Liberal Party has always had, although I am not quite sure what the appeal to the Greens is—but I will have to ask them about that privately.

My major concern there is that that clearly militates against the central aim of building up an indigenous land base and maintaining it for future generations. The government has continued to maintain its position—a position which the the parliament has previously always adopted—that holdings by indigenous corporations best reflect traditional forms of land ownership and provide more reliable guarantees of accountability.

I cannot begin to imagine what would occur the first time an individual Aboriginal sold land granted under the land fund and used those funds for personal consumption purposes. I have listened to Senators Panizza and Crane over the years making repeated attacks on what they see as wasteful spending in ATSIC programs. They have continued to highlight what they say are real concerns about accountability and the expenditure of money in Aboriginal affairs. Senator Kernot referred to this problem in one of her earlier contributions.

For the Liberal Party to seriously suggest that it would support granting land to individual Aboriginals, land which they could then on-sell and use the proceeds for personal consumption, and that the Liberals would not be the first to be screaming blue murder in this chamber, alleging misuse of funds and carrying on a treat, is unbelievable in my view. I cannot believe that the Liberal Party, given its previous positions, could seriously suggest that we should support amendments that go to that objective.

I am pleased that the government has accepted the general view of ATSIC and Aboriginal groups to whom I have spoken that we ought to maintain the grants to corporations rather than individuals and that we look to maintaining the land base and extending it over time for the benefit of all Aboriginals. I would like to acknowledge that the land fund will not be the last step or the last word in this process. The native title legislation represented the first step and the land fund represents the second. The third step is the social justice measures. Some of the ideas coming out of the debate regarding the social justice initiatives may be the most challenging and innovative in dealing with the problem of dispossession of Aboriginal people from their land and taking measures to help Aboriginal people regain their connection with traditional lands.

There have been a number of suggestions about making available other crown land, about regional land management agreements and about a range of other initiatives that involve a lot of lateral thinking. That lateral thinking has been possible only because of the way the native title legislation, the Mabo decision, and the land fund debate have pushed forward the debate about these issues and the recognition generally that land is very important to Aboriginal people. The cultural and spiritual relationship with the land that Aboriginal people enjoy is a much stronger one than that which Europeans have. It is a very special relationship that we have to recognise in responding to Aboriginal needs.

I am not sure that the Liberal Party has quite come to terms with that. Contributions by Senator Hill earlier today and Senator Alston in this debate leave me in some doubt as to whether they have yet come to terms with that special relationship with the land and the need for the parliament to recognise that. We always come back to the debate about what this means for education, health and so on. I do not think the Liberals necessarily grasp the central nature of that Aboriginal connection with the land and the fact that, while those other issues are very important, the relationship of Aboriginal people with their land is, in itself, a very central and important issue. I welcome this second bill and hope the Senate supports it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is wonderful to have the opportunity finally to assist the passage of the Land Fund and Indigenous Land Corporation (ATSIC Amendment) Bill in its amended form. On behalf of the Australian Democrats I signal again our support for the concept of this land fund and our vigorous resistance to some of the core amendments from the opposition and the Greens which, in our view, have the cumulative result of undermining the purpose of the land fund and, in so doing, eroding the land stock.

PARA.TAB: I heard Senator Alston's contribution and I am a little disappointed to hear the opposition mentioning what I regard as citizenship rights—rights to basic health standards, education and housing—and the way in which most Australians have access to those rights. The opposition is still tying those to the notion of land; still seeing land as some sort of commodity, which primarily is there to be bought and sold in a reasonably materialistic way. It is still seeking to measure, in the buying and selling of land, some tangible improvement in what I regard as citizenship rights of indigenous people.

I have to say to the coalition, given what Senator Alston said about seeking to move the opposition's amendments should the opposition form government, that I have not heard anything in the debate that would persuade me to change my view on those three core issues: attaching conditions to land acquisition and maintenance, making grants to individuals and seeking to give priority to the most disadvantaged. I signal to the opposition that, if it really means to put these amendments back before the Senate, should it win government, the Democrats would have to vote against them at that stage as well.

The Native Title Bill and the land fund bill have benefited us by focusing public attention on wider issues associated with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs in this country. It has been important to canvass views with respect to self-determination—the role of land, the spiritual attachment Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have to the land and the sea, and the place of customary law and cultural practice, particularly now with the Hindmarsh Bridge episode. We have talked widely about what constitutes consultation and dispossession. Those have been important discussions to have had in this place. Equally, it has been important to talk to Aboriginal people in this building and at various consultation points around the country—and for us to have gone to them in various ways as well.

I agree with Senator Chris Evans: the land fund is phase 2. A great deal of consultation so far has gone into what should be in the social justice package. The issues that Senator Alston raises with respect to citizenship rights will be clearly addressed in the social justice package. I welcome the public comments we have seen so far from ATSIC and the council of reconciliation on what should be in the social justice package. Phase 3 of this government's response to indigenous issues in this country could well turn out to be, in practical terms, the most important element. I reiterate the Democrats support for this land corporation and land fund bill and look forward to some constructive debate on the social justice package.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the extensive hearings conducted by the Select Committee on the Land Fund Bill, a body of evidence was of the view that, should the coalition and the Greens not be able to get the amendments through, in any event there be a land fund of some sort. Mr Griffiths, who gave evidence at Dubbo, is the coordinator for the Red Chief Local Aboriginal Land Council in Gunnedah, New South Wales. He stated:

PARA.TAB: To be totally honest with you, I agree with the concept that Lois O'Donoghue has put that we have to have something in place. I could not disagree with that. But, prior to that happening, I would hope that any house of parliament would have a look at the wording between the lines. If someone is saying that there has been full consultation with Aboriginal people then that is not right. It has not happened.

SPEECH.PARA: That really sums it up. Some 244 witnesses appeared before that committee, and there was an overwhelming view that there was insufficient consultation. For that, the government stands condemned.

PARA.TAB: However, the coalition had a difficult decision to make. When it became apparent that the land fund bill might not succeed if we stuck it out with our amendments, the question was whether to pass a bill which provides a land fund of some sort or whether to oppose it and thereby thwart the process completely. Mr Griffiths believes that something has to be in place. He was in favour of the New South Wales Land Council amendments, which the coalition has adopted. Rather than lose out on the whole lot, he was saying that he would prefer a land fund in any event—if it has to be that way. That was the decision the coalition had to make. I believe that, in the end, it was an unavoidable decision.

I notice that the government had to make a decision as to what it did with the 67 amendments and the one request which were put forward in this chamber. The government decided to adopt 28 of those amendments. It would seem that the process of debate and inquiry by the committee concerned was of value. It was of value because the government accepted that there were amendments worth taking on board. I caution those who are somewhat overoptimistic about the working of this land fund. Having heard the evidence, I think it would still have been desirable to have had those amendments as proposed by the coalition.

There was a great body of opinion in favour of having the land vested in individuals, Aboriginal trusts and the like. It was regarded as patronising to have said to Aboriginal people, `You can only have it in the form of a corporation because we don't trust what you might do with the land.' It was put to the committee that in the wider community individuals were able to hold land and dispose of land, but in this case we had ties imposed upon the recipients, ties being that the Indigenous Land Corporation has some sort of control over the land.

Most importantly, I believe the question of regional strategies verses national strategies will prove to be one of the most troublesome aspects of this bill. I believe that in a year's time we will again be debating this bill. I believe that we will then have seen 12 months of activity which will show that we cannot place more emphasis on the national strategy than the regional strategy. I fully agree with those witnesses, numerous as they were, who said to our committee that we had to start from the grassroots and work our way up. I say as some sort of prophecy that we will be looking at this aspect.

As a member of the Joint Statutory Committee on Native Title, I look forward to monitoring the progress of this legislation to ensure that it does what the government says it is going to do, to ensure that it provides for the grassroots for whom this bill was intended, to ensure that vesting land in corporations only does not result in groups of Aboriginal people missing out, to ensure that the ILC remains accountable for its decisions and to ensure that it makes the most appropriate decisions where there is a conflict of interests. After all, there is a limited fund and there will be competing interests. We will have Aboriginal groups vying with each other for land grants and grants for land maintenance. It will be interesting to see how the Indigenous Land Corporation applies its decision making process.

I make those comments for the record because I believe this bill proceeded without sufficient consultation and that the select committee which travelled around this country demonstrated that quite vividly. I say to the government that, if it is going to tackle any further bill of this sort, if it is going to embark on any further social legislation, it must consult and consult widely. That was not the case with this bill or the Native Title Bill. The government seems hell-bent on achieving a political agenda; that is, getting this bill through before the next election so that it can go to the Australian people and say, `We did this, that and everything for those in need and for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.' The real question is whether the government did what it did effectively. Did it really provide an instrument whereby those who are dispossessed will be adequately recompensed? That has to be the question at the end of the day. It is not a question of whether the government consulted with some major entities or main role players in the Aboriginal industry, went away and then came up with a political solution. The question is whether it really addressed the needs of those who have been dispossessed over the course of time.

There has been some comment that this bill is for those who have lost their traditional ties with the land. That is so because the Native Title Act provided in the preamble that there should be a provision for those who could not claim native title. I say to the government that it would be totally unfair if there were a biased view that this land fund bill should be used only for the more remote areas of this country. This land fund is available for all Aboriginal people, including those who happen to live in suburbs in densely populated cities, not just for those who are living in the more remote areas. It seems to me that there is some misconception about this matter.

In the course of our committee's travels to built-up areas, there were Aboriginal people living in such areas who had long since been dispossessed of any land but who are just as entitled to be considered under this legislation as any other member of their race. I will be monitoring that aspect very carefully to make sure there is an even-handed approach; that those in the city are catered for, those in the country are catered for and those in the remote areas are catered for. This is not just an instrument to be used for favourites.

I support the bill. However, there is one flaw, and it is something that the government might take on board. As stated in annexure A and in the second reading speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), amendments 36 to 40 as proposed by the coalition and the Greens were to be adopted. There seems to be some problem because in the bill amendment 39 relates to clause 192D(3), which states:

The Minister may grant the Indigenous Land Corporation Chairperson leave of absence, other than recreation leave, on such terms and conditions as to remuneration or otherwise as the Minister determines in writing.

SPEECH.PARA: As I recall—and I am referring to the list of amendments as contained in the report of the Senate Select Committee on the Land Fund Bill—amendment 39 was in fact put forward by the Greens to omit the word `Minister' and substitute `Indigenous Land Corporation Board'. This bill was supposed to be a replica of the original bill and was supposed to have adopted word for word those amendments which have been set out in annexure A to the Prime Minister's second reading speech.

PARA.TAB: I am telling the Senate that there is a mistake because, when you read that amendment and its brief description, it states that the ILC board, rather than the minister, is to approve certain terms and conditions for ILC directors. The bill that I have been provided with via the chamber certainly has that flaw in section 192D(3). If the government does intend to adopt that amendment, it is going to have to change the wording. If it had intended this to act as a trigger for a double dissolution, it would have been in trouble because this does not incorporate the amendment word for word that was put by this chamber.

You could have used this bill only if it was an accurate replica of the original bill with those amendments that you chose to adopt, but you have chosen to adopt an amendment which has not been faithfully reproduced. It is not the amendment word for word; therefore, I submit, with respect, we would have been considering a different bill. So you could not say this could have provided you with a trigger. If you thought you were being smart, you were not. In fact, I would advise you strongly to have a look at that amendment, because you have adopted all the other amendments which replaced the word `Minister' with `ILC Board', and I see no reason why that should not be followed through in this case. That is just another piece of advice for the government in my submission today.

This most important piece of legislation is part of a package, as indicated by the government. As Senator Kernot and Senator Chris Evans have said, it is phase 2 of a package of three. I ask the government to try to handle the next phase a lot better than it handled the previous two. It would help if it consulted with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community at large. It does not take that much.

The select committee did a very good job over the two weeks that it consulted with the community at large and covered a good deal of ground. The government, with all its resources, could easily do the same job, if not a better one. Unfortunately, I suspect that these words will go unheeded. Senator Campbell, who was the chairman of that committee, regrets that he could not be here today to support this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —For good reason!

—For a very good reason. I think the Senate owes his wife a debt of gratitude because she had a child on the weekend which has kept Senator Campbell away from the chamber which, as he said to me, has no doubt shortened the proceedings today. He regrets that he is unable to make a contribution. He did a very good job as the chairman of that committee and has taken a keen interest in this bill, but the birth of his son, Douglas Andrew, has kept him away. No doubt he will make a contribution at a later stage.

PARA.TAB: I commend the bill to the Senate. I look forward in the next 12 months to scrutinising the progress of this bill and to looking at both the positive aspects of the bill and those which need improvement. I suggest the government not be biased in its approach to this bill. If there are some aspects which do not work, then address them. The Native Title Act has demonstrated to a large degree a lack of efficacy. In fact, there is one view in the west that it is totally unworkable. My view tends to that view. I believe that vast changes to the act are needed, and it would be irresponsible if the government did not face up to them.

Mr Justice French is reported in today's Australian as suggesting that sweeping changes are needed. Even Aboriginal groups themselves have suggested that. Let us not play politics and turn a blind eye to amendments when they are needed. Let us look at these two pieces of legislation and, in a rational manner, address them and make them workable for all Australians. I hope that this bill does work, but if it needs amendment let us have the courage to face that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly on this new Land Fund and Indigenous Land Corporation (ATSIC Amendment) Bill to support my colleague Senator Ellison and to try to answer some of the smirks or points Senator Chris Evans made on the other side. This bill is for indigenous people who have been dispossessed of land in the last 207-odd years since European settlement in Australia. The bill enables the same people to purchase land, acquire land—whatever you like to call it—where they cannot make a claim under the Mabo legislation.

PARA.TAB: An amount of $45 million will be set aside in a perpetual fund for the Indigenous Land Corporation to make these purchases. The allocated $45 million is not a very big sum, but it is rather symbolic. I will certainly be waiting to see what will be done with it. That money is there for Aborigines to acquire land, to manage that land and to provide economic, environmental, social and cultural benefits. We have been told that in this case the Indigenous Land Corporation will be setting up a national strategy to carry out the tasks ahead.

If I can go over each of the points I have made, firstly, acquiring land is quite easy if you have the necessary finance and, of course, if the land is available. Secondly, to manage that land is a bit harder. As one who has been on the land—managing land, acquiring land but not selling it very often in my time in business—I can tell you that managing land is slightly different from acquiring it, and Senator Chamarette is nodding in assent. You manage land to provide economic benefit.

Some of those corporations might have a few surprises coming. I do not know what type of land they have in mind, but I presume it is mostly pastoral land, the sort of land that Aborigines prefer to wander over and carry out their cultural activities. If anyone looks today at the pastoral industry in Australia and the difficulties it has been having, they might think twice as to whether it is such a good idea to buy these big pieces of land. Pastoral stations are especially quite cheap to buy, and there are quite a few willing sellers these days, but when you acquire land that is when the work starts, that is when the thinking starts and that is where the extra finance has to start.

It is all very well to say that there is a pastoral station on the market down the road in the Kimberleys, the Pilbara or the eastern goldfields of Western Australia. Excuse me for using the Western Australian regions, but they are the ones I know best. When buying a pastoral lease for $1 million—that is, one forty-fifth of the amount available—you have to look at ongoing costs and at paying the wages bill. I presume that if Aborigines are going to run a lease themselves—and there are not too many pastoral leases that they have bought that really run themselves—they will still have to pay themselves, so there will be a real wages bill.

Paying that million dollars to pick up a pastoral property with a few head of cattle or sheep on it is only the beginning. There is a lot of ongoing cost. You have to buy fodder if you need it. You have to buy fencing and pay for its upkeep. Then there is the upkeep on windmills. These things do not look after themselves; you have to attend to them if you want a viable operation.

Even if you only want to live on the place, you have to keep up the windmills and the power generators. You have to do all those sorts of things and a lot of these people will have a lot to learn. After a few years they might wish they had stayed where they were rather than taking on such a venture. But I wish them well in their endeavours.

I do not believe that the economic situation provided for by this legislation will improve the lot of Aboriginals very much. When you pay the $1 million that I talked about for a pastoral lease, or a farm for that matter—I talk about pastoral leases in particular because these people are more suited to that sort of thing—that $1 million station will provide a good income for, say, two couples only. That is the sort of population I envisage on a pastoral lease.

Perhaps there will be Aborigines living on these places who are still supported by social security; I do not know. But I thought that this fund was designed to allow Aborigines to support themselves. In that case, there will be a lot of surprises when the time comes. My good friend Senator Brownhill, who is a farmer from northern New South Wales, knows the cost of running a farm or pastoral operation these days and—

TALK.START.PARA: —Especially under Labor Party policy.
—Yes, that is true. No doubt these pastoral leases run by Aboriginal corporations will have to adhere to the Labor Party policies and small business loadings that apply to everybody else.

PARA.TAB: If you have $45 million available each year and you buy 45 properties at $1 million each, you would probably only generate an income providing a reasonable standard of living for about four times 45, which is about 180 people. I want the government to listen to that. It may be an economic lesson.

It has been said that this legislation will provide environmental benefits. I want to look at that proposition. A pastoral station, a farm, or whatever, has a lot of environmental responsibility. You cannot overstock it but it is not much good understocking it either because then the weeds come up and start to gallop away. Even worse, after that you have to control them by use of chemicals. I am sure that Senator Chamarette's hair would stand on end if she even thought about that—but we should all think about it.

Environmental upkeep on a station is fairly high. You need fencing to keep stock out of some places and in other places. All those sorts of things have to be considered in farm management. Then there is flood damage and the damage caused by cyclones which has to be repaired. So it not all plain sailing.

On the subject of social benefits, I am sure there will be some as a result of Aborigines being able to live in areas where their forefathers lived and with which they have cultural associations. But on the social side things might not be so rosy. Most Aboriginal people these days live in urban areas. Plenty of ordinary Australians would not trade the easy life of urbanised areas, especially in places like Canberra and Sydney and in the south-west of Western Australia, to go to the stations and outback life. Our pastoral industry is kept going by a dedicated few. But that is something we will see in due course.

No doubt the ILC will develop strategies—I certainly hope that it will—but in time I would like to see monitoring of the land fund to know what is happening. Every day that I have been in this place I have heard the Labor government telling us that it is the only one that cares for the Aboriginals, the only one that cares for ethnic and other smaller groups in Australia. But let us look at the Aborigines.

The government claims that billions of dollars have been spent on them but unfortunately there has not been too much benefit. We only have to look at health. This is not a health debate, it is a debate about helping Aboriginal people, but the health situation of the communities I visit on a regular basis around Western Australia has not improved very much. Housing has not improved very much. The school retention rate has not improved very much.

One of these days there will have to be performance indicators, of which we will have to take note to see where we are going with that sort of spending. This bill provides for an amount of only $45 million per annum. In a federal budget, that is nothing. But it still has to be accounted for, whether it is $45 million or $45, as far as I am concerned. I will be keeping an eye on accountability. Of course, if you happen to question one of these social programs you are branded a redneck but I intend to keep questioning it.

There occurred last week a black day for Western Australia, a day made even blacker by the way our own newspaper, the West Australian, treated the decision of the High Court. Western Australia is in a unique situation, although no-one on the other side wants to believe it, in that only seven per cent of Western Australia is held freehold. During the Mabo debate here in November and December of 1993 Senator Gareth Evans said time and time again that pastoral leases wiped out native title. If you check Hansard you will see that he said that time and time again.

Why is it that all of a sudden, with up to 93 per cent of Western Australia under the hammer, people are now saying that it is for the court to decide where pastoral leases extinguish native title? I hope that is not to be decided by the same court that brought down the decision last week because Western Australia has special circumstances. If someone could guarantee me that pastoral leases extinguished native title, as we were told in this chamber time and time again, I would not be so worried about last week's decision. But I can tell you that it was a black day for Western Australia and you ain't seen the end of it yet.The Australian last weekend said:

The president of the National Native Title Tribunal, Justice French, is preparing for the Court Government to ask him to make thousands of Mabo-style rulings in what may be an attempt to sabotage the system.

Justice French told The Australian yesterday that although he wanted State government cooperation in the wake of Western Australia's defeat in the High Court, it was possible for claims to be successfully negotiated without its involvement.

SPEECH.PARA: Successfully negotiated without involvement? That is if you apply for a mining title, which only takes two months to go through the mines office in Western Australia. That is if you run then the gauntlet of mediation, because you have a native title tribunal and then mediation, and then it goes on to the Federal Court if you cannot decide. How many have been fixed up in mediation in Western Australia since native title was introduced? There have been two. Does anyone in this place know how many mining titles are issued in Western Australia in a year? Does anyone know that? A mining title does not last forever. A mining company might hold it for three months and then release it. It might hold it for six months and release it. It might hold it forever. About 10,000 per year are processed by the mines department of Western Australia and its tribunals. The Australian went on to say that the two major Aboriginal legal bodies indicated yesterday they would immediately challenge some of the 10,000 mining applications in Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: What do people want? Our legislation in Western Australia does not stand up. We have 10,000 applications a year. When we try to put matters before the federal tribunal we are told that we are trying to plug the system up. You tell me where else people can go. I do not know how many mining titles are issued in Victoria and New South Wales, though most are on private land where native title is already extinguished. You tell me where Western Australia can send those 10,000 applications every year. You tell me where there is a tribunal. How many applications has the federal tribunal dealt with? You can count on your hand the ones it has dealt with in two years. What will you do with the 10,000 applications in Western Australia every year? And of those 10,000 that are held up every year, who will recompense the investors in mining and the people that are employed in mining? There are four times as many people employed in the manufacturing sector which supplies the mines as in mining itself—for example, the surveyors and the transport people who rely on mining for their income.

Since Richard Court got into power in Western Australia unemployment in Western Australia has dropped from 11.6 per cent to 7.5 per cent. He has created employment. He was elected to provide more jobs and better government. What will happen to the growth in the economy if the federal tribunal takes as long to process those 10,000 titles as it has to process other matters?

What will happen to those titles? There is no reaction coming from the other side. Someone has to give us some answers before long. The government had better get some pretty good advice before long. The best thing it can do is to take on Justice French's other suggestions—except that he thinks Western Australia is going to try to clog the system up and wreck the system. The government had better take up some of the ideas about speeding up the situation so that those 10,000 titles will be dealt with. It is not only the Western Australian economy that will suffer. You can be as broad as you like. It will be all of Australia that will suffer.

As Senator Ellison and Senator Alston said, we are supporting this bill. But I believe that, as Senator Ellison said, it will not be very long before we are back in this chamber looking at further amendments—as we will for the Native Title Bill in time also—because it will not work. I certainly hope the Native Title Bill works. With my experience in land management, I will be looking at it carefully. The bill has our blessing and we hope that it is going to work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot of words have been said but I want to put my words on the public record to indicate the Greens' view of this new presentation of the Land Fund and Indigenous Land Corporation (ATSIC Amendment) Bill. I acknowledge that the legislation is part of the government's three-stage package in response to the High Court's decision on native title, the first stage being the Native Title Bill. It has been said that approximately five per cent of Aboriginal people may stand to gain from that native title legislation. At this point, 12 months or more down the track, we have not had any Aboriginal people gain, so the number of people who do gain by that provision may be much smaller than five per cent.

PARA.TAB: The second part of the three-stage package concerns the land fund and the bill that we are looking at at the moment. The government said on this fund that it would deal with the land needs of the remaining 95 per cent of Aboriginal people who do not stand to gain from the native title legislation. Of course, we are yet to see a full response to the social justice package that has been proposed in recent days by the reconciliation council to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). The Greens have expressed repeatedly our disappointment with the proposal and its total failure to meet its aim to address the dispossession of 95 per cent of Aboriginal people over the last 200 years.

The land fund is so small and its operation so constricted that only a small number of people will benefit from it. I am delighted to see that in the presentation of the bill and the second reading speech the language was far more restrained than in earlier times. We did not have the obnoxious reference to the $1.4 billion land fund. I wish the media could recognise the same inaccuracy and restrict their language about it too. The reality of this land fund is that at the very most it will provide $240 million in the next 10 years and extra on what is already available. There will be a draw down of $45 million a year indefinitely as a result of the amount put aside in the consolidated revenue, but that will be largely eaten up, as the debate earlier has showed, not only in management costs but also in administration of the fund itself. So we see a small amount developing.

The government has developed a strategy that has been looking at Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people as three groups. One is those who have been least damaged by the impact of colonisation, seizure of lands and extinguishment of native title. That is the group of people who are fortunate enough to still be on their land and be able to disprove any claims by governments that their native title has been extinguished over the last 200 years. The second group is those who may be able to gain assistance from this land fund and gain access to this fund to buy back some country, and presumably pastoral leases will be the main target of these, as we can see from the comments of Senator Panizza: a pastoral lease could be expected to be gained for maybe $1 million, but we know that land in the city and in places where urban Aboriginal people live would scarcely be available. That means that the amount that is available will primarily be used in the country.

I am indebted to Senator Panizza for having far greater experience on this matter than me. He pointed out the total inadequacy of the amount, the way in which it will be eaten into by management requirements and the way in which the environmental concerns and the capacity to support numbers of Aboriginal people will be severely impeded by the lack of funds.

The third group are those who have been totally removed from their country and sometimes not even able to acknowledge what part of the country they were taken from. This is because, over the last 200 years, a lot of them were taken in childhood. Those who have been most damaged by colonisation will be last in the queue for this land fund. It is highly unlikely that they will ever gain anything from it.

What we basically have is a land fund that will meet the needs of a very small number of people. Obviously there have been different views across Australia amongst Aboriginal people, and they revolve around the same dilemma that the Greens have expressed: do we put in place legislation that satisfies a small number—it may be a key number, but it is a small number—who stand to gain, and leave the large percentage of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people dispossessed and, with their dispossession, unaddressed?

Accepting the land fund means accepting the fact that we will fail to a large degree to address those Aboriginal people who stand to gain nothing from this land fund. In fact, the existence of the land fund penalises them, because it allows the government to pretend that it has redressed the injustice of that dispossession. Senator Gareth Evans referred to this bill as a bill which establishes:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a very substantial perpetual fund, and an Indigenous Land Corporation to use and administer that fund.

I think the key test of the amount of the fund is how much impact it has on the budget deficit this year. Because if it is a $1.4 billion fund—which, fortunately, most people realise it is not—it would presumably have a $1.4 billion impact on the deficit. If it is one-tenth of that amount, it is a similar amount. The reality is that the budget will increase by $24 million this year and each year after, and the budget deficit will diminish by $24 million for the next X number of years beyond the 10 years.

PARA.TAB: That is the symbol of what this government is prepared to do to redress the dispossession of Aboriginal people. That is why I feel a great disappointment with the opposition for its unwillingness to hold out a bit longer on this government and support the amendments that were raised and supported right around the country during the process of the Senate Select Committee on the Land Fund Bill. I think it is a disappointment. I can only assume that the opposition believes that tying Aboriginal people down to a pittance is better than nothing. I will quote from a statement by the Jandu Yawuru Women's Group, because I believe it sums it up very adequately. The women said:

SPEECH.PARA: With this piece of legislation Aboriginal people find themselves "caught between a rock and a hard place". It's tempting to grab whatever it is that is offered, especially when nothing was being offered to begin with. Country must be protected now, and land acquisition may be the best way to do this. Culture and tradition associated with that land must be protected and maintained now.
The women in that delegation went on to make some very cogent points. They stated:

Whilst supporting the intent of the amendment bill, several of the amendments need to be reviewed. The point must be made that organisations such as ATSIC have the most to gain from both the original and amendment bill, and have the resources to lobby Aboriginal people in this matter. What other alternatives to the Indigenous Land Corporation have been put to Aboriginal people that reflects less centralised and more regional control, and that are true to Aboriginal self-determination?

I think that is a very valid point. If this bill is passed as it is, it will be a great disappointment to all those people who appeared before the committee and urged us to assert the inadequacy of the amount. In fact, that point was unanimous. I do not think there was anyone who did not refer to the inadequacy of the amount in the land fund and want more. Several submissions stated this; I cannot actually count them. One submission which was put at the Dubbo hearing of the Senate select committee urged us to reject the bill as proposed. It said:

While the Senate amendments improve what would otherwise be very paternalistic and regressive legislation, the funding is far too inadequate for the Bill to be treated seriously. The original Bill undermines all the struggles of Aboriginal peoples in the last forty years to end Government paternalism and to demonstrate that they are capable of making their own decisions and that they should be allowed to do so.
It went on:

The funding currently proposed for the Fund is completely inadequate. It represents an increase of only $25 million per year on what is already provided. The inadequacy of funding is likely to create conflict between Aboriginal communities and may see a disproportionate amount of the funding spent on management rather than on acquisition. This will disadvantage people who have no land.

We think the amount of the fund, because of the agreement between the opposition and the government, will not be addressed. Nevertheless, while Senator Evans has expressed the view that he would like this bill to pass unanimously in the chamber, the Greens cannot allow it to go by in that way. We will flag amendments that relate to the size of the land fund, the restrictiveness caused by it being held only by corporations, the disposal of surplus land, the fact that there is no statement which says that this is not to be regarded as compensation for dispossession and the revival of native title.

PARA.TAB: A final point was also raised by the Jandu Yawuru Women's Group relating to the gender balance on the ILC board. I will discuss that now because it has not been raised before. While the Jandu Yawuru Women's Group was making its statement to the Senate select committee, it presented something that had not been presented before. Certainly a question had been asked about gender representation, but basically the group recommended that there should be three Aboriginal women selected amongst the Aboriginal members of the board in order to ensure that those who stand to gain from this land fund are able to reflect on women's concerns, contact and connection with the land.

So that is a further amendment that will be introduced into this bill for the very good reason that Aboriginal women took the trouble to come to the committee. Two delegations of women appeared before the committee: one in Darwin and the other in Broome. I believe that it does them justice to at least flag that point; whether or not it gains support is a moot point.

Again, I repeat the fact that the amendments that the Greens will move are largely designed to place on the public record our disappointment with this bill, the land fund and the government's response to the land needs of Aboriginal people. In his speech on this matter, Senator Evans said:

SPEECH.PARA: The original bill, with all the Senate's amendments, has been laid aside in the House of Representatives, and will expire when that house is prorogued for an election. So, the decks have finally been cleared for the parliament to approve this great measure of social justice.

That is why the Greens will be presenting just a small number of the amendments that it presented earlier. In the main they are not the ones that had support, although some are. We will be doing so because in the future there will be no other record of the concerns about that bill and we would like them on the record for this particular bill.

PARA.TAB: As I indicated before, the Greens are disappointed. But we feel that the opposition's bipartisan support with the government does two beneficial things: firstly, it reassures at least some Aboriginal people that a token attempt has been made to look at their land needs and that this may augur well for bipartisan approaches that should not be used as political footballs in election processes; and, secondly, it prevents the government from taking, quite unjustifiably, a high moral stand on this particular land fund. Government senators cannot complain that they are the only ones who want to see the land needs of Aboriginal people addressed.

Unfortunately for the Greens, the opposition is willing to tolerate the low level of funding available for Aboriginal people through this land fund, but at least it means that it is bipartisan and will not be used as a political football. I put on record that I heard the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) make his first election promise, which was that, should the coalition be elected, it will support the amendments as passed in the Senate.

I believe that this is worth while, but I am extremely disappointed on behalf of all Aboriginal people who have not been adequately consulted before the design of this fund and who would have liked to have seen something far better produced if it were really to achieve the high words that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) spoke when he announced the fund during the debate on the Native Title Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will, as is known in the chamber, not be opposing the passage of the Land Fund and Indigenous Land Corporation (ATSIC Amendment) Bill, but I place on the record that National Party senators have reservations about the format of the government's legislation. We stand side by side our Liberal Party colleagues in believing that exemplary work was done when the predecessor of this bill was first presented and in the work that was done by Senator Ian Campbell and by Senator Chris Ellison. I think their work has been first class in terms of seeking to achieve a better result in the legislation. It is to the government's shame that it ignored the recommendations of the Senate—the Senate's amendments. It is to the government's eternal shame that it saw base political advantages being more important and therefore sought to bring in this other bill.

PARA.TAB: I make it very clear that, as far as the National Party is concerned, there are manifest defects in legislation which says that Aboriginal people are not to be trusted with freehold title to land. Earlier in the second reading debate, Senator Chris Evans from the other side of the chamber said that this legislation was important because it was the first time there was a recognition that Aboriginal people had rights. Leaving aside the mammoth political hyperbole in that, I doubt the extent of a right we give to people if we do not trust them to exercise judgment in relation to their rights.

My friend on the other side of the chamber Senator Cooney may wish to think about how valuable a right is if it is a right which is curtailed. Senator Cooney and I could get into an interesting philosophical discussion here. A right which is limited in a fashion such that it is less than a right that somebody else may have in similar situations is not much of a right at all. That is my concern. This government legislation says that Aboriginal people are not to be given freehold title to the land in question which is purchased—it is to be under the control of a corporation—and they are to be precluded from enjoying the benefits of a freeholder.

Here there is a problem in the government's arguments because the only defence for that is saying that we do not trust Aboriginal people not to sell the land. If one argues that we do not trust Aboriginal people not to sell the land, it becomes very difficult to continue sustaining the argument that there is a particular special significance. Surely if there is a special significance for Aboriginals in holding land, it is appropriate that we trust them to preserve that special significance.

The government wishes to have its cake and eat it too on this issue, because it wishes to say, `There is a special significance to Aboriginal people in the land but, having said that, we're not going to trust them that they will not sell it.' There is the conundrum. Ultimately, the government is condemned forever and a day to a paternalistic attitude that says, `We don't believe Aboriginal people are capable of exercising proper judgment in relation to these issues.' There is a yawning gulf between the Labor Party, the government, on that side and the coalition, the opposition, on this side because we believe it is time that we ended the era of paternalism.

This legislation seeks to perpetuate paternalism for political motives. If one accepts the argument that we should search for a form of land-holding which is, in as close a sense as possible, consistent with the land tenure that Aboriginal groups had prior to white settlement, the way to do it is not to put the land in a corporation but to entrust the land on trust to elders. Surely that is more consistent with traditional Aboriginal concepts of the holding of land. Yet, we have this argument that we have to have a corporate structure. A corporate structure is entirely alien to traditional Aboriginal concepts of holding land, but a corporate structure is very useful for the government because it lets it utilise corporations for political advantage. Make no bones about it: that is exactly what will happen.

While we wish to be as bipartisan as we can on these issues, we have a moral obligation to the people of Australia to point out where the government will use this legislation for its political benefit and not for the benefit of Aboriginal people generally. That is undoubtedly the case. By denying Aborigines freehold title to land, this government denies individuals an opportunity to better their lot. It denies individuals the opportunity to have control of their own destiny. That is what the government will do with the passage of this legislation.

What I am saying on behalf of the National Party is that we have grave reservations about many of the provisions of this legislation. Our point of view is that there should be no special laws for people on the basis of the colour of their skin. The government cannot say that this is a special law for people on the basis of the colour of their skin because, after all, the government has said that this is to rectify wrongs which occurred in the past. So there is no argument—no moral argument, no political argument, no argument based even on utility—which can justify the government then saying that it will make things special. Special laws really advantage the people at whom they are aimed. Special laws—this is an experience around the world—marginalise. Special laws condemn groups of people to the periphery of mainstream society.

I believe very firmly that we have an obligation to ensure that the Australian community is as integrated and as equal as possible. I think it should be on the record that government senators who support these provisions and support the denial of freehold title are in their own way perpetuating the inequality about which the government complains. It is as simple as that.

There are other issues which we have reservations about. Those issues will be dealt with after the next election when the coalition government has the opportunity to right the wrongs to Aboriginal people which will be created by this legislation. I do not wish to delay the further passage of this legislation through the Senate, but I put the Labor Party on notice by saying that after the next election things will change and the Aboriginal people of Australia will soon realise that the government has sold them a pup and in many ways it has not taken a real and genuine interest in their needs. This legislation is proof of that and we will rectify that situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this is a happy day for Australia because, as Senator O'Chee has indicated, the Land Fund and Indigenous Land Corporation (ATSIC Amendment) Bill is supported by both sides of the chamber. Of course, there has been the usual shouting and tumult that must go on in the parliament, but the bottom line in this debate on this legislation is that all senators other than the Greens support the legislation.

PARA.TAB: As senators would be aware, all senators on the opposition side are free to vote as they like. I do not think for one moment that those opposite are concerned about a double dissolution. I think they are people of principle. It is very exciting to see that all opposition senators will be voting for this bill with enthusiasm. The points we have heard in this debate today are points worth debating. I think we should all be congratulated for arriving at this position.

Senator Chamarette has said that she will move 21 amendments to the bill—which she has said she expects to be defeated—at the committee stage, but even so, at one point in her speech, she congratulated the other parties in this chamber for coming to an agreement on this bill. Senator Chamarette says that the main thrust of her objection is that not enough money has been allocated in this regard. There is never enough money for the various things that government must do—there are always more schools to be built, more health services to be provided and we could go on and on. The fact of the matter is that the amount that has been agreed upon will be endorsed by a near unanimous vote of this chamber.

Senator Chamarette says that the Aboriginal people of Australia have been sorely abused over the years. That is absolutely true. Her position is that the community ought to give one per cent of government receipts to Aboriginal people. That would not be sufficient to make up for what has happened over the years. We have to look at the current situation and see what can be done to improve it.

If we took Senator Chamarette's argument to its logical conclusion, we would find that she would say that we should give the land back to the Aboriginal people. That is inconsistent with her proposition that, at the same time, we should bring in more migrants and help the boat people who come from overseas. That might be a logical proposition when taken on its own, but it is an illogical proposition when taken with the proposition that Aboriginal people should be entitled to what they lost in the past.

I do not want to debate this bill for too long, but I do point out, however, that we have reached a position where we have agreement across the chamber except for the Greens and all parties have embraced this legislation. The first paragraph of an article in today's Australian headed `CRA chief hails Mabo law as opportunity for partnership' states:

The new chief executive of Australia's biggest mining company, CRA Ltd, yesterday applauded the Federal Government's Native Title Act for providing opportunities for more exploration and partnerships with Aborigines.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill before us today will improve the current position of Aborigines. This is by no means the end of the matter. Aboriginal people will no doubt be pressing for more from the community and will be doing more for themselves as the years go by. I venture to say that there are many people of Aboriginal descent who are now much better off than they would have been had the money that some people are complaining about having spent on them not been spent. In 20 years from now their position will be even better.

PARA.TAB: It is in that light that I say that this is a happy day. This position we have achieved where we have near unanimity on this legislation was not reached easily. Some people have laboured long and hard to get this legislation to the point where it is now. I am not just referring to the Prime Minister (Mr

SPEECH.PARA: Keating), the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) who headed up the team that prepared the legislation. I am also referring to those people, some of whom are in the chamber today, who have worked hard in the background.

PARA.TAB: I think we sometimes forget the amount of work that is done on our behalf by those in the Public Service. They are oftentimes the butt of jokes or criticism. Unlike us, they are not able to answer the charges made against them which are usually most unjust. I will mention, no doubt to their embarrassment, those who were part of the team that has prepared this legislation that has been so well received, will be voted on soon and will be passed by an overwhelming majority of senators. The people involved were Sandra Ellims, John Van Beurden, Caroline Edwards, Michelle Cannane and Dorothy Leedie. I think it is proper that we acknowledge their work. I am sure the Prime Minister, Senator Evans and Mr Tickner would endorse with great enthusiasm my acknowledgment of the work of that team. I pay tribute to those people for bringing this legislation before us today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is gratifying to the government that the coalition has finally seen the sense of the situation and agreed to pass the Land Fund and Indigenous Land Corporation (ATSIC Amendment) Bill 1994 in a form which will be efficient in practice and defensible in principle. It is a matter of regret that the same still cannot be said of the Greens. One would have wished that the opposition's motives in this matter had been a bit more exalted than simply the fear of fighting a double dissolution election in a policy area in which they continue to feel profoundly embarrassed—or if they do not, they should.

PARA.TAB: It would have been preferable if the opposition had approached this issue with a real sense of understanding of the significance of the issues involved and a sense of grace about the great changes that are involved, with the enactment of both the native title legislation itself and this companion piece of legislation, the second stage of the government's response to the historic Mabo decision, establishing the land fund and recognising and making provision for recompense for the dispossession which has been suffered by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples.

It would have been nice if the opposition had shown the same sort of grace and acknowledgment of the issues of principle involved as was shown in the speech yesterday by the new chief executive of CRA, Leon Davis, who did say—in what was clearly a groundbreaking change of position for his organisation and one which I hope will signal a similar change of direction for the whole mining industry—that he was `satisfied with the central tenet' of the act. He said further that the Native Title Act:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . "laid the basis for better exploration access and thus increased the probability that the next decade will see a series of CRA operations developed in active partnership with the Aboriginal people".

That particular statement, which has been referred to by a couple of other speakers today, was appropriately responded to by Noel Pearson, the director of the Cape York Land Council, when he described those comments by the CRA chief as an `absolute milestone' in the relationship between Aborigines and the mining industry in Australia. He said further that the statement:
. . . showed a "culture change" more tolerant of Aborigines was about to sweep across the mining sector—a change that would have been inconceivable just two years ago.

It is worth recording for posterity the cartoonist Nicholson's response to all this in the Australian today when, under the heading `The sensitive new-age miner', we have a depiction of a miner standing on a rock with his arm around an Aboriginal Australian, with the Aboriginal saying to himself, `Well, bugger me. Next it'll be John Howard.' One hopes that it would be John Howard next. So far, unhappily, there has been no sign of that in terms of the basic response of this opposition to the Native Title Act, which it is still talking about fundamentally amending when it gets the chance.

PARA.TAB: There has been no fundamental change of heart, it seems, in what those opposite are saying about the proposed land fund act, because they are talking about making further amendments to that, if and when they get a chance. There has not been a change of heart in the attitude to Aboriginal cultural sensitivities, as is revealed by the extraordinary saga over the Hindmarsh documents affair over the last week, where Mr Howard continues to stand behind his former front bench spokesman, Mr McLachlan, after Mr McLachlan engaged in what must be the most tawdry and unpalatable little exercise in recent Australian politics in distributing and photocopying sensitive documents, as he did, for crude political advantage in circumstances of the utmost sensitivity for the Aboriginal people involved.

I say all that because, although we are obviously pleased that there has been a sufficient change of heart on the part of the opposition to enable us to get this land fund legislation through, it unhappily does not seem to presage the kind of change of heart, change of mind and change of attitude that really would mean something for the Aboriginal people in this country. One can only hope that that will eventually occur.

We are pleased that the coalition has not insisted on those of its amendments which would have made the ILC a statutory body excessively bound by legislative prescription. We simply hope that the coalition's threats to amend the bill, when and if it ever attains government, will fade away once the ILC is given the opportunity to prove itself under the flexible and autonomous approach that the bill provides for. In the end, a good piece of legislation does seem to have triumphed. The ILC will be able to get on with the job of acquiring and managing land on behalf of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

We will be moving quickly to ensure that the ILC is set up by the end of the financial year. I am confident that, if there are any continuing differences in opinion on the part of various Aboriginal organisations or particular members of the affected community, then those will be capable of easily being resolved once the ILC is up and running.

I want to place on record the government's appreciation of the very helpful and constructive role which indigenous organisations have played throughout the long and difficult course of framing this legislation. I am not excluding those organisations which disagreed with some aspects of the bill. Differences of opinion are to be expected in relation to any piece of legislation, particularly a complex piece of legislation. They are hardly surprising in this situation here, given the diversity of circumstances of Australia's indigenous peoples.

I do think the approach taken by the government on this bill has the broad support of the majority of indigenous organisations. I do not think there is any question of gilding the lily in that respect. That is simply the case. ATSIC has been a very strong and effective supporter of this legislation from the outset. Of course we gave very significant weight to the views of ATSIC, the only organisation capable of representing indigenous opinion nationally and the government's adviser on indigenous matters, but we also took into account, and adopted wherever it was possible to do so, the views of other indigenous organisations.

Might I close by repeating Senator Cooney's very gracious tribute to the public servants who have been involved in this very difficult exercise—Sandra Ellims and the rest of the team. It has been an outstanding effort, as I can well testify, having been the beneficiary of their very detailed advice on practical and technical questions as they have arisen. I take it that I will be a further beneficiary of their advice in the committee stage now about to dawn upon us. I certainly hope so, because I could be floundering without it when I look at some of these amendments—God help me—that have been foreshadowed once again by the Greens.

Might I wish the bill a speedy passage, thank those senators who have contributed to the debate and hope that we really are putting in place today a piece of legislation which will live up to the expectations that we all have of it; that is, it is a very serious attempt to address one aspect of the fundamental injustice done to Aboriginal people in this country, by enabling people who have been dispossessed of land and who do not have the opportunity to recapture possession of traditional land at least to have access to land that would be meaningful to them through the process of acquisition and disposition that is provided for in this bill. I commend the bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a series of amendments that have been circulated in the chamber. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) said that he would need help. It is possible that I may also get a little adrift in this because I have not actually seen the drafting of the amendments until this moment, but I do know the principles underlying them. My understanding is that amendments Nos 1 to 4 relate to the size of the land fund, Nos 5 to 13 refer to the corporation aspect of the bill, and then the other amendments follow on. If I may, I want to move my amendments Nos 1 to 4 and then give the minister and anyone else who wishes to come in at that stage an opportunity to respond.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
