SPEECH.PARA: N
where N is the number of days remaining in the first category A year after the commencement of this section.

PARA.TAB: `(2)On the first business day in the second category A year or a later category A year, there is to be credited to the Land Fund 1% of the total Commonwealth revenue collected from all sources in the previous financial year.".

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Clause 3, page 29 (line 21) to page 30 (line 5), omit proposed section 193A, substitute the following section:
" `193A.(1)Monies credited to the Land Fund may not be invested other than in the manner for the time being authorised by an Act or a State or Territory Act for the investment of trust funds.

PARA.TAB: `(2)In each category A year, as far as practicable, not less than 75% of the monies credited to the Land Fund in that year pursuant to section 193 must be invested.".

SPEECH.PARA: 3.Clause 3, page 31 (line 6) to page 35 (line 24) omit proposed sections 193B to 193H.
4.Clause 5, page 46, lines 16 and 17, paragraph (d), omit definition of "category B year".

As I said, the first amendments relate to the size of the land fund. Just very briefly, for the public record, I will go through the reasons for them. Under the legislation, the government will contribute around $1.28 billion to a trust account in the Commonwealth public account called the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund over the next 10 years. The Greens (WA) are concerned that the fund will not be sufficient to meet the land ownership needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and that the fund will not be self-sustaining.

PARA.TAB: The Greens also believe that the fund is unlikely to provide any degree of historical justice for the 95 per cent of Aboriginal people who will not gain anything from the recognition of native title. So our amendment proposes that the House of Representatives amend the bill so that one per cent of total Commonwealth government revenues will be placed in the land fund per annum for 10 years. This would see the government contribution exceed $11 billion at the end of 10 years.

Why have we stipulated the one per cent? There are two reasons that I will briefly put here. The first reason is that it is a substantial sum. It really is the kind of substantial perpetual fund that Senator Evans referred to in his speech. However, it is not substantiated by the amount in the bill we are considering. Therefore, $1 billion a year is a substantial sum which would more satisfactorily address the land needs of Australia's indigenous people. One per cent of total revenue would see a government contribute about $1.12 billion per annum—a genuine billion dollar fund.

The second reason for the one per cent is a historical one. In 1890 when the British handed self-government to Western Australia there was a clause placed in the constitution to ensure that the new government of Western Australia fulfilled its obligations to protect Aboriginal people. Under the clause, one per cent of total government revenue had to be spent on Western Australian indigenous people. The clause disappeared in 1904 and early this year a group of Aboriginal people began a challenge on this issue in the High Court.

It seems to us that if we are addressing historic injustice we ought to look at the historical attempts to redress that injustice that unfortunately have not operated in any way, shape or form within this country. So we felt that one per cent of total government revenue was a really good amount to be put in a land fund when we consider that that government revenue is derived from Australia and from the land of its original indigenous owners. That is all I wish to say about the size of the fund. The amendments come in the form of amendments and requests for amendments. I just leave it to the minister or anyone else to comment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Needless to say the government rejects these particular amendments, as we did last time around, and their companion volumes. The government will be allocating a very sizeable sum of $1.463 billion to the land fund over a 10-year period. Two hundred million dollars has been allocated this year to give the fund a significant base.

PARA.TAB: The annual draw downs from the fund from 1995-96 will be $45 million per annum. This is more than double the $21 million spent by ATSIC on land acquisition and management annually. The ILC will also have the capacity to borrow from commercial sources or to facilitate land-holders borrowing from commercial sources. That will allow significant capital injections into indigenous land based enterprises over and above existing sources of capital.

We really do believe that these amounts represent a significant commitment of Commonwealth moneys consistent with responsible economic management. The Greens' proposal, which is aimed at providing a fund of around $15 billion after 10 years, is completely unrealistic and fiscally irresponsible. The land corporation will be simply unable to handle the sum of about $450 million a year it would have available to spend on land acquisition and management. The availability of such an amount would artificially drive up land prices to the detriment of indigenous interests.

The Commonwealth currently provides around $1.5 billion annually to ATSIC and other agencies to address the needs of indigenous people. If the Commonwealth were to place one per cent of Commonwealth revenues in the land fund, this would amount to around another $1.5 billion annually. While we cannot be certain of Commonwealth revenues collected far into the future if the land fund were outside the public account, this amendment would contribute about $1.5 billion annually to the deficit and that would represent an addition of over 10 per cent to the budget deficit this year, rising to more than half the projected deficit in 1997-98. If the land fund were to remain in the public account, this amendment would add up to $270 million annually to the deficit.

I think the orders of magnitude that we are talking about there, whichever way you approach this, simply put it beyond the pale in terms of our reasonable economic management strategies at the moment. The government has agreed to a Democrats amendment, it will be recalled, which will guarantee a four per cent return after inflation on investments over 10 years. The guarantee of that return is an addition to what is already a pretty sizeable allocation by the government.

We are committed to the reconciliation process. Mabo itself, the decision, the native title legislation and this fund have all advanced that process, but it has to be acknowledged that reconciliation is in its early stages. If we were to irresponsibly allocate around $15 billion to the land fund with no regard to the effects on the broader economy, there is a strong possibility that the reconciliation process itself would be put in jeopardy. I think that adds another dimension to our response to this. I think that point has been made clear enough.

As to amendment No. 2, which goes to the method of investment of land fund moneys and the percentage to be invested, it does appear to us inconsistent to repeal section 193A, as you are proposing, while retaining subsection 192W(3) which provides that land fund moneys have to be invested in accordance with section 62B of the Audit Act. Proposed new subsection (1) adds forms of investment permitted under state and territory laws to those permitted under section 62B of the Commonwealth Audit Act. It really appears that this would provide the lowest common denominator for prudential investments; it would not improve the bill. It is likely to create confusion rather than assist the fund to operate efficiently. In particular, it will never be clear which legislative authority is the basis for fund investments. In the event that the states amend their legislation, the legislative basis for long-term strategies could be undermined conceivably resulting in losses to the fund.

There are similar difficulties with proposed new subsection (2). It would, under the funding arrangements currently contained in the bill, provide a total annual draw down of only $36 million instead of $45 million, that is to say 25 per cent of $121 million. However, the new subsection is no doubt predicated on the bill being amended to provide for the massive funding sought by the Greens in their proposed amendment to section 193A, which the government cannot agree to. It might make sense in the context of such an increase but in the absence of that increase it just makes the bill go backwards.

The proposed new subsection (2) also seems to involve a drafting loophole. As drafted it would allow the ILC to spend the previous year's allocation since the 75 per cent limit here proposed only applies to the year the allocation was credited to the fund. So there are a whole variety of substantial reasons why the government opposes that amendment.

Amendment No. 3 and its companion piece No. 4 are also unacceptable. They, in our judgment, will result in a quite unworkable scheme and the government opposes them on that basis. In removing sections 193B to 193H, as is proposed, this amendment removes from the bill provisions for payments out of the fund to the ILC and ATSIC. It would appear that this would leave no legislative basis for the making of payments out of the fund. The assumption appears to be that the ILC will control the fund and not need some legislative basis. That is an inadequate assumption.

These amendments would remove the requirement for the accounts and financial statements of the fund to be in a form determined by the Minister for Finance, which is presently provided for in section 193H. That again, in our judgment, is an unattractive proposition that further contributes to making the bill unworkable in this form. For all those complex reasons—at least it should show the Greens that we are taking them seriously—the government opposes these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the amendments. I have heard the arguments rehearsed, but I have not seen the amendments.
—They have been circulated.

—No, they have not. Senator Ellison has not seen them either. I have heard you recanvassing things that you have said several times already. I do not think it will change my view, but technically I have not seen what I am about to vote on.

—I apologise. I understood that the amendments had been circulated already. I failed to make that instruction obvious. As Senator Kernot has mentioned, the amendments and their contents have been well rehearsed, apart from a new one today.

PARA.TAB: I wish to respond to Senator Evans's concerns about amendments Nos 2 and 3. The assumption was that there would be an increased amount and not the 75 per cent of the $121 million that the government is intending to put aside by way of this bill. There is the possibility that an increase in the total amount of the fund would be addressed.

As a final comment, I refer to Senator Evans's statement. I am glad he is acknowledging that no substantial hole in the budget deficit is produced by this fund. It is only one of $24 million. We would like to see in a so-called billion dollar land fund at least an attempt to put $1 billion into it, but with the draw down it would be considerably less. It would make clearer the logic of the government in its statements as to how it is addressing the needs of 95 per cent of the Aboriginal people in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to the chamber that perhaps the 62nd contribution that I am making here initially may not be dreadfully relevant to the committee stage of the bill.
—You wouldn't want to break your duck in here, would you, Brian?

—You will appreciate that this measure came on this afternoon before many of us expected. A number of us have been caught up in other meetings. I want to say to the chamber, as I would have said if I had made a speech on the second reading, that I support the legislation. I am very disappointed that all of the work that went into the amendments adopted by this chamber and the discussions undertaken by members of the Senate Select Committee on the Land Fund Bill appears at this stage not to have borne fruit to the extent that most of the amendments are not contained in this piece of legislation that is currently before us.

PARA.TAB: Nevertheless, I also acknowledge that a tremendous amount of work on this particular measure has been done by others in the process. It is not only this chamber that has been involved in the immense amount of work that has gone into the development of the Land Fund and Indigenous Land Corporation (ATSIC Amendment) Bill, and I acknowledge that. I am supporting the legislation with an expression of disappointment that a number of the amendments that we adopted in this place have not been included.

I had the opportunity to hear the last five minutes of Senator Evans's contribution in response to Senator Chamarette. Senator Chamarette has identified a matter which is very much at the heart of this question; it is at the heart of the matter: is our commitment through this legislation going to be more than just words? Is it going to be supported by a substantial monetary commitment?

Having said that, I did hear what Senator Evans said about the difficulty, particularly in the early years, of the fund management in handling that type of money. I also heard the comment that was made about the effect that it would have on land price. That is something that we have to be concerned about. I am not going to go over the argument that we had previously when we debated the amendment regarding consultation with various groups which we wanted in the legislation. Senator Evans might come back at me on that particular matter.

I for one would like to see the government constantly review its practical commitment to the fund. In saying that, I indicate again that I support the legislation but I am disappointed with the fact that most of the amendments were not incorporated into the legislation.
Amendments negatived.
