SPEECH.PARA: These amendments relate to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander corporations. Under the bill, the ILC can carry out its land acquisition functions only for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander corporations. The Greens believe that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people should be able to own land as they see fit and that the bill is far too restrictive on this issue.

PARA.TAB: This topic was raised with the Senate Select Committee on the Land Fund Bill. Many people felt that Aboriginal people should determine the capacity in which they held the land. While some felt that the corporations model, which has worked in other areas through ATSIC, has been a workable one for them, they felt that there was a legitimacy to other means being available and for the communities to be able to make that decision.

We believe that acquired interests in land—that is the purpose of these amendments—may be granted to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander corporations, or Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders, or trustees of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trusts. We have moved these amendments because we believe that Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders should be treated like any other citizens and be allowed to hold their land as they see fit. It is an act of paternalism to do otherwise.

The only outstanding issue would be the definition of `trust'. The Greens WA have adopted a definition which ensures that each person who benefits or is capable of benefiting is an Aboriginal person, a Torres Strait Islander or an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporation. It is our view that the reason why the government has been so restrictive in allowing only corporations to have it is, in a way, imposing a bureaucratic structure upon Aboriginal communities that makes it easier for corporations to be administratively handled. Presumably, if they fold, it makes it easier for the government to reacquire anything that the corporations have had in the time that they have been established.

Many committee hearings noted that Aboriginal people feel that corporations have in some ways done them an injustice. They have forced people to adopt this white bureaucratic convention of a legal entity. Those who are better able to understand those mechanisms have been able to benefit from them, sometimes to the detriment of some Aboriginal families and people within communities, when the corporation has perhaps folded through mismanagement or other problems. It is for that reason the flexibility of these amendments was proposed to be included in this bill—not, as has been publicised, to allow the land to be given to individuals but to prevent the bill from being so restrictive as to allow it only to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander corporations and to allow Aboriginal communities to make their own determination of the entity which wants to hold any land that may be acquired through this fund.

TALK.START.PARA: —On this group of amendments the government's position remains implacably hostile because grants to individuals and trustees threaten to undermine the bill's fundamental purpose, as we see it. This group of amendments was moved by the opposition in both the House of Representatives and the Senate last year. We opposed the amendment then for the same reasons as we do now.

PARA.TAB: The Senate Select Committee on the Land Fund Bill failed to find any consensus among indigenous peoples about this amendment, although a number of witnesses did explicitly endorse the government's original approach to the issue. The coalition's stated rationale for this amendment, and that again now by the Greens, is that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people should be treated like other Australians and should not be required to incorporate in order to have title to land.

Of course, other Australians do not have access to the land fund. This is a special case of unashamed positive discrimination designed to redress a past injustice. The land fund provides for indigenous people an avenue in addition to that available to all Australians to purchase land. Indigenous people will still be free to pursue the ordinary means of acquiring land if they do not wish to be bound by the restrictions on title to land acquired through this fund.

It all really goes back to the fundamental purpose of this whole exercise, which is to give indigenous people back their land and to ensure that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people can enjoy the benefits of their land—land granted to them on this basis—for generations to come. Vestment of ownership incorporations will ensure that the land remains part of the Aboriginal land base for the use of future generations of indigenous people.

Aboriginal people did invariably hold in the past a communal form of title which was inalienable. They are familiar with operating on a collective basis. The Senate select committee purported to establish that individual ownership was traditionally accepted in some indigenous communities and based its argument on the testimony of one Torres Strait islander witness, yet it is abundantly clear from that gentleman's evidence that even he was in no way talking about individual ownership. He was referring to former familial ownership in which the structure of the owning family clearly extended well beyond what we would call a nuclear family.

Grants to individuals run the risk of potentially excluding the rightful traditional owners—I am using the word `traditional' here in a loose sense because we are not talking in this context about people with native title claim as such—who are likely to be communities or groups. Besides being consistent with the fundamental purposes of the land fund bill, ownership by corporations does have some practical advantages. Corporate ownership does strengthen accountability through the statutory requirements which are placed on such bodies, including the need for them to report publicly on their activities. Allowing grants to trustees would mean that non-indigenous individuals and corporations could acquire legal ownership of land under the bill. Even though beneficial ownership would be with indigenous interests, there would not necessarily be a full indigenous ownership contemplated by the bill.

That is a miscellany of points, but they all move in the same direction, which is that of the non-acceptability not so much this time in terms of workability but basic principle—the basic principle being that we want the land base to be maintained and retained for future generations. We see that corporate ownership is not only consistent with known Aboriginal tradition but also by far and away the best way to ensure that that in fact will be the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was the minister saying that the recent select committee had evidence from only one witness in support of the individual ownership of land? I understood him to say that. If it is otherwise, then I stand corrected.

—I am advised that, on the specific question of individual ownership being traditionally accepted in some indigenous communities, there was only one witness. There may well have been more witnesses than that arguing in favour of individual ownership, but on the factual question—the anthropological question, if you like—as to the nature of the ownership tradition I am told that that is so. Everyone is nodding in unison on my left. I do not know whether you want to take on the assembled forces of bureaucratic light over here or whether you will accept that as the explan ation.

—I accept that explanation. It was not quite clear at the outset. Suffice it to say, the coalition has made its position quite clear on this in the past. We will be supporting the bill without this amendment. In my role on the Joint Committee on Native Title, which will now be reviewing the operation of this legislation, I will be maintaining a keen interest in how this provision operates.

—I would like the minister to clarify whether this land fund is designed for the 95 per cent of Aboriginal people who will not be able to assert their rights through native title. I then want him to explain how this can possibly reflect those people for whom communal traditional concepts no longer hold and for whom the corporation structure is a form of white bureaucracy that is being superimposed upon them and in no way reflecting any remnant of `communal, inalienable title', as he referred to it as.

—It is the case that this legislation is primarily designed for those who have been dispossessed and who are unable to recreate a claim in relation to some particular piece of land with which they have maintained traditional attachment. Of course, we have had this discussion often enough. That does not mean, however, that it is inappropriate to think in terms of the closest thing we can get to communal title as being the way to go when we are vesting land in these people. It is not a matter of white bureaucracy; it is the best that white bureaucracy can do to get close to what we are trying to do—that is, to recreate some kind of land base for those people who cannot establish a land base in any other way.

PARA.TAB: It is not just hung on that particular notion. It is also to do with the business of preserving that base as intact as possible intergenerationally for the future. It is linked with the question of alienability, which we are dealing with separately. But the point is a very important one: we want to create from the outset a sense that this particular legislation is designed not to benefit individuals but rather groups—groups of people who are trying by this means to recover some of the heritage which has been lost.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the reasons I supported the previous amendments—and these are similar to those—is that they give flexibility. I have a very great concern, shared by a lot of Aboriginal people, about the decline of job opportunities for Aboriginal people. I think it is fair to say that a greater percentage of Aboriginal people were working during the Great Depression than are working now. That is a very real concern. Admittedly, some of the Aboriginal people working at that time were working in very substandard conditions. That would absolutely not be tolerated and should not have been tolerated then. Nevertheless, in 1995 a great percentage of Aboriginal people are unable to find employment but want it. They want to be able to be creative.

PARA.TAB: I supported the proposals that Senator Chamarette is giving another run to precisely because they would give flexibility to the management of the fund to ensure employment opportunities would be created in its administration. Thus, I believed it was necessary to have a more flexible arrangement than the inflexible one that appears to be in the legislation at this time. I apologise to the committee for raising this matter again but it worries me very much that a number of Aboriginal people who want to be employed and engaged in creative and income generating work do not have the opportunity. Could the government now, or at some stage, give the Senate its views about that very important issue?

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the aspirations we have is that property will be able to be vested for income earning and job generating purposes, for enterprise development purposes. I take very seriously the point Senator Harradine makes. I hope the ILC will bear that objective in mind in disposing of its funds. That said, I do not think the requirement that it be vested in corporate structures rather than individuals would necessarily inhibit flexibility in pursuing that enterprise objective to quite the extent Senator Harradine suggests. It is an interesting point he raises and one that can certainly be kept under review when we look at the way the legislation operates. If there is any unnecessary inhibition of the objectives he is pointing to, we might usefully debate that at some future time in the light of any accumulated data.

PARA.TAB: I do not think Senator Harradine is astray at all in suggesting that that should be a legitimate aspiration for the use of the fund. If employment opportunities can be generated, so much the better. It is not the only objective. The use and enjoyment of land for purposes approximating traditional purposes is a very legitimate usage as well, giving people a sense of space and access to land which urban, dispossessed Aboriginal people might well be craving. It does not necessarily have to have an economic component but there is certainly no reason why it should not and every reason why, at least in part, some funds should be directed to that objective.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point that I was trying to make—and I think it has been borne out by Senator Harradine's comment—is that by restricting the fund to corporations the bill could penalise or disadvantage some Aboriginal people in urban areas for whom a corporation is a very artificial entity—an excessive administrative hoop. They may have natural entities that are more amenable to allowing them that independence. I want to complete this section by reading two quotes that illustrate the dilemma in the Aboriginal community. One is the testimony before the Senate select committee by Sharon Firebrace, the Director of Palm River Pty Ltd and a councillor for ATSIC's Tambukka region. She argued:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the ILC should have the flexibility to make grants of land to individuals, groups and families, as well as corporations. Whilst acknowledging the long-held principle of indigenous community ownership, we must be conscious of the changing place, role and contribution of Aboriginal people in contemporary Australia, particularly urban localities . . . We have fought long and hard for equal rights; let us not be constrained by traditional ownership practices that are foreign to many in contemporary indigenous communities in the south-east of Australia.
The other comment was from the Ballarat and District Aboriginal Cooperative Ltd which maintained:

. . . land [should] be owned by the indigenous people with no conditions or restrictions of their right to make all decisions in respect to the land including the right to sell even after a short period of time . . . Although traditional Aboriginal culture has been for community control/care of the land, we assert that the Aboriginal people should have the same rights as other Australians . . . be it as corporations, individuals, groups of individuals or trustees . . . The argument of Corporations being answerable [to the ILC] is further evidence of government desiring to keep control of and take decision making away from Aboriginal people.

That is the point of these amendments. I concede that the government is not going to move on them but I want it on the public record that it is a paternalistic measure, intended to restrict Aboriginal people from being able to have a real say on how they will own and manage their land.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 14.Clause 3, page 10, line 36, proposed subparagraph 191J(1)(a)(ii)(B), omit "and".
15.Clause 3, page 11, lines 1 to 5, omit proposed paragraph 191J(1)(b).
16.Clause 3, page 11, at end of proposed section 191J add the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: (a)the Indigenous Land Corporation or the subsidiary, as the case requires, proposes to dispose of the interest under subsection (2); and
(b)the interest was acquired by the Indigenous Land Corporation or the subsidiary, as the case requires, for the purpose of making a grant of the interest to:

TAB.TAB: (i)a particular Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporation; or
(ii)a particular Aboriginal person; or
(iii)a particular Torres Strait Islander; or
(iv)trustees of a particular Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trust; and

PARA.TAB: (c)in the case of an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporation or an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trust—the corporation or trust is still in existence at the time of the proposal; and
(d)in the case of an Aboriginal person or a Torres Strait Islander—the Aboriginal person or the Torres Strait Islander is still alive at the time of the proposal;

SPEECH.PARA: the Indigenous Land Corporation or the subsidiary, as the case requires, must consult the corporation, Aboriginal person, Torres Strait Islander or trustee, as the case requires, before disposing of the interest under subsection (2).".

These amendments relate to the disposal of surplus land by the ILC. The bill as it stands permits the ILC or its subsidiaries to dispose of land that it no longer needs to hold. As in the case where the ILC should own or acquire land for the purposes of making a grant to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, the Greens WA believe that it is appropriate that relevant people and bodies be consulted before the ILC disposes of any land.

PARA.TAB: We believe that the bill should require consultation with relevant Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander corporations or Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders or trustees of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander trusts before disposal of any land bought for grants to indigenous people. I was confused about amendments 14 and 15 because we were still including the concept which we have just lost in the previous amendments, a concept of wider ownership possibility than corporations. The bill permits the ILC to gain land that it uses for other purposes to raise money and so on.

The amendments relate to when the ILC has bought land specifically to grant it to an Aboriginal and Torres Islander corporation. We believe that it is only reasonable for those people to be consulted if the ILC decides to dispose of that land prior to granting it. So it is really a mechanism to permit the efficient passing over of the land to the people for whom it has been acquired. It removes the capacity of the ILC to hold on to it or to dispose of it without consulting those people.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government thinks these amendments are unnecessary. There is no requirement for legislative prescription here which might in practice unnecessarily fetter the ILC, bearing in mind here as elsewhere that, whenever you create an obligation to do anything, that immediately becomes litigable by someone who might be minded to make a nuisance of himself, herself or itself in the case of a corporation. You have to have pretty solid grounds before you start cluttering the landscape with those kinds of inhibitions.

PARA.TAB: We see the power to dispose of surplus land as likely to be used in the following situations: first, where the ILC has purchased a parcel of land, only part of which is required for granting to indigenous people. You might well have a situation where part might be required to be sold to assist in the financing of the other part. A second situation which could easily arise as a matter of routine is where land which was originally purchased by the ILC is surrendered to the ILC for disposal on behalf of the land-holders. Another situation could arise where the ILC is unable to find an appropriate body to hold title to land which it has purchased. In the event that there were people affected by the disposal, we would certainly expect the ILC to consult them as a matter of good administration. I think it reasonable to anticipate that that will occur without the need to multiply legislative strictures of this kind.
Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 17.Clause 3, page 17, proposed subsection 191X(2) line 21, omit "at least 4 other", substitute "at least 5 other".
18.Clause 3, page 17, after proposed subsection 191X(2), insert the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: " `(2A) Not less than 50% of the Aboriginal persons and/or Torres Strait Islanders referred to in subsection (2) must be women.".

SPEECH.PARA: I think these amendments are the most exciting amendments because they have not been seen before in the debate. I move them on principle, not that I am unduly unrealistic about the outcome. They relate to the gender balance on the ILC board, and they arise from the views of Aboriginal women in Broome who appeared before the Select Committee on the Land Fund Bill. I believe a reference was also made by Aboriginal women who appeared in Darwin. They wanted to make sure that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women were equally represented on the ILC board. In order to achieve this, it is necessary to increase in the bill the minimum number of Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders from five to six.

PARA.TAB: I am putting these amendments on the record for the Jandu Yawuru women's group. It was one of the best moments in the debate and in the committee's consultations when they asked some questions and made this suggestion regarding representation on the board. They were followed by a group, whose name I cannot immediately recall, I believe from Kununurra. Its members stated that they felt it only just to have three Aboriginal women on the board, but they wanted the male representation not to be penalised by the constriction of up to five Aboriginal representatives on the board of seven. They wanted the number increased to six so there could be three men and three women.

Having placed that on the record and having urged honourable senators to think about what that means before they pass or reject it, I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) for an update on the process by which the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) will appoint the board. Is it at all possible for the consideration of this amendment, or is that process so far advanced that it would not be possible to include it? I urge him to do that because right throughout the committee proceedings we heard people saying that they did not mind the minister appointing persons provided he received nominations perhaps one from each state or from various regions of Australia. The idea that he might arbitrarily appoint a number of people was not contemplated by or did not impress many.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition does not believe in quotas as such. However, there is some merit in the comments of Senator Chamarette. Again, in the supervisory role of the Joint Statutory Committee on Native Title, I will be looking to ensure that appointments are made with that situation in mind. In the course of the evidence being given, many Aboriginal women appeared who were concerned about one or more aspects of this bill. I say to the government that, although there is no quota as such, the comments of Senator Chamarette must and should be borne in mind.

—We will certainly bear those comments in mind, but we do not feel we ought to be constrained by a formal rule of the kind that is proposed. As to the need for gender balance, for a start we certainly favour boards balanced on gender grounds wherever possible. However, there will be circumstances where there will simply be insufficient men or insufficient women with the particular skills or experience required for membership of a board who, in turn, are available to serve on it. In such cases, we certainly would not want to have the options to appoint a suitably qualified board limited by a prescription of this kind.

PARA.TAB: As to the proposal of at least six indigenous members, the bill allows for a board that could be entirely indigenous but it does not make that a requirement. It is likely that the board will be all indigenous when there are indigenous men and women with the appropriate level of expertise available to be part of it. But it is important that the ILC is able to use the skills and experiences of non-indigenous experts when it happens to be the case that there are no indigenous people available or when there is an insufficient number to play that role.

The bill is based on the indigenous commercial development corporation model, which provides that five out of the nine board members must be indigenous. I think it is worth stopping for half a second to note that a number of quite vital contributions have been made to that corporation by some of its non-indigenous members who have been appointed because of their expertise in financial and business matters. I do not think in this context it is invidious to name some names. I am thinking of people like Brian Wright of the Commonwealth Bank, Sir Lawrie Willett, who is head of the Commonwealth Funds Management Ltd, and Professor Bob Walker, who I think is widely regarded as Australia's pre-eminent independent expert in public sector accounting. As it stands, we think the bill provides the correct balance between the need for indigenous direction and self-determination and the need to ensure that there is appropriate expertise on the board. For that reason, we will not support the amendments. But I recognise the aspiration. We are not unsympathetic to that, and in practice we will try to get there.
Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 19.Clause 3, page 45, at end of proposed Part 4A, add the following Divisions:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Part is not intended as compensation for dispossession

SPEECH.PARA: " `193U.(1)Nothing in this Part is intended as compensation for the dispossession that Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders have suffered.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Act does not prevent claims being made for compensation

SPEECH.PARA: " `(2)Nothing in this Act prevents a claim being made for compensation or restitution by Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders in respect of that dispossession.

PARA.EMPHASIS: `Division 16—Extinguishment of native title rights and interest to be disregarded
Extinguishment of Native Title not to apply

SPEECH.PARA: `193W. Any extinguishment of the native title rights and interest must be disregarded in any lands purchased, dedicated or set aside for the benefit of Aboriginal people or Torres Strait Islanders, whether under this Act or any other law.".

This amendment inserts at the end of clause 3 a new division concerning dispossession. Currently, the Land Fund and Indigenous Land Corporation (ATSIC Amendment) Bill 1995 does not make clear whether compensation is intended for dispossession. The Greens believe this bill should not be seen in any way as compensation, and nothing in it should prevent claims for compensation being made in the future. The Greens are concerned that the associated rhetoric from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) and the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) might lead people to understand that this is the major act of compensation for dispossession. It has been repeatedly stated that this is the major financial component following from the High Court decision on native title. It may then lead to the land fund being taken as compensation for the dispossession of the last 200 years.

PARA.TAB: Compensation for dispossession does not come at $45 million a year, or $24 million a year more than is currently available. Compensation for dispossession would be incalculable. The Greens see it as important that the legislation leaves the option open for compensation to be sought at another time. Thus, the legislation should include a clause which specifically states that this is not compensation for dispossession and that nothing in this bill prevents claims for compensation being made.

We have already talked about how many people are going to benefit from this fund. The reality is that those who already know that they will never get access to that minute amount want some kind of guarantee that they will not be regarded as having gained some kind of compensation at a governmental level for which they have not received anything. It is for that reason that they want it stated within the bill as a disclaimer that prevents them from being disadvantaged in any way by taking that stand.

The amendment here creates a new division at the end of part 4 of the ATSIC Act which deals with the extinguishment of native title on indigenous held land. This amendment statutorily sets aside any extinguishment of native title on any land which has been acquired, set aside or dedicated for the benefit of Aboriginal people or Torres Strait Islanders. In doing so, it provides for the revival of native title similar to the revival of native title on mining leases under the Native Title Act 1993.

If the object of this bill is to restore land to Australia's indigenous people, it is important that the land be restored to them in terms which are appropriate to them. If this land is to be treated as indigenous held land, as the government keeps arguing, it should be treated as other indigenous held land, as land where native title rights remain.

In an earlier discussion, Senator Evans used the words `communal, inalienable title' in order to justify corporations having the land as being the closest equivalent to the `communal, inalienable title' of Aboriginal culture. We are proposing that the revival of native title allows that inalienable aspect of land that is acquired under the land fund to be made available to Aboriginal people. It would offset the concerns, which I have not agreed with, which have been referred to by Senator Evans as wanting to keep control of the Aboriginal estate by using corporations as the means by which the land is held rather than actually giving it to Aboriginal people in whatever form their community feels is most appropriate and then allowing them to revive native title in such a way that that communal, inalienable title is really reflected. That is the purpose of that final amendment.
I would not mind the minister commenting on whether there is any chance of a change of heart by the government in relation to either amendments 19 or 20.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is not much prospect of a change of heart, I am afraid. I do not want to disappoint you, but that's the breaks. As to amendment 19, it is wrong to claim that nothing in the bill is intended as compensation for the dispossession indigenous people have suffered. The provision of $1 1/2 billion for the acquisition of land is intended as one step in the process of recognition of indigenous possession and some compensation for that dispossession.

PARA.TAB: The Greens are mistaken in their view that the government considers this as the totality of a final settlement. It has been stated over and over that this bill is only part of the government's broad response to the Mabo decision. There is nothing in the bill which states that this is the government's final position or action, and I can assure Senator Chamarette it is the government's view that a good deal more should and will be done to address the issue of dispossession.

As to prior extinguishment being disregarded, can I say—it is a little complicated but I need to put the government's position clearly on the record—that this proposal means that, if any land is acquired or set aside for the benefit of indigenous people for any purpose, any previous extinguishment of native title over that land will be disregarded and presumably native title re-established.

This section would apply to any acquisition or dedication of land under any Commonwealth law whether related to this act or not. It is at least arguable that the provision would apply to state laws. This section would provide for the non-extinguishment of native title even over land which has been freehold title for over 100 years.

The amendment shows a fundamental misunderstanding about the nature of native title which exists only where indigenous people have maintained their connection with the land. There will also be major difficulties in determining who the native title holders are, if any, when the extinguishment occurred a long time ago. That again raises further potential for significant dispute and conflict among indigenous people.

The proposed section differs from section 47 of the Native Title Act in the following ways: section 47 only applies to pastoral lease land, not to all land; section 47 builds in the requirement of continuing attachment to the land; and section 47 also provides for pastoral leases to remain in place and coexist with native title. There is nothing in this proposal to provide for the situation where the revived native title and the acquired interests are not in the hands of the same indigenous people. This is another potential source of conflict and division between Aboriginal groups: for example, where the corporation attempts to assist a group of Aboriginal people by granting it land to which it had no prior connection and the native title to that land, as re-established, is held by a different group.

One can imagine a number of examples where this provision will create extraordinary difficulties. For example, if the Commonwealth funds the purchase of land to set up a health centre in the middle of Sydney for the benefit of the Aboriginal communities there, the native title to the land on which that centre is situated may continue to be held by the so-called traditional owners. If the ILC purchased an office block in a CBD for investment purposes similar to the New South Wales land funds purchase in Parramatta and then later wished to realise that investment, it could not do so. If the ILC wished to rationalise a number of purchases through swaps of land, linked sales or acquisitions, similarly there would be difficulties.

Again, complex compensation issues may arise for the ILC and other Commonwealth agencies especially where land acquired for the benefit of indigenous people is subsequently used for some other purpose or disposed of. The ILC and other bodies may be precluded from granting land or using it for the purpose for which it was acquired because the possible existence of native title makes that act an impermissible future act for the purposes of the Native Title Act.

The proposed amendment is completely at odds with the Greens' previous support for the removal of controls on the disposal of land in section 191S because native title land is, by its nature, inalienable. There are a number of strikes there which Senator Chamarette might conceivably be prepared to acknowledge. I think I have covered the terrain in more than adequate detail to indicate why it is that the government cannot accept that amendment either.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I could ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) a question which relates to one previously asked by Senator Chamarette, but it is relevant in that the minister has mentioned section 47 of the Native Title Act—the method by which pastoral properties purchased through the ILC can be converted to native title under that section.

PARA.TAB: Having regard to the ATSIC provision remaining in force for the next three years, there is a concern within the Northern Territory that, in view of that limited time, that money would be devoted mainly to acquiring properties in the Northern Territory and that that would deplete funds available to purchase a property in other parts of Australia. Can the government give an undertaking that that will not be the case, that during the next three years you will not have a heavy concentration on the acquisition of property in the Northern Territory?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not our expectation that ATSIC will do anything other than maintain the normal pattern of land acquisition using those funds available to it. ATSIC is an independent authority and makes its own decisions about this matter. But I do not believe there is any basis for thinking that the kind of strategy outlined by Senator Ellison will be pursued. There are far too many other people around the country with competing interests who would be far too upset for that to happen. I think we can rely on good sense prevailing in that respect.

—Having regard to the minister's comment that you do not put all your eggs in one basket, I ask whether he would envisage that expenditure by the ILC would be spread evenly across the country, as much as possible? Would the main aim be to provide as wide a spread as possible?

—I think everything hangs on the `as possible'. There is a sense in which we have to leave it to the ILC's discretion. Situations vary enormously around the country. To talk about an even spread, it begs a lot of questions that need to be answered by the board. I hope it will be equitable and balanced but how that is best done depends on the combination of national and regional strategies that emerge. There will be a consultative process associated with that and I hope, again, that good sense will prevail. We expect it will.

—I point out that in a Northern Territory publication provided to me by the Chief Minister in a letter dated 15 March there is a statement to the effect that the Northern Land Council is considering the purchase of 21 cattle stations at an estimated cost of $50 million. The NLC said that the money for the stations would be provided by the federal government's proposed Aboriginal land fund. I ask the minister whether he knows anything about that?
—I don't—I'm sorry.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) proposed:
That this bill be now read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to place on the record the reasons the Greens cannot and will not be supporting this land fund. We do not support it because it is inadequate in its amount and because the government has shown itself inflexible and paternalistic, as well as ungenerous, in its response to the calls right across Australia from various Aboriginal communities in relation to a land fund.

PARA.TAB: This land fund actually ties Aboriginal people into a system of never having more than $24 million a year for land acquisition and management and associated administration costs. We feel there has to be some protest against that. As we vote against it we actually represent far more than two out of the 76 senators here; we represent that percentage of Aboriginal Australians who do not agree with this bill in its current form.

Ours is a symbolic vote. It is one that recognises that the Senate is about to pass this legislation, making some small concession in giving access to a land fund to a small number of Aboriginal people across the country. That is a symbol of the government's willingness to do something but we feel that it is an indictment of its government's will to do something that should be far bigger and far more generous to the Aboriginal people. That is why we indicate that we do not support this bill.
Question put:
That this bill be now read a third time.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—On behalf of Senator West, I present the report of the Community Affairs Legislation Committee on the Health Legislation (Private Health Insurance Reform) Amendment Bill 1994, together with the transcript of evidence and submissions received by the committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—Order! It being 6.55 p.m., I propose the question:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr John Fahey and Mr Bob Carr are fighting the New South Wales election due to be determined next Saturday on the proposition that society wants to lock away for ever those it would be rid of. Both leaders are intent on that strategy. They would imprison men and women for decades in close to arbitrary fashion.

PARA.TAB: The abuse of arbitrary power corrodes the quality of any community. Criminals misuse such power when they murder, rape, maim, steal and blackmail. Monopolies do so when they ply their trade in defiance of consumer rights. Contractors follow that course when they oppress their workers. So do parents when they violate their children. Partners do likewise when they excoriate each other on parting. Governments abuse arbitrary power when they jail a class of people indifferent to the particular circumstances of each of its members.

What happens to law enforcement in New South Wales may in the future spread to other states and the Commonwealth. A statute made in Macquarie Street taking away a court's capacity to judge people on their merits may come to taint criminal justice throughout Australia. We need all address the issue.

Three questions face a judge about to sentence a convict: firstly, what has this criminal done; secondly, who is he or she; thirdly, what ought be done with him or her? From what Mr Fahey and Mr Carr have proposed, the courts will be allowed to answer the first question only. Parliament is to take the other two away from them. This usurps the proper role of judges. To attach a maximum penalty to a crime is a function of parliament. To impose an appropriate sentence on a particular individual for a specific wrong he or she has perpetrated is a duty of the judiciary. Were the legislature to invade the proper province of the courts as advocated in the current election, the right balance between them would be grossly disturbed.

A long sentence is not necessarily a wrong one but a judge ought not award it automatically. A judge ought to take into account a number of matters when sentencing convicts. These include their role in the crime, the harm they have done, what efforts they have made to redress it, their character, their social and cultural history, their age and the quality of their remorse. When parliament fixes a mandatory rather than a maximum term of imprisonment for a crime, it puts at risk the free, democratic and liberal society most Australians want. It countermands the imperatives arising from the uniqueness of each individual and those of fairness, compassion and propriety. People subject to the criminal justice system are treated as little more than automatons.

How society treats those at its margin is a key test of its worth. A community which embraces the rich, the powerful, the beautiful and the healthy, while spurning the poor, the weak, the ugly and the sick, is grievously flawed. Where it treats the criminal as no more than refuse to be cast into a garbage bin and buried for a generation, it perverts the humanity of all of its members.

There are times when the public is unfairly critical of political leaders. During their careers, both Mr Fahey and Mr Carr have done many good things and deserve much praise. But on this issue, where each commits himself to outdoing the other in locking away law breakers in New South Wales, indifferent to the demands of justice and morality, they both fail miserably as men of principle.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a very serious matter in the adjournment debate tonight; that is, the conduct of senior executive officers within the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. The matter in question relates to issues first aired by the Deputy Leader of the National Party, Senator David Brownhill, and myself in the estimates committee immediately following the last federal election. We had details of financial impropriety which was alleged to have been committed by a number of senior executive officers within the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service.

PARA.TAB: To cut a long story short, extracting the information on these improprieties was a bit like pulling teeth: getting the officers to acknowledge that there was even reason for concern was a very difficult process. As a consequence of that, the estimates hearings relating to the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service were particularly protracted sessions, and they did not bring a lot of satisfaction to any of the people who were involved in the whole process.

In May last year, charges were brought under the Public Service Act against one officer—an officer by the name of Phillip Corrigan. As at November last year, the official inquiry under section 61 of the Public Service Act into those charges had only just commenced, and the inquiry officer had not been able to do anything in the interim.

What Senator Brownhill and I were not told on 29 November was that that officer in question had obtained permission from the secretary to the department to have extended leave of absence so that he could take up a high paying job in the United Kingdom. That high paying job in the United Kingdom was to head the operations executive of the new meat hygiene division of the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry.

It is our understanding from information provided to us that Mr Corrigan may have been aided in obtaining that position by references provided by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service itself, and not by individual officers of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service personally writing references. We understand that there may have been the belief in the United Kingdom that Mr Corrigan went with an official reference from AQIS.

Given that the officer was under investigation on six charges of impropriety under the Public Service Act which carry penalties of up to dismissal, it is particularly disturbing that that possibility may even arise. The estimates committee was not told on 29 November that this was the case. Nobody even attempted to tell senators attending the estimates committee that Mr Corrigan had already obtained approval for his extended leave of absence.

Mr Corrigan is now the subject of questions in the House of Commons because word has travelled over there about the charges against him. Members of parliament in the United Kingdom take a different view about financial propriety to that which was expressed by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins). He seemed to think at the estimates hearing on 15 February that it was all well and good that Mr Corrigan should have obtained this job in the UK and that it was a great feather in our cap. Parliamentarians in the United Kingdom have a different view.

This is turning into a scandal in the UK. The view over there is that it is entirely improper that this officer should have obtained references from his colleagues at AQIS and been fixed up with a job in the UK with their assistance. They got him out of the country and unloaded him onto the United Kingdom. That is exactly what has happened.

This is unsatisfactory, because I believe that this sort of going on blemishes the good name and integrity of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. For Mr Corrigan to be able to obtain these references and be fitted up with a job in the United Kingdom is quite simply a slur on the integrity of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. It should never have happened. It happened only because there was a failure of proper management.

It is also my understanding that findings have been made in relation to those six charges. I am waiting for the official advice from the minister as to exactly what the situation is. I understand that Mr Corrigan has been advised. I also understand from journalists that Mr Corrigan does not want to answer any questions about the results of the findings on those six charges. I can only surmise why Mr Corrigan does not want to answer any questions. I can only assume that, if Mr Corrigan had been found innocent on all six charges, he would have been very happy to answer questions from journalists. I understand from a journalist who contacted Mr Corrigan that he was not particularly keen to talk about the issue at all, which suggested to me that Mr Corrigan has not had the benefit of six verdicts of innocent. I am concerned that these matters, which I was told were finalised on 15 February—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are disgraceful.
—I am sorry, Senator Crowley; would you like to repeat that interjection?
—You are disgraceful, Senator.
—I want that withdrawn.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—Minister, would you withdraw it, please?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quite sure what is to be withdrawn. Is it the claim by Senator O'Chee that there is a presumption of guilt if a person is not proved innocent?
—You know exactly what is to be withdrawn, Rosemary.
—No, I do not. If you want me to withdraw that I called you disgraceful, I withdraw it. Your comments are disgraceful.

—We think your financial impropriety in government has been disgraceful. I am absolutely sick and tired of this government's attempt to hide the financial impropriety of senior officers in AQIS. It is now becoming an embarrassment to this nation and an embarrassment to our primary producers. That is the simple fact about it. Senator Crowley, on the other side of the chamber, shows the Labor Party's attitude to these matters: do not talk about it.

PARA.TAB: It is a matter of record that these charges were finalised on 15 February. The Labor Party's contempt for the estimates process has meant that there is still no official advice from the minister as to the outcome of the charges, notwithstanding an undertaking on 15 February that they would be provided forthwith. So much for the Labor Party's view of accountability. That is disgraceful.

The minister must immediately make available the findings and details of each of the six charges so that we can assess exactly what has happened in AQIS. The idea that the secretary to the department would allow this officer to have extended leave of absence so that he could go over to the United Kingdom and take a high paying job whilst he is still facing charges here—and knowing that if that officer is found guilty of the charges it will be an embarrassment to AQIS and the Australian government—is in itself very disturbing, notwithstanding the fact that this officer may have knowledge of other financial impropriety which was committed by other members of the senior executive service of AQIS.

This has not been a pleasing task to be involved with, but it is something that has to be done to protect the financial interests of producers whose livestock is ultimately inspected by AQIS and who rely for their overseas earnings on the good work of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. I hope this scandal is concluded as soon as possible, but concluded properly and with a sense of accountability to parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight because of an event that occurred in the chamber earlier today when Senator O'Chee called upon me to resign for remarks I allegedly made on a Perth radio station some weeks ago. Before I deal with that, I want to read into the record an extract from a letter that I circulated on 3 March 1995 to quite a large number of constituents in my home state of Western Australia. The number of people who received it would run into hundreds. I want to put into the record item (3) from that letter, and I will explain my reasons for doing so at the conclusion of the quote. Item (3) says:

TAB.EMPHASIS: (3) Expose of the National Civic Council Plans for Australia

SPEECH.PARA: The Sunday Times article of last weekend—
which was 26 February 1995—

"Growth will halt refugees, says NCC", went some way towards explaining the puzzling support that the National Civic Council has been giving over the years to the boat people. That support has been overt and covert. They have used their WA State Secretary, Richard Egan, sometimes on behalf of fringe organisations, but their covert operations are less easy to delineate.

The NCC have infiltrated political parties, service organisations and refugee support groups. Their influence in some refugee support groups has had such effect that some of these groups work exclusively for boat people, ignoring the 13,000 refugees who are settled in Australia each year.

The article states that the NCC want to populate and develop Northern Australia—"Clearly the only way is to seek to inhabit and exploit the area". The NCC weekly bulletin "News Weekly", says that it is naive to say that Australia cannot be allowed to be overpopulated because of our poor soils and shortage of water. The article suggests that there is plenty of water, and that this can be used to expand the economic potential of the area. They cite the Ord River Scheme to prove their point.
The hidden agenda may now be obvious. The encouragement they have given to some groups of refugees can possibly be explained.
They want to populate Northern Australia with wealthy (those who can afford passage on a boat) Asians who are "fleeing Communist regimes".
By giving encouragement and support to boat people, they ensure that the flow will continue. When the flood becomes too big, Australia will be forced to accept and settle these people.
They will not be processed in the normal way. No character checks. No health checks.
What is the future for Australia if the NCC's sinister plot comes to fruition?

I end the letter there with my salutations and signature. I make the point that this letter was circulated on 3 March 1995. I did not seek in putting forward those strong words to use the privilege that is extended to me as a senator representing the people of Western Australia to make remarks that I could not substantiate in another place—be it in this place or out there in the broader community. I have never sought to abuse or misuse the privilege of this place. That letter is on the record and has been sent to some hundreds of people in my constituency of Western Australia. I have also used the text in different contexts in various interviews that I have done again back in my home state of Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: On 10 March this year, 6PR radio station interviewer Rob Broadfield interviewed both Senator O'Chee and me in regard to the general matter relating to boat people but in particular the legislation that is before this chamber, which I do not seek to canvass during the adjournment debate because that would be wrong and in contravention of the standing orders of this place. From my point of view, there was a very lively debate between Senator O'Chee and me, with Mr Broadfield having to act on some rare occasions as a moderator to keep both of us in check.

I was quite happy with the comments that I had made according to the printed record of the interview that was given to me at a later time. I was surprised to find today that, while I was out of the building—I am trying to look after my health for a change—Senator O'Chee again used the chamber to get up and make some suggestions about my comments on the radio. He concluded that I was not here. The information that I have from other people in the building who were here was that his language was strong. I understand it was much stronger than the words that were recently challenged in the chamber about being outrageous.

I understand from what I have been told—and I do not know this for certain myself—that, if those comments had not been made under the privilege of the parliament, I might now be talking to my lawyers instead of making a contribution to the adjournment debate. I do not know that for certain because I do not have the Hansard record of Senator O'Chee's comments. I will not get that until tomorrow, but when I do get it we will see whether or not the same principles that I adhere to in terms of the privilege of the parliament have been respected by my opponent on the other side. I do not know. The record will prove it at a later time.

I have been told, however, that during the course of Senator O'Chee's comments today he misquoted me. I am not making any assertions or allegations. I have been told that, and I will hold my counsel until that is proven by the record tomorrow. I was told that it was in the context of an interchange between Mr Broadfield and me that a certain thing was said. I am doing this from second-hand information, but from my point of view it is important to put the record straight. That is why I am seeking to do this. If I am wrong, I will most graciously stand up in this place tomorrow and apologise. I have been told that the part I have been misquoted in relation to was the following extract from my record of the interview:

SPEECH.PARA: ROB—
which was the presenter or the moderator—
Now, the National Civic Council, Bob Santamaria's mob as most Australians would know it, you are saying, is in league with the opposition now?
SENATOR MCKIERNAN: No, no, no. I am saying that the NCC have infiltrated political parties, refugee support groups and others in our community.
ROB: To what end?
SENATOR MCKIERNAN: The legal profession.
ROB: No, but to what end? For what purpose?
SENATOR MCKIERNAN: To populate the northern end of Australia.
ROB: With Asians?

SENATOR MCKIERNAN: To populate the northern end of Australia. To keep the pressures off countries in the Asian region which they say are over populated. Now it's not by accident that we have the full time secretary of the NCC in Western Australia, Mr Richard Egan, who is also the secretary of the WA representative of the Indo China Refugee Association.
ROB: Okay.

Again, the record will show this tomorrow but I am told that it was at the time the reference to Asians came in that Senator O'Chee added some additional words to the comments in the record that I have and also went on to say that I was going to say something else but did not say it—which, if what I have been told is true, will completely and utterly distort the record in a most unfair way. I have not had the opportunity because of other events, such as the transcript reaching me only recently and our adjourning early, to show it to the opposition. But it is available. I am more than happy to supply it. I will not try to subvert the practices of this place by seeking to table it because I have not had the opportunity to show it to the opposition.

PARA.TAB: I conclude by making the comment that I stand by everything I put in the letter to my constituents on 3 March, I stand by my comments that I made on 10 March, and if I have upset some people with those comments I have done so on behalf of the people of Western Australia, my constituents in Western Australia, and those long-suffering taxpayers who have been exploited to the hilt by a small number of people who are acting sometimes in a not too professional manner in support of illegal entrants to this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will give you leave.
—With that invitation, I seek leave to table the transcript.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add some remarks to those already made by my colleague Senator O'Chee about AQIS. The Senate estimates process is designed to obtain information from an assessed performance of the commonwealth Public Service. Over the years it has been used in various ways by various senators from various political persuasions. During my period in the Senate the officers who have come before Senate estimates committees have become increasingly adept at avoiding issues and so skilled at providing information that has so little substance that it renders the estimates process rather difficult.

PARA.TAB: In May 1993, a series of questions were asked of officers from AQIS and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. It was a simple line of questioning based on information conveyed to the Queensland parliament about travel irregularities involving senior officers within AQIS. The concern of senators at the time, including Senator O'Chee, was that this department was in the process of moving to full cost recovery and was, in this case, predominantly in the rural sector and there were allegations and evidence to suggest that certain officers were abusing the system.

I will not waste the time of the Senate by outlining the exhaustive process that followed, suffice it to say that my office and Senator O'Chee's office pursued the issue largely as a result of the stonewalling we received in the first estimates hearing and subsequent hearings in September and November 1993. We learnt through our investigations that several officers had breached Public Service guidelines. We uncovered a range of inappropriate activities, a series of cover-ups and a total lack of cooperation by officers both within AQIS and the wider the department for the estimates process.

During our inquiries and as a result of the mismanagement that we exposed, the head of AQIS was transferred and an officer from another department was brought in as the head of AQIS. Obviously, the department was hopeful that the matter would be dropped. I am afraid it was not. As Senator O'Chee has advised, one officer involved in that original line of questioning was purportedly found to be in dereliction of his duty resulting from issues we raised nearly two years ago.

Quite coincidentally that officer is no longer in Australia. It is of some concern to me and other senators that this officer is now in a senior position in the United Kingdom Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries. How he obtained that position and on whose recommendations he was sent from Australia is yet to be determined. Obviously, the ability and the willingness of the Australian authorities to pursue those charges, of which I understand he has found to be in error, also needs to be examined.

The other point I wish to raise is that when changes were made to the organisation in November and December 1993 we were given to understand that a new regime and a commitment to service had been adopted. During the rural and regional affairs committee hearings into the legislation relating to domestic meat charges there were calls from inside and outside the parliament for an inquiry into AQIS. That should have happened. It was generally agreed that it would be more appropriate to wait to allow the new management to establish itself and to allow time for the promised reform regime to commence, so we waited.

The inquiry was finally established late in 1994 and the first hearings were held earlier this month. I must say that we have not had a very auspicious start. Our first witness, Mr Don Ford, refused to provide details of the allegations he had mentioned in the media. He claimed that he had passed his concerns on to the minister and was awaiting the minister's response before proceeding further. The minister has told the Senate that inquiries are proceeding. I think it interesting for us to note that fact. I think that that may be contempt of a Senate inquiry.

The second hearing of the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Committee provided the opportunity for AQIS senior officers to demonstrate a new cooperation with the parliament. They too refused to comment on Mr Ford's allegations claiming, as we have seen happen with the minister, that they did not have the details. I believe that that also put us in a rather difficult position.

All the allegations Mr Ford has made relate to incidents which Mr Ford has already said publicly were subject to incident reports to the appropriate AQIS officers. In other words, I know and AQIS knows that the incidents Mr Ford refers to are already on the AQIS files. For the AQIS officers to suggest that they are not aware of the substance of the allegations implies that AQIS either is not coming clean or is incompetent or hiding something. That saddens me because I believe that that matter should have been cleared up a couple of years ago so that AQIS retained a good name.

We now have the situation where a former AQIS officer, a key witness to the whole issue of the integrity of AQIS, has left Australia. He still has charges hanging over his head which emanate from the estimates inquiries.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the outcome of the question in the UK House of Com mons?

—I have an article which says that inquiries were made in the usual way about Mr Corrigan before his appointment, including from his previous employer, the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. Basically, the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service has given Mr Corrigan a recommendation for the position that he is now in. Mr Corrigan is now in a senior position in the United Kingdom government as a result of that recommendation from the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service.

PARA.TAB: This process has taken two years. I think this says nothing for public accountability and says little for the consultative process and the expressed desire by departmental officers to cooperate with the Senate. I include the minister when I say that because I think he should have given us the information that Mr Ford had given him that did not pertain to Mr Corrigan or others earlier so the allegations surrounding Mr Ford could have been cleared up.

I advise the officers from AQIS and other departments that the Senate should have the cooperation of government departments to clear matters up. It is not good for us as law makers and administrators and it is not good for the departments if we do not have a squeaky clean organisation. I will continue to pursue the issue of accountability and integrity. I think the Senate should ensure through you, Mr President, or others that parliamentary committees are not held in contempt. Whatever obstacles are put in our way we will continue to find out the result of all these accusations that have been made and make sure that proper processes are used in relation to Senate inquiries and committees.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Labor Party: New South Wales Branch

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today I raised in passing the fact that the bankruptcy of the Labor Party in New South Wales, financial as well as moral and political, was evident from the fact that Labor Centenary House Pty Ltd has assets amounting to, at the most, $1.8 million and appears to have liabilities of about $10 million. It is hard to tell which element of the Labor Party owes who what.

PARA.TAB: The point I made in passing was that it is very hard to tell exactly how disastrous the situation is in financial terms for the Labor Party in New South Wales and how bankrupt it really is because Labor Centenary House Pty Ltd has not lodged its annual return. In fact, the 1993 annual return is not complete. That is the case with a lot of shonky organisations. I note that its annual returns for 1991, 1992 and 1993 were all lodged in one lump on 10 March 1994. In other words, there has been a blatant breach of the requirements of the Australian Securities Commission by this subsidiary of the Labor Party—a subsidiary which is a bottomless pit, which cannot work out its accounts and which has not provided any key financial data because it does not have it. It appears to be in continuing breach of a whole range of matters.

I have a letter which Mr John Della Bosca, the company secretary of Labor Centenary House Pty Ltd and also secretary of the New South Wales Labor Party, wrote when he filed the 1993 annual return, which has not been regarded as a proper return by the Australian Securities Commission. That letter was signed on 2 March 1994, a year ago. In it he says:
The key financial data has been excluded from this return due to circumstances beyond the control of the Company Secretary.

SPEECH.PARA: That is him. `It is not my fault,' he says. It must be Stephen Loosley's, I guess. He then goes on:
The financial data has been prepared, but as the ultimate control of this company rests with voluntary officials, a commitment for the Directors to sign the accounts has not been given.
I guess that if I were one of the directors of this company, I would be very reluctant to put my name to this shonky organisation. He further states:

PARA.TAB: The Company Secretary endeavours to provide the key financial data on Form 902, supplementary document before 30/6/1994.

SPEECH.PARA: That, as the Senate can tell, was nine months ago and there is still no key financial data.

PARA.TAB: The member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) put out a press release today because, as I understand it, the gallery was being misinformed by the Labor Party—in particular by Mr Della Bosca's wife, who happens to be a Labor senator for New South Wales—that it did not have to put out the key financial data, that there was no need to. She has made a basic error because on the form that Mr Della Bosca signed and sent to the Australian Securities Commission, there is a question, `Were the company accounts for the financial year audited?' and that box is ticked `No'. The accounts were not audited. The Labor Party cannot get away with the shonky trick of saying, `We do have an auditor and therefore we don't have to provide accounts.' But the auditor has not audited the accounts, presumably because the accounts are not in a state capable of being audited.

One would certainly get that impression because the ASC has threatened on a previous occasion to deregister this company for not complying. The subsidiary in New South Wales of the Australian Labor Party has been threatened twice by the ASC with deregistration for not complying. The previous time—1994 was the latest time—was back in December 1992. I will read a letter dated 9 December 1992 from Mr John Della Bosca to the Australian Securities Commission:
We refer to your letter dated 30 November 1992 and wish to advise you that the above company is in operation.

SPEECH.PARA: The ASC could not have told whether it was in operation because the company had not provided any annual returns. By the way, I do hope that the directors of this company have received penalties for failing to meet the requirements of the Australian Securities Commission. It is pretty ordinary, is it not, when officials of the Labor Party—which claims it has the capacity to run the state of New South Wales—cannot even abide by the Australian Securities Commission requirements and, presumably, receive penalties? Unless, of course, they had some mate fix it up for them. Mr Della Bosca goes on to state in the letter:

PARA.TAB: We are currently experiencing administrative difficulties affecting the company's accounting and secretarial functions—

SPEECH.PARA: The simple answer is that they cannot add up—
We are addressing these issues but we believe it will take 6 months to be in a position to lodge annual returns.
We would appreciate your confirmation that you will grant a 6 months moratorium in complying with the Corporations Law requirements.

As I said, it was not just six months. That letter was dated 9 December 1992 and it took them until March 1994 to get around to filing the annual returns. Once again, they were inadequate because the financial matters were inadequate. All these returns were filed in one hit.

PARA.TAB: I say this to the Labor Party: just by putting down the name of an auditor who has not audited the books—because the books are not in a state to be audited—and admitting that the books were not audited, it cannot get away with dodging the requirements, sneaking around the rules and breaching the law that the ASC administers by that kind of shonky device. Sure, when Labor was last in government in New South Wales it did all those shonky things; it did get around everything; it did have corruption—yes, that is the way Labor runs because you cannot trust Labor with money. That is evident, once again, from these accounts.

It is also interesting that one of the things Mr John Della Bosca had to swear was this: that there are reasonable grounds to believe that the company will be able to pay its debts when they fall due. That must be one of the greatest jokes of all time. It would be interesting to see whether Mr John Della Bosca—let alone the directors who do not want to contribute their names—would be prepared to swear that when he files, if he ever gets around to filing, the 1994 annual return. This is yet another example of how the Labor Party cannot be trusted with money, how it has continually breached the ASC requirements and the Corporations Law and how this branch of the ALP has not just shown bad judgment in losing a fortune in the Sydney property market; it has shown a total disregard for the law. (Time expired)
