TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What type of production/development was undertaken by DDB Needham Worldwide, North Sydney, on behalf of the Australian Taxation Office at a cost of $300 000.
(2) When did this take place.
(3) Over what period of time did this take place.
(4) What was the purpose of this production/development.
(5) What other costs were associated with this particular assignment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) An amount of $300 000 was committed for production and development costs for the 1994/95 financial year on the Superannuation Guarantee Campaign. The amount of $300 000 was an estimate of the total amount anticipated for this phase of the campaign.

To date $113 771.94 has been spent on the Superannuation Guarantee campaign. Major costs are for the production and development of Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia (ASFA) conference materials, Tax Pack and TaxPeople (ATO internal magazine) advertisements, newspaper and magazine advertisements, revision of all Superannuation Guarantee publications, press kit folders, omnibus research and production of Superannuation Guarantee 1994 Update brochure.
(2) & (3) The work was commissioned in February 1994 and took place over a period of 9 months—February 1994 to October 1994.

Further work will be done over a period of 6 months. This will include preparation of materials for the Conference of Major Superannuation Funds (CMSF), advertisements for Super Funds and Super Review magazines, producing a brochure in 10 languages and generic Superannuation Guarantee posters for conferences, seminars etc.
(4) The production/development work on various components was undertaken in association with the items outlined below.

ANSWER.PARA: Association OF Superannuation Funds of Australia (ASFA) Conference

PARA.TAB: ATO staff had a presence at the ASFA Conference. High quality presentation materials for the information booth and speaking material were prepared by DDB Needham.

As the Tax Pack is distributed to every household in Australia, this was seen as a marketing opportunity to inform taxpayers of changes to certain obligations under the Superannuation Guarantee legislation.

Accounts received in the 1994/95 financial year were for work completed in the 1993/94 financial year on press advertising, which informed the public of the contribution deadlines and the percentage increase for Superannuation Guarantee contributions.
TaxPeople is a magazine distributed to all ATO staff nationally. This was seen as a suitable vehicle in updating and informing ATO staff on the Superannuation Guarantee legislation.
Due to changes in the legislation all Superannuation Guarantee publications were revised and updated.
(5) Other costs associated with the Superannuation Guarantee Campaign which are included in the total expenditure to date are administrative and freight charges.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 15 December 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) How much did the Federal Government give the Nature Conservation Council to carry out a survey of plantation products and their future.
(2) How does this survey differ from another Federal Government funded survey on plantations being undertaken by Environment Victoria.
(3) What is the total amount spent on green groups during the 1994 calendar year and the 1994-95 financial year to allow them to look at different aspects of the forest industry.

(4) Is the Minister aware of comments by Mr Bob Richardson of the Australian Council of Trade Unions criticising the amount of funds awarded to green groups for plantation surveys, and does the Minister agree with Mr Richardson's assertion that the work being undertaken by green groups has already been done by the National Plantation Advisory Council (NPAC).
(5) Has the Government responded to the NPAC report; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Funding has been provided to Environment Victoria to carry out a plantations survey. Environment Victoria has employed a NSW Nature Conservation Council official as a Project Officer to develop a NSW State profile and a number of issue papers for the plantations study. To date the Commonwealth Government has provided $126 563 to Environment Victoria to conduct the plantation survey with total expected expenditure for 1994-95 being $166 563.
(2) See (1) above.

(3)(a) Funding by the Environment, Sport and Territories Portfolio to voluntary conservation organisations for the purposes of examining aspects of the forest industry during the 1994 calendar year was $404 933. These funds were provided as follows:
$126 563 was spent on the plantation study;
$114 025 was provided to conservation groups in NSW, Victoria, Tasmania and Western Australia to provide substantiated information on forests likely to be of high conservation value;
$9 945 to Environment Victoria for consultancy services in relation to production of a position paper on guidelines for environmentally preferred paper products;
$2 000 to the Tasmanian Conservation Trust to cover costs associated with consultations with executives of Australian pulp and paper companies and for preparation of a report; and
$152 400 provided to various organisations under the Australian Heritage Commission's National Estate Grants Program (NEGP) for the following projects:
$3 000 to Nature Conservation Council of NSW for review of Red Gum vegetation in NSW;
$39 500 to Victorian National Parks Association for studies on Box Ironbark forests and other remnant ecosystems in Victoria;
$1 900 to Karawatha Forest Protection Society for General Inventory of Forests;
$55 000 to the National Parks Association of NSW for assessment of the conservation value of South Coast Crown Land;
$23 000 to the Rainforest Conservation Society of Queensland to assess the national estate values of rainforests on the central Queensland coast; and
$30 000 to the Victorian National Parks Association for education kits on Box Ironbark woodlands.

(b) 1994/95 financial year expenditure to date has totalled $368 033. This figure consists of the above projects with the exception of funding under the NEGP of $44 400, provided prior to July 1994. These projects were:
$3 000 to Nature Conservation Council of NSW for review of Red Gum vegetation in NSW;
$39 500 to Victorian National Parks Association for studies on Box Ironbark forests and other remnant ecosystems in Victoria;
$1 900 to Karawatha Forest Protection Society for General Inventory of Forests.

In addition it includes funding of $7 500 to conservation groups in Tasmania, Victoria and NSW for supplementary work on the high conservation value project provided in the 1995 calendar year. Figures for the remainder of the 1994-95 financial year are not yet available.
(4)(a) Yes.
(b) No. Refer to my answer to Senator Cooney (Hansard, 11 October 1994, page 1400).
(5) Yes. The National Forest Policy Statement constitutes the Government's response to the recommendations of the NPAC report.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner. Some criticism has been made of the minister's funding of Environment Victoria to carry out a national plantation study. Amongst the critics was Mr Bob Richardson of the ACTU. Is the criticism justified and, if so, to what extent?
—I am aware, of course, of the comments that—

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill—How did you go at the conference?

TALK.START.PARA: —Better, in fact, than at many other conferences I have been at. I am aware of the statements that Mr Richardson has made, and I can say to the Senate, through you, Mr Deputy President, that they are groundless. I think they are mischievous statements. They are certainly statements that, I believe, are out of step with many of his union colleagues.

PARA.TAB: I did publicly announce in a speech I made in Hobart at the ALP national conference that I am currently looking at how plantations can play a role in relieving pressure on native forests while, at the same time, offering significant expansion of the industry's resource base. To this end, I have recently agreed to fund a national plantation study. The study is fully consistent with the national forest policy statement and will involve state and territory conservation councils. I believe it will be significant in progressing the NFPS goals of the full utilisation and expansion of Australia's plantation resource and the NFPS objectives in relation to the development of plantation based industries.

The study will develop an aggregate national overview of the plantation estate, involving the identification of the extent of hardwood and softwood plantations in each state, opportunities for processing this resource, industry expansion opportunities, employment potential and also Commonwealth actions to stimulate an increased emphasis on plantation resource utilisation. It is designed to provide a picture of the extent of the plantation resource nationwide and will identify specific development opportunities which could enjoy the support of both industry and conservation groups. It will also provide the Commonwealth with information on the potential for the ecologically sustainable expansion of industry and employment.

The study does differ substantially from the National Plantations Advisory Committee work, which primarily focused on the development and establishment of new plantations on cleared agricultural land. It also differs from the work of the Resource Assessment Commission, which undertook financial feasibility assessments for possible expansion of the plantation estate and studies that detailed the area of land suitable for new plantation development. This study, by contrast, will focus on the extent of existing plantation estate and will examine means to fully utilise that resource. The consultant who is coordinating the study has already had very positive feedback about the study from industry sources.

A study proposal from Environment Victoria entitled National Plantations: Environment, Industry Development and Employment was first submitted to my department in June of last year. A revised proposal, which was redrafted to fit more directly within the funding guidelines of the environment portfolio, was submitted in February 1994. On 1 April I received that revised study proposal with the recommendation from my department that funding should be granted for the study. I did, however, withhold further action until July, pending receipt of Environment Victoria's audited financial statement for the grants to voluntary conservation organisations program for 1993-94 and until questions raised by Mr Barry Cunningham on the extent of departmental funding to the organisation were answered. I believe this study will provide a basis for greater dialogue on plantation issues between industry, union and conservation interests. I think this is very important to the environment debate in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 6 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many 1995 calendars were printed by Craftsman Press Pty Ltd, Burwood, Victoria, at a cost of $65,780.
(2) What was the topic of the calendars.
(3) How were these calendars distributed.
(4) What resale value do these calendars have.
(5) Where can these calendars be purchased by the public.
(6) What is the recommended retail price.
(7) What costs were involved in the preparation of these calendars for printing.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) A total of 23,000 copies of the 1995 Australian Weather Calendar were printed by Craftsman Press Pty Ltd. The firm's initial quote for the printing was $65,780. Corrections, additional film work etc. at the pre-print stage, together with some freight costs, resulted in a final payment to Craftsman Press of $74,170.
(2) Since 1985 the Bureau of Meteorology, in conjunction with the Australian Meteorological and Oceanographic Society (AMOS), has produced annually the Australian Weather Calendar.

The primary purpose of the Calendar is to promote greater understanding of the science of meteorology and to improve the effectiveness of the community application of meteorological information and services. As well as photographs of meteorological phenomena, the Calendar contains information on the topic identified by the World Meteorological Organization as the focus for World Meteorological Day on 23 March each year.
The topic of the 1995 Australian Weather Calendar and of World Meteorological Day on 23 March 1995 was `Public Weather Services'. The 12 sub-themes, one on each of the monthly pages, were:
weather phenomena
weather services
World Weather Watch
Australian public weather services
newspaper weather services
radio and television weather services
telephone and facsimile weather services
marine weather services
weather services for the rural sector
fire weather services
severe storm warnings
tropical cyclone warning services.

(3) Of the total of 23,000 copies printed, approximately 14,000 were made available for sale through the Public Relations Unit of the Bureau's Head Office in Melbourne and through its Regional and Field Offices in each State and the NT. Some 6,700 copies were distributed to the Bureau's volunteer rainfall observers and co-operative observers around Australia, in recognition of their contribution to the national climate data base and in order to assist in their appreciation of the significance of their voluntary observations in support of the public weather and warning services network. A further 2,300 were distributed on a complimentary (in several cases exchanged) basis to overseas National Meteorological Services, Australian Heads of Missions overseas, Federal Parliamentarians and State Environment Ministers, and to agencies that the Bureau of Meteorology works closely with (e.g. State Emergency Services, Fire Authorities etc.) in the delivery of forecast and warning services to the community.

(4) The `for sale' copies are offered to the public through Bureau offices for $12 over the counter without cylinder, $13 over the counter with cylinder, or $15 if postage within Australia is required. Some 200 copies are sold to AMOS, which makes a small `in kind' contribution to production of the Calendar, at $6 each for resale to Society members at $10 each.

(5) The calendars can be purchased by the public only from Bureau offices (Head Office in Melbourne, Regional Offices in each of the States and the NT, and some 50 field offices around Australia). They are not provided to any retail outlet for resale.

(6) As indicated in the response to Question (4), the calendars are sold to the general public for $12 over the counter without cylinder, $13 over the counter with cylinder, or $15 if postage within Australia is involved. Copies are sold to Bureau staff for $10 and a limited number (200) are sold to AMOS, which contributes `in kind' to the production of the Calendar, for $6 each.

(7) The total cost of preparing the Calendar for printing is estimated to be $102,000. A significant part of the cost is offset against other public education activities by using the basic material assembled for Calendar purposes in other Bureau of Meteorology publications.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 6 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: In the light of the recent decision to award the contract for engine maintenance of the RAAF's F/A-18 aircraft to New Zealand:

(1) Was the decision to award the F/A-18 engine maintenance contract to Air New Zealand based upon lowest tender considerations; if not, what prompted the department to accept the Air New Zealand bid.
(2) Has the Government given consideration to the significant loss of skills that the loss of this engine maintenance contract to New Zealand will represent; if not, why not.
(3) How is the export of these vital maintenance skills to New Zealand consistent with the Government's defence policy of self-reliance.

(4) What sums of money did the department authorise to be spent to acquire equipment for Hawker de Havilland (formerly the Commonwealth Aircraft Corporation) to support its involvement in the F/A-18 industry program.
(5) What was the cost (in then year and 1995 dollars) of each of the following; (a) the 5-Axis Machining Centre; (b) the NC Vertical Lathe; and (c) the Engine Test facility.
(6) What will be the fate of all equipment provided to Hawker de Havilland for the F/A-18 industry program now that the engine maintenance has gone to Air New Zealand.
(7) Will the Commonwealth's investment in this equipment be recovered, part-recovered, or lost; and (b) if full or part recovery is possible, what is the extent of recoveries envisaged.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) As all three tenderers were assessed as being technically competitive and capable of performing the work, cost became a significant determining factor. Tender prices were assessed in terms of value for money, as clearly set out in the Defence White Paper.

The Government also looks to Australian industry to produce major items of equipment for Defence. Major defence equipment will be produced in Australia when it offers value for money, taking account of factors including the ability to meet needs arising from our geographic and strategic environment, the development of a capacity for through-life support and modification, and assurance of uninterrupted supply.

(2) While the loss of this work from Hawker de Havilland in Port Melbourne is regretted, the capability to maintain high performance jet engines still exists within Australian industry with Qantas and Ansett.

(3) Defence self-reliance is an important strategic consideration in the formulation of Australian defence policy and New Zealand defence industry falls within that strategic interest. Australian and New Zealand firms are treated equally when tendering for Australian defence work.

Again, as clearly stated in the Defence White Paper, a strong Australian defence industry is important in sustaining the operational effectiveness of the Australian Defence Force, and ensuring that the Force is able to adapt to changing circumstances. Industry's contribution to our defence effort will become more important as our strategic environment becomes more demanding. Australia's defence industry capacity is supplemented by New Zealand's. Under the terms of the ANZAC Ship Treaty and in accordance with closer economic and defence relations, New Zealand industry together with Australian industry are considered as a single defence industrial base. Australian and New Zealand firms are therefore treated equally in our Defence industry policies, except in regard to a small number of high-security or third country collaborative projects.
These arrangements are consistent with general Government procurement guidelines which treat Australia and New Zealand industry the same.
(4) Approximately $34.2 million.
(5) (a) 1984 cost $879,603; (b) 1984 cost $544,127; (c) 1985 cost $9,279,520. No 1995 dollar cost figures for the equipment are held by the Department.

(6) Following a commercial decision by Hawker de Havilland in 1993 to close its Engine Component Division, a large amount of Commonwealth-owned production machinery and plant used previously by the company has been sold. All Government-owned equipment remaining at Hawker de Havilland used to support F/A-18 engine maintenance is available for transfer to Air New Zealand Engineering Services.

(7) The Government's investment in production machinery has already been partially recovered and (b) Defence will make every effort to maximise the benefits or return for this investment, where current Government-owned F/A-18 engine maintenance equipment at Hawker de Havilland is identified as being excess to the requirements of Air New Zealand Engineering Services.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 7 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware that plant nurseries are continuing to sell rubbervine and other potential weed species as ornamental plants in States other than Queensland where rubbervine is recognised as a `declared weed'.
(2) Is the Minister aware of the current high infestation levels in Queensland and the very real threat of the spread of rubbervine to the Northern Territory from sea borne seeds.

(3) Is a draft national weeds strategy being considered in co-operation with State governments to ensure that: (a) the nursery trade is encouraged to adopt a responsible policy on plant sales; and (b) national control strategies of prevention and eradication are implemented to prevent future spread of rubbervine and other potential weed species, and joint campaigns are undertaken in affected areas to eradicate currently high infestation levels of rubbervine in northern Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I became aware in January 1995 that plant nurseries in States other than Queensland continue to sell rubbervine.
(2) Yes, I have been advised of the major problem faced by Queensland and the Northern Territory on the spread of rubbervine.

(3) A draft National Weeds Strategy is under consideration in close consultation with the relevant Commonwealth, State and Territory agencies that have responsibility for such matters. I understand that the National Weeds Strategy (NWS) addresses the trade in problem plant species between the States and Territories and the development of national control strategies to eradicate and prevent the spread of major and new weed problems, such as rubbervine, across Australia. It is anticipated that the draft NWS will be considered by appropriate Ministerial Councils in the near future.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 10 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Was a management plan for the Willandra Lakes World Heritage Area promised by the Australian Heritage Commission in 1982, to be implemented within 12 months.
(2) Has this management plan been released or indeed written.
(3) Can a guarantee be given that it will be released by September 1995; if so, can the landholders be confident that this guarantee will not be broken.

(4) Given the fact that 17 landholders at Willandra Lakes have lost $4.6 million in income and up to $10 million in property values since the area was World Heritage listed, will compensation be forthcoming from the Federal Government; if so, when will compensation be forthcoming.
(5) Will Federal Government compensation include interest from the date that the area was World Heritage listed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) (2) and (3) No. It is not, nor has it ever been, the role of the Australian Heritage Commission to prepare a management plan for the Willandra Lakes Region. The Commonwealth provided funding to NSW for a number of projects associated with the preparation of a management plan under the National Estate Grants Program between 1982 and 1988. These projects did not result in the implementation of a management plan.

Following the implementation of new administrative and management arrangements in 1993, my department has contracted Manidis Roberts Planning Consultants to prepare a management plan for the Willandra Lakes Region World Heritage Property. On current estimates, this plan will be released by September 1995. It then becomes the responsibility of the relevant NSW authorities to give the plan appropriate statutory effect.

(4) and (5) The Commonwealth has commissioned a study of the socio-economic impacts of the World Heritage listing of the Willandra Lakes Region on local landholders. The study covers the period from listing in 1981 to July 1993, when the new administrative arrangements were implemented. The revised draft report is currently being reviewed by relevant Commonwealth and NSW agencies, and is expected to be finalised by the end of March.

I will not comment on the revised draft report, or questions of compensation, until the Commonwealth and New South Wales governments have reviewed and considered the contents, methodology and recommendations of the final report.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 28 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What are the restrictions on the ability of the military police to have any power over civilians.
(2) Are defence forces able to be involved in local disaster planning at the State or regional level.

(3) Has the Government given consideration to enabling military police to assist State police in responding to civil unrest such as street fights or pub brawls in areas where there is a low number of police.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) With one exception, military police have no powers over civilians by virtue of their status as military police. The exception relates to the Defence Force Discipline Act. That Act provides for persons other than members of the Defence Force to be declared to be `Defence civilians', when they accompany a part of the Defence Force outside Australia or on operations against the enemy and have consented in writing to be subject to the Act. A military police officer has certain specific powers in relation to investigation of offences under the Act, meaning that a police officer might have powers exercisable in relation to Defence civilians. There are presently no persons who are `Defence civilians' for the purposes of the Act.
In limited circumstances specified in legislation, members of the Defence Force, including military police, do have powers over civilians.

For example, under section 82 of the Defence Act, a member of the Defence Force may arrest a person who is believed on reasonable grounds to have committed an offence against the section, namely trespassing on Defence establishments or photographing or sketching Defence equipment. Under the Defence (Special Undertakings) Act, a `Commonwealth officer' (which term includes a member of the Defence Force) may apprehend a person in the vicinity of a `prohibited area' (an area declared to be prohibited under the Act) and suspected of having committed an offence against the Act.

(2) Although disaster relief is the responsibility of the states and territories, in circumstances where their resources are inadequate to deal with a particular emergency, or they are unable to react with sufficient speed, the Defence Force may assist.

ANSWER.PARA: In particular, assistance of this nature may be provided where immediate action is necessary to prevent loss of life or widespread property damage.

PARA.TAB: The coordination of Defence assistance would normally be facilitated through Defence liaison officers in each capital city and regional commanders in other localities. These officers maintain close contact with state emergency relief authorities and often participate in state emergency exercises.

The development of state disaster preparedness plans would not normally involve Defence directly. However, Defence liaison officers do interact with state coordinators in planning once Defence assistance has been sought. This interaction occurs at both the state and local level.

(3) Law enforcement tasks such as dealing with civil unrest are the province of state and territory law enforcement authorities. It is not envisaged that the Defence Force would be used to assist with such tasks except in the most extreme circumstances, and then only after all other alternative means of dealing with the problem had been exhausted.

Under section 51 of the Defence Act, State Governors may proclaim that domestic violence exists, and may request the Governor-General to call out the Defence Force for the protection of the State against domestic violence. If this has occurred, the Minister may authorise a part of the Defence Force to move to the vicinity of the incident, following which the appropriate civil authority may request a part of the Defence Force to assist in the law enforcement role. In such a case, Defence Force policy requires that those members involved use the minimum force necessary to achieve the purpose. They remain subject to military command, but are also subject to the normal civil law, which is not suspended by reason of the involvement of the Defence Force.
The Government has no intention to change this policy so as to expand the circumstances in which the Defence Force becomes involved in civil law enforcement tasks.
